[h1] Race Across North America! [/h1]
The Crew 2 is a 2018 open world racing video game developed by Ubisoft Ivory Tower and published by Ubisoft. The Crew 2 features a persistent open world environment for free-roaming across a scaled-down recreation of the Contiguous United States. The game allows players to control a variety of vehicles including cars, motorcycles, boats, and airplanes.

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üíæGraphics[/td]
        [td] The game looks fantastic! The world looks beautiful and the weather system helps make the world look even better. The car models are stunning and really detailed. The character models look pretty good too. Sadly the mirrors do not work, and the steering animation is horrible. You're lucky to get a 90 degree turn. The character just barely turns it and it can be distracting if you are playing in the interior view. Also the UI in my opinion just feels messy and can take a little bit of time to get used to. Besides that gripe, the game is just stunning and in my opinion aged pretty well.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üéÆGameplay[/td]
        [td] The Crew 2 has some really good features. One is the incredible amount of cars here. You have dirt bikes, speed bikes, planes, helicopters, demolition cars, sportcars, race cars, F1 cars, etc. The list is absolutely insane and one of the best car lists in any game out there. The upgrade system is simple and has good progression, luckily you can switch your upgrades to other cars in their respective category so the grind for upgrades is not that bad here. The grind for money (in my opinion) is horrible. Making money here will suck and takes forever to make good money, especially if you are wanting to get many vehicles in the game. Some may like it, but I don't. The Motorpass (which is basically like their season/battlepasses) is a complete joke. Now you can get the Motorpass for ‚Äúfree‚Äù, but have fun spending 3+ million for it, or hey you can spend real money. You do have the option to spend real money in this game (hint at the insane grind). It kinda overshadows the experience, but nowhere near as bad as the events (I will talk about in the story section). The sense of speed is really good here and you do have some sort of customization. Don‚Äôt expect a need for speed levels of customization, but it‚Äôs pretty solid, it just depends on what vehicle you want to customize (as some don‚Äôt really have many options). The photo mode is really good here too, you can change the weather, time of day, with many awesome filters to mess with (perfect for you photographers). The physics here are actually pretty solid. The drifting though was a mix bag, but once you get use to it, it‚Äôs okay (still nothing great).[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üìúStory[/td]
        [td] The story is pretty vague. Basically just beat all of the main events (Freestyle, Offroad, Pro Racing, Street Racing, etc). You also have many more events since this game has been getting frequent updates. The Summit allows you to unlock limited time items and vehicles which are actually really fun and rewarding. Some of the other events are fun though, like dirt biking for example and street races. Sadly most of the events are a bore fest. Mainly just racing yourself and no one else (well a timed race but same thing). You will do these timed races ALOT! I almost lost my mind just doing these races. The ending didn‚Äôt feel all that rewarding here and I was immediately back into the grind of doing these boring event races. This is the biggest weakness The Crew 2 has, so just be warned that most events are pretty underwhelming here.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üé≠Multiplayer[/td]
        [td]The multiplayer was pretty fun here. Being able to do races with your friends was a blast. The best part was traveling around the map with a buddy. Doing cruises in some JDM cars or motorcycles was an absolute blast. Even cruising in planes/boats or going off road on a dirt bike felt so unique compared to other racing games (like the Forza Horizon series for example). Honestly if you are planning on buying a game to cruise with friends, this is a must buy for that reason alone. It was super addicting and fun.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üïõPlaytime[/td]
        [td]With the amount of content and events, you have a ton of playtime here. The grind will also promote a longer playtime as well. If you can get a buddy to play with you will sink in a ton of time here. The game took me around 50 hours to get all of the achievements, and I still have a ton of cars to unlock so you will have a ton of time with progression in The Crew 2 no problem![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üéßSound[/td]
        [td]The cars sound pretty average. I will say some cars do sound really good, but don‚Äôt expect most of them to sound impressive. The dialogue here is horrible. With cheesy lines that will make the hair on your neck stand up from cringe. Ubisoft has a thing for bad dialogue, I don‚Äôt know why.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]‚ùóBugs‚ùó[/td]
        [td] I have gotten stuck on rocks plenty of times, so offroading can be kinda sketchy. I had my game act weird with the menu at times. With me having to exit the menu and starting it up again helped. Like it wouldn‚Äôt load up the next menu, it can be odd at times.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üîÖPerformance[/td]
        [td]The game runs at a solid 60 fps on max settings so frame drops were non-existent here. The bad part is that I would be getting these stutters during races. Not during free roam, which was weird. But certain events would make my game stutter. I tried lowering my graphics, or turning off Uplay overlay but nothing changed at all for me. This could just be a me issue so keep that in mind.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]‚úîÔ∏èPro‚Äôs[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Solid graphics
[*]Tons of content
[*]Huge/Diverse car list
[*]Huge open world
[*]Great photo mode
[*]Decent driving physics
[*]Diverse set of events
[*]Still supported with updates
[*]Car customization (but limited depending on your vehicle)
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]‚ùåCon‚Äôs[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Grindy
[*]UI is messy
[*]Always online
[*]Stuttering issues
[*]Cringy dialogue
[*]Motorpass is a joke
[*]Get repetitive really fast
[*]Horrible Force feedback
[*]Car sounds are average (some good ones)
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üèÜRating[/td]
        [td]6/10
Buy this game on a steep sale if possible (around 75% off or more) [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üîóConclusion[/td]
        [td]The Crew 2 has a beautiful map, and a huge diverse car list that I adore greatly. Sadly the events and issues surrounding this game, makes this a mixed bag for me. I‚Äôm gonna recommend it because it may not be for me, but I can see many people enjoying this game that want a more casual and easy racing game. This game has very little challenge (except the grind), so if you are a more casual player, you may enjoy this game. Just know that the events are underwhelming, but you can explore an amazing map with friends and have a good time. Just make sure you put the time in to get the cars you want as the progression is really slow. [/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

On principle I don't think anyone should buy this game as it'll be shut down within a few years for certain with no capability to play offline. If you also like driving to the middle of nowhere this is also pretty good for that, had a good amount of fun doing that in between doing trials and drift challenges.
Don't buy unless you're OK with them taking away your purchase a few years down the road.

I used to play this game a lot as a kid and I remember that I was about Icon 800 on Playstation.

The game has a great selection of cars, a gigantic map, many races and a decent playerbase. All of these are good things, and I used to love this game, so what's my problem with it?

As I said the map is gigantic, a lot of great cities like Miami, San Francisco, New York, Washington DC, Dallas etc. [b]But my god[/b], is it lifeless. If you actually drive in one of these cities it'll feel like driving in a cardboard box, it is genuinely, [b]INSANE[/b], how empty these cities are. Not to mention the fact that they all look exactly the same.

I do believe they attempted to fix this issue for Motorsports, but come on, the game has been out for 6 years. We have to remember that Ubisoft is behind this game, we know for a fact they could've made a much better map by just putting in a little more effort.

Ubisoft just shut down The Crew 1 on very short notice with no offline patch or anything. Us consumers who paid to play the game can no longer play the game at all. It is inevitably going to happen to this game too. I made the mistake of buying into an always online game and I don't others to make the same mistake as me. 

Do not buy into these greedy companies that will take your money and leave you with nothing.

Edit [b]January 23rd, 2024[/b] 
The original Crew 1 is shutting down March 31st, 2024. This is a huge disappointment because I used to really like the original one, to the point I acquired 2 copies (on separate Ubisoft Accounts).

I'm not review bombing this as it makes no sense to, but I'm very disappointed in the path you would go. Some people (well I'm not one of them who paid full price each time) will miss the original title, and if the way I see it happens, The Crew 2 is subject to the same treatment in the coming years.

A lot of disappointment in 2024 already starting. I'd like to see more optimistic approaches for the remainder of this year.

Original review below (2018):

A lot of reviews I've read are related to a mistake that happened yesterday (June 28) but they have appeared to have fixed the issue since 8:00AM Pacific this morning.

I know a lot of reviews are writing about how crappy that is, but the point of this review is to point out that not everything is wrong.

For The Crew 2, when it was announced in E3 2017, I had lots of high hopes. This led my uplay account to be flagged (in a good way) to enter the Closed Alpha (NDA required), the Closed Beta, and the Open Beta. I also pre-purchased the Gold Edition since April 2018, and had absolutely no launch issues when it went live at 9:00PM PDT June 25.

Let me go in depth on why this is a good game, and my recommendations:

[b]Positive:[/b]

[b]+ Very large open world[/b]
This is a core aspect of the game. In fact [spoiler]one of the achievements requires you to go outside of the map zones, which is easily done in New England with an airplane[/spoiler] and it has an icon of an octopus, which actually is pretty funny.

[b]+ Variety of races[/b]
At the start of the game, you are thrown into a series of crazy races. These involve 3 of the [spoiler]10 or so discliplines of The Crew 2[/spoiler] and then you must complete a series of trials to unlock the ability to purchase those types of vehicles. They give you one vehicle for free on the 1st disclipines of each branch of racing which are [spoiler]Street Racing, Pro Racing, Offroad, and Freestyle[/spoiler] while the rest you must purchase with in-game cash.

[b]+ In-Game Cash seemingly easy to make[/b]
Unlike The Crew 1 (which I got for free during Ubi's Christmas one year), The Crew 2 puts efforts into their money system easier. Crew Credits (CC) do make a return, however it is not an absolute core to buying the dream car you want. While playing The Crew 2's early access Gold Edition, I managed to purchase the most expensive car in the game upon reaching the [spoiler] Icon 1 [/spoiler] rank. There also is an achievement related to this as well on Steam. I only say this point because every time you rank up, they [spoiler]Pay you $125,000 and 10,000 CC except past Icon 1[/spoiler].

[b]+ Different ways to explore the game world[/b]
Well the first thing is, some people think (especially those who've played The Crew 1) the ability to "Fast Travel" was removed. But, actually, this was removed to a small extent - you can still travel to event start locations and skill start locations as well. Besides, while driving on the game world, you might encounter [spoiler] Live Rewards, which give loot drops, which are almost always upgrades. Blue upgrades also give an affix, and Purple upgrades give 2 affixes [/spoiler].

Neutral:

[b]Airplane Controls are iffy plus cause issues for new players[/b]

By Default the controls for airplanes are actually self-explainatory in the introduction, but I strongly recommend you disable STICKY KEYS and FILTER KEYS (you do not need to dsiable TOGGLE KEYS, the game doesn't require you to use that key) and  (from Windows Accessibility commands) because you will run into those two always if you use the default controls. (R+Shift to decrease altitude, R+CTRL to increase altitude, W to increase throttle, S to reduce throttle, A and D to turn fast)

[b]Loot drops sometimes go in your favor, other times, they don't.[/b]

This isn't really a negative point, but when you see Blues and Purples drop, you have to look at the affixes (F9 on performance screen) and see if they are good affixes. [spoiler]All the affixes you do see are actual unlockables for Icon Points, once you reach Icon 1.[/spoiler] Due to this, I sometimes must use lower quality item parts to keep the good affixes on my vehicles.

[b]GPS sucks compared to The Crew 1[/b]

Forgot to add this point in my comprehensive review. This is actually a problem because it forces you to pay attention to your map (since there is no line, like there was in The Crew 1) and they should consider re-adding it.

Negative:

[b]-No PVP Interactions in game (extremely rare)[/b]

Unlike The Crew 1, finding a player in-game at the same time is very rare. Not to mention, it's almost impossible to spot out their location on the in-game map. This is a mistake and should be corrected, since The Crew 1 was known for that reason.

[b]-PVP Modes unavailable at launch[/b]

I do not usually PVP, but I understand that people are upset that they did not include this feature at launch. However, Ivory Tower developers and The Crew 2 discord users have confirmed that their major update in September will release [spoiler]Legendary loot drops (I'm going to assume 3 affixes) and the Hovercraft races.[/spoiler] Unfortunately, we have to wait for PVP until December (in their 2nd major update.)

[b]-You probably need a good computer to run this game[/b]

There are some locations that I've lagged out with a fairly decent rig (GTX 1060 6GB & i6500 4.4Ghz) and there is a frame cap of 60 (which is not necessary but I see why they are doing that). 

[b]CONCLUSION[/b]

The Crew 2 absolutely lives to my expectations, even more then when I purchased Destiny 2's $100 edition. The fact I shedded out $100 for The Crew 2 (and invited into all phases of their testing) should tell me that it was going to be a great game.

Graphics: 10 / 10 (excluding high system requirements and 60 FPS cap)
Sound: 10 / 10 (good music choice, always keep it on. Theme is spot on, you also can unlock it through the Ubisoft Club.)
Gameplay: 10 / 10 (lots of races to choose from)
Multiplayer: 6 / 10 (for now, until the 1st major update)
Loot/Vehicle Variety: 9 / 10 (not Battlefront 2 or NFS Carbon, thank goodness.)
Leveling Flow: 10 / 10 (Very consistent, and very lasting)
[b]OVERALL: 9.17 / 10[/b]

[b]Recommendation? [/b]
I recommend this game. But if you do not want to pay $60, wait for a sale.
It's a great game, and when they release their 1st major update, it will get better. Trust me.

It's a great game. Please give them credit for their hard work since E3 2017.

The Crew‚Ñ¢ 2 offers a huge map to explore with a lot of activities,stories or events to do. It's a great alternative to Forza Horizon titles.

On its own terms the game shines ,with original ideas like Fast Nav,switching from plane to car to boat smoothly. This is a one of kind experience .

The crew 2 is impressive in terms of quantity, but i'm afraid they left out what matters  the most : attention to detail and quality. However some areas and aspects of the game are build well like impressive track designs and original ideas.

In terms of gameplay ,it feels arcade and less realistic..but once you understand how it works it's a decent experience. Feels different than other racing games on the market and that's a positive. 

I really liked the followers and loot systems. After each activity you earn followers that can increase your popularity level. At higher popularity levels you'll unlock more disciplines and activities.Also you earn parts to upgrade your car which provides a unique leveling system and a sense of progression.

I'm still waiting for Crew Motorfest on steam, it's strange how Ubisoft decides to shoot his own foot!

Ok then..... I originally bought Crew2 back in 2018. At that time I had a MSI GTX970. The game crashed often for me. I also got tired of waiting for so long for the game to load. I thought the graphics were really good. There was lots I didn't like about the game at that time. 

But here I am in 2024 and running a MSI RTX3080. I am running it at 4k resolution on a 65" screen. I am extremely happy with the graphics. The latency with my G27 wheel is not too bad either. I'm running a 15-3670k processor from 2012. It's keeping up. I am enjoying the game and discovering lots of cool things in it. The landscape and other terrain is very good. Overall, I have to say this is definately one of the most fun driving games out there. One of the downsides is that there doesn't seem to be live players that want to race etc. I don't know.... maybe I don't know something.  It's different to Project Cars type games. In some ways it reminds me of NFS The Run. NFS The Run had so much potential.

The Crew 2 Review: A Thrilling Open-World Racing Experience

The Crew 2, developed by Ivory Tower and published by Ubisoft, is an ambitious open-world racing game that offers a vast and diverse landscape for players to explore.

Strengths:

Expansive Open World: The Crew 2 boasts a massive and detailed open-world environment set in a scaled-down version of the United States. The diversity in landscapes, from bustling cities to scenic countryside, provides a rich playground for exploration.

Versatile Vehicles: One of the standout features is the wide variety of vehicles available, including cars, motorcycles, boats, and planes. The seamless transition between different vehicle types adds a layer of dynamism to the gameplay.

Stunning Visuals: The game's graphics are impressive, capturing the essence of various locations with attention to detail. The day-night cycle and dynamic weather contribute to a visually engaging experience.

Weaknesses:

Narrative and Characters: The storyline and characters may feel secondary to the overall gameplay. Some players might find the narrative lacking depth compared to other aspects of the game.

AI Behavior: At times, the AI behavior during races can be inconsistent, leading to moments of frustration. Improved AI logic could enhance the overall racing experience.

Innovative Features:

Photo Mode and Content Creation: The Crew 2 introduces a robust photo mode, allowing players to capture and share their best in-game moments. The content creation tools add a layer of creativity to the overall experience.

Live Xtrem Series: The addition of Live Xtrem Series events, featuring a combination of different vehicle types in a single race, adds a unique and exciting element to the racing genre.

Conclusion:

The Crew 2 successfully builds upon its predecessor, offering a thrilling open-world racing experience with a diverse range of vehicles. While it may have some narrative shortcomings and occasional AI issues, the game excels in providing an expansive and visually stunning world for racing enthusiasts.

This is a HORRIBLE game. Graphics are trash, Game-play is trash, Car mechanics are trash, Car sounds are trash. Absolutely one of, if not THE worst car game.

Update:

TL;DR; Game still sucks. 
- The soundtrack feels like you are eternally playing inside an elevator. Indie games have better soundtrack than this game.
- Story and Progression is non existent. And every single NPC sounds like an A Hole, why is everyone so aggressive to one another? It sounds like the development switched directions at some point and they already had the voices recorded.
- Devs/Managers refuse to fix the Dualsense controller bug - It might be intentional? I wonder.  
- Compared to Forza, driving is just awful, it is not just because it is arcade either. To be honest GTA III did better vehicle physics than this game. And on the topic GTA Vice City probably did Boats and Planes better too.
- And don't get me started about the rarity/score upgrade system. It is an annoying way to smoke screen your player into not noticing that: in reality, you don't have all that much content. To say the least. 
- Whoever planned and developed the UI/UX and keybinding for it needs to be arrested by the gaming police. Slow, Clunky, Nowhere near streamlined, it is a Maze. I bet you 100 bucks a 5 year old can plan a better UI. Damn frankly I can do it myself. 

I want to end this by saying TC1 was a better game.

=====

Ever since the Alpha and Beta I posted on the forums regarding some of what will be present on this feedback.

TL;DR the game feels, unpolished, rushed and unfinished. It does not have a tenth of the immersion The Crew 1 had. Although the car models look nice some have incomplete customization options and the scenery in general looks poor/worse  than The Crew 1.

The Story:
  Even though The Crew 1's story was somewhat weak, The Crew 2 simply gives no mention of importance to put you in the game with a nice story driven content. And to make it worse everyone you meet at the start of the game seems to be a jerk. It really throws me away from even trying to like the characters.

Menus: 
  The Menus and GUI are a pain. I had to spend a few minutes just to figure out that Ubisoft, out of their endless pit of knowledge, decided no to use the ESC button to call in the menu. But then again, the whole UX and UI is slow and sluggish, too many clicks and lack of critical information all over the place.

Un skipabble content:
   There is a lot... get used to it.

Planes:
   Planes feel sluggish and slow and the flight dynamics are just awful, even for the most arcadish ever simulation of a plane I can think of, the model lacks just too much to be fun. And of course the default control scheme will get you into a keyboard ghosting situation real quick. 

Cars and Boats:
   Well no complain here, they feel fast and have a nice handling - so far. Although I feel there is a lot of customization missing in the game.

There is a lot to be done, and I doubt they will, better keep with The Crew 1.

Games sold as Single Player titles should have offline capabilities. They should not have Always Online features. It is appalling how disconnected the companies are from their clientele. 
As long as the product is sold and non-refundable, they are good. If the patch doesn't come out for the game that is being taken down just because Online features and upkeep of the servers are not feasible things for the company, it will clearly show there the interest lies. 

People get it, keeping up with server payments and infrastructure is costly and doesn't get cheaper, but if you pull a license from paying customers just like that, I really hope people will take notice and never buy anything from them going forward. 

I won't, and will do my best to advise everyone I can to steer clear from companies like Ubisoft and Electronic Arts. 

And I really do hope companies that feel that it's an okay thing to do to their customers will implode and close up shop. It would suck for talented people who work on good games, but they are not the ones that profit from their own creations.

Edit: If anything, it would be somewhat of a fun time to pirate games of the said company to enjoy them for free. And without the constant worry that the library I've spent money on will go AWOL because some asshole in a suit made a call. I'm more than happy to pay for games I play, but the sad reality we all worried about for about a decade and a half start to creep in - If it's not Physical, don't buy it. I'm sure there will be more and more precedents like this and the big companies will hide behind "anti-piracy drm" argument with their Always Online bullshit as well. 
I guess it's about time we dust off the old consoles and revisit some second-hand marketplaces for games we like.

[h1][b]The Crew 2 Review - Revving Up the Open World Racing Experience[/b][/h1]

[h2][b]Introduction:[/b][/h2]

[b]"The Crew 2"[/b] roars onto the gaming scene, promising a dynamic open-world racing experience that goes beyond the conventional. Released to eager audiences, this game takes the wheel, offering players a diverse and thrilling journey across a vast virtual America.

[hr][/hr]

[h3]Gameplay (8/10):[/h3]
    
The gameplay in [b]"The Crew 2"[/b] is a high-octane blend of racing styles, seamlessly transitioning between cars, boats, planes, and motorcycles. The open-world design encourages exploration, allowing players to seamlessly switch between vehicle types and conquer varied terrains. The dynamic and responsive controls contribute to an exhilarating racing experience.
    
[h3]Graphics (9/10):[/h3]
    
Visually, [b]"The Crew 2"[/b] stands as a showcase of graphical prowess. The game boasts stunning landscapes, detailed vehicle models, and realistic weather effects. The day-night cycle and dynamic weather further enhance the immersion, creating a visually stunning world for players to race through.
    
[h3]Sound/Music (8/10):[/h3]
    
The sound design in [b]"The Crew 2"[/b] revs up the excitement, with realistic engine roars, screeching tires, and the rush of wind as players soar through the skies. The soundtrack complements the fast-paced action, offering a diverse selection of tunes that enhance the overall adrenaline-fueled atmosphere.
    
[h3]Features and Innovation (8/10):[/h3]
    
[b]"The Crew 2"[/b] introduces an expansive open-world playground where players can showcase their racing skills across various disciplines. The innovative aspect lies in the seamless transition between different vehicle types, providing a unique and exhilarating twist to the traditional racing genre. The variety of events and challenges keep the gameplay fresh and engaging.
    
[h3]Story/Plot (6/10):[/h3]
    
While not the central focus, [b]"The Crew 2"[/b] weaves a loose narrative around the player's journey to become a racing icon. The story serves as a backdrop, providing context for the various events and challenges. However, the narrative may feel secondary to the gameplay for those seeking a more story-driven experience.
    
[h3]Replay Value (9/10):[/h3]
    
With a plethora of events, races, and challenges scattered throughout the open-world map, [b]"The Crew 2"[/b] excels in replayability. The vast array of vehicles and disciplines, combined with regular updates and community events, ensures that players will find themselves returning to the virtual streets for more adrenaline-fueled action.

[h3]Technical Details (7/10):[/h3]

[b]"The Crew 2"[/b] showcases technical polish, offering smooth performance and minimal bugs or glitches. The attention to detail in both graphics and gameplay contributes to a well-rounded and enjoyable gaming experience. The developers' commitment to addressing issues and improving the game is evident in regular updates.
    
[hr][/hr]

[h2][b]Conclusion:[/b][/h2]

[b]"The Crew 2"[/b] delivers a high-octane racing experience with a vast open world, stunning visuals, and diverse gameplay mechanics. While the story takes a backseat to the exhilarating races, the game excels in providing a thrilling adventure for racing enthusiasts. With its innovative approach, variety of vehicles, and ongoing support, [b]"The Crew 2"[/b] earns its place as a top-tier open-world racing game.

[h2][b]Rating: 8/10[/b][/h2]

This one kind of hurts, because I always wanted a good open world racing game where you had access to multiple states or countries and were able to transition seamlessly between them. 

The Crew 2 kind of does this, but in an extremely unfulfilling way. It takes the joy out of actually traversing across these states due to unpolished vehicle movements, wonky ai mechanics and poorly rendered surroundings. The civilian vehicle npcs are tragic and will oftentimes disappear 100 feet in front of you, being somehow replaced by either thin air or a different vehicle altogether. They'll honk at you if they're in the opposite lane on a bent road (unpolished distance/impact measuring). The ones walking around in the cities will dramatically jump out of the way even though you're just casually cruising on the road, nowhere near the sidewalk. 

The switching mechanic is kind of cool, but again doesn't really get used enough. Not only does it ruin immersion but it's trying too hard to be multiple things at once. Oddly, being in the plane feels like home for this game. The textures don't look that crappy from up there and you won't notice the ai as much.

The whole thing just feels like something Ubisoft would make and they definitely stuck with their formula on this one. A massive open world with tons of opportunities that may look extremely interesting at first glance, but is shallow and empty underneath the thin layer of temporary excitement.

Just as a disclaimer, the Crew series is actually not bad, but for anyone who hasn‚Äôt noticed this yet, yesterday Ubisoft spontaneously delisted The Crew 1 and also announced that the game will be shutdowned and unplayable after March ‚Äô24. Sorry, this is absolutely inexcusable. They tried this with their DLCs last year (but rowed back due to the sh**storm), yet seriously, now this again??!! Don‚Äôt get me wrong, The Crew 1 is actually a great game which has quite some single player story content, obviously even an offline mode is integrated hidden in the files (due to some programmers in the community who are working on a mod, see the forum discussions), so there‚Äôs obviously no real reason to not give us customers (who paid for all those expensive season passes and DLCs) an offline function. Ubisoft really needs to stop their extremely toxic anti-consumer behavior, because meanwhile even I (I always defended them in the past) am losing interest in their products. And another joke, if you want to complain at the moment, there‚Äôs even no official Ubisoft internet forum anymore, only one on Discord (where all discussions get lost anyway). Uggh, sorry, this just had to get out, it‚Äôs just super frustrating. 

And regarding The Crew 2, yeah, if we tolerate this behavior, The Crew 2 will go the same way, as will probably go a lot of other Ubisoft games with multiplayer online integration.
Not a fan of the game, and not a fan of ubisoft's anti-consumer practices. If I didn't get this game at a massive discount, I'd have refunded.

The game is ok-ish, but seriously - [b]f*ck Ubisoft and their f*cked up practices[/b].

[h1] The Crew 2: Navigating the Mixed Terrain of Racing Entertainment [/h1]

Embark on a cross-country journey in The Crew 2, where land, air, and sea converge to create a diverse and expansive playground for motorsport enthusiasts. With a multitude of vehicles and an open-world expanse mimicking the USA, the game promises a high-speed, action-packed experience. However, it's not without its share of strengths and weaknesses.

Pros:

Multifaceted Gameplay: The Crew 2 introduces a unique blend of racing disciplines, allowing players to seamlessly switch between cars, bikes, boats, and planes. The sheer variety of vehicles and racing modes adds an extra layer of excitement to the gameplay.

Vast Open World: Spanning the entire USA, the open-world map offers a rich and expansive playground for exploration. The ability to engage in leisurely drives, road trips, and intense races across iconic locations contributes to the game's immersive experience.

Vehicle Variety: The game boasts an extensive collection of vehicles, ranging from traditional cars to boats, planes, and bikes. This diversity caters to different racing preferences, ensuring that players can find a vehicle that suits their style.

Visual Improvements: Over its predecessor, The Crew 2 exhibits graphical enhancements, showcasing improved visuals and more detailed environments. The game captures the beauty of various landscapes, enhancing the overall visual experience.

Continued Content Updates: Despite the release of The Crew 3, The Crew 2 continues to receive content updates, including new game modes, tracks, vehicles, and events. The ongoing support from developers keeps the game fresh and engaging.

Community Engagement: With a large player base, The Crew 2 fosters a sense of community among players. The option to play with up to seven friends online enhances the social aspect of the game.

Accessibility: The game offers a trial period, allowing players to experience The Crew 2 for free for a limited time. This feature provides an opportunity for players to determine if the game aligns with their preferences before making a purchase.

Enjoyable Exploration: The game excels in delivering an exploration-focused experience, allowing players to casually drive through iconic locations and relish the diverse landscapes.

Cons:

Inferior to Predecessor: Some players express disappointment, stating that The Crew 2 falls short of its predecessor in various aspects. This sentiment extends to elements such as boats and planes, which are considered by some as gimmicks, and the game's wheel support, perceived as inferior to the original.

Performance Issues: Certain players report performance issues, including crashes and lock-ups, particularly on high-end rigs. Such technical problems may impact the overall gaming experience and potentially lead to frustration.

Monetization Concerns: Microtransactions and the introduction of predatory practices in the form of paid content have raised concerns among players. While not forced, these microtransactions can restrict access to significant content, creating a sense of frustration.

Repetition and Lack of Challenge: The single-player experience is criticized for its repetition, with a noticeable bias toward Street Race events. The abundance of Street Race events compared to other disciplines, combined with AI that lacks challenge, contributes to a less enthralling single-player experience.

Devs' Lack of Responsiveness: Players express frustration over what they perceive as a lack of responsiveness from developers to player feedback. The perception that the developers prioritize monetization over addressing player concerns may impact the overall relationship between the gaming community and the development team.

Limited Variety and Boring Events: Despite the promise of diversity, some players find the game lacking in variety, particularly in terms of the vehicles introduced through updates. The focus on Street Race events, both in the base game and updates, can lead to a monotonous experience.

Empty and Bland Map: The open-world map is criticized for feeling empty, bland, and at times soulless. Copy-pasted elements, stretches of empty road, and condensed towns contribute to a map that falls short of the vibrant and dynamic environment expected in an open-world racing game.

Graphical Quality: While there are visual improvements, some players find the graphics, while good, not up to the standards set by other modern racing games like Forza.

Final Verdict:

The Crew 2 navigates a mixed terrain, offering a multifaceted racing experience set in an expansive open world. While it successfully introduces diverse vehicles and gameplay modes, it stumbles in areas such as performance issues, monetization concerns, and perceived shortcomings compared to its predecessor. For players seeking an accessible and exploration-focused racing game with a variety of vehicles, The Crew 2 may be a worthwhile experience. However, those prioritizing realism, robust challenge, and a responsive developer-player relationship might find some aspects lacking. The game's strengths lie in its community engagement, vast open world, and ongoing content updates, making it a decent choice for those looking for a casual open-world racing experience.

Let's be real, The Crew 2 is kind of a mixed bag, but it leans more towards a good game, hence the recommendation.

Visually, it's in this weird in between. The free roam and most races will look pretty bad in 90% of the cases, very flat colors, lack of detailed textures on buildings, and the general shading looks quite fake and off. But in certain free roam situations and races, when the settings are just right, it looks GORGEOUS for no reason. Cars look good but some models have lower polygon count, but that's to be expected if you want to fit 600+ vehicles in a 60Gb game. 

Gameplay is... not it. The cars feel way too responsive and grippy, and even a slight steering input might make your car go crazy. It's not helped by the fact car settings aren't well explained, you don't even know what does what. 
Don't even get me started on planes. If you don't have the "feeling" for them, then you're going to hate those.
The structure of the game is interesting, I like the 4 branches with many disciplines in them, and once you complete enough in a branch, you get to fight its boss for a big cash reward and a new car. Also some races switch up the vibe of the game drastically (like that one Street Car event that makes the game look like a retro game).
I personally am fine with the Motorpass, it gives an avenue to earn cosmetics and the paid pass that allows for unlocking premium rewards is a one time purchase, which I appreciate. It is a bit too expensive though.
I do feel quite annoyed by the "premium money" packs that trivialise some things like buying new cars but a lot more annoyed at the fact it's the only currency that can buy cosmetics that rotate every week, I don't like it when games try to exploit FOMO even if it's just with visual stuff.
My personal favorite feature though, is the fact that if you're going to play The Crew Motorfest, you'll be able to import your TC2 collection of cars and cosmetics, which actually doesn't make your TC2 collection disappear, it's just getting copied over to TCM which is great imo.  

Music is solid, some good choices are in there but I'm sad there's no songs from The Heavy, their inclusion in 2014's The Crew elevated it in my opinion.

The game runs well enough on my PC, but 2014's The Crew had pretty bad periodic stuttering and while The Crew 2 doesn't have the exact same issue, I do encounter near-constant stuttering in the game. The solution I found was to lower my screen's refresh rate to 59Hz in Windows settings before launching the game. So be aware this game has issues.

All in all, it's a solid 14-15/20. It's fun, but the handling model will make you frustrated more than anything else. Can be worth it to get it before Motorfest if you're planning on playing it too.

Crew 2 sets out to be a diverse open-world racing game, but unfortunately, it falls short in several key areas, resulting in a lackluster experience that fails to live up to its potential.

One of the game's notable aspects is its expansive open-world map, featuring a scaled-down version of the United States. However, while the map is vast and diverse, the world lacks depth and fails to offer a truly immersive experience. The environments feel empty and devoid of life, making exploration less engaging than anticipated.

The variety of vehicles available is a highlight, allowing players to switch between cars, boats, planes, and bikes on the fly. However, the handling and physics of these vehicles often feel unrealistic and beyond arcade-like, detracting from the game's immersion. The lack of depth in the driving mechanics may disappoint players seeking a more realistic racing experience.

Additionally, the progression system feels uninspired and lacks innovation. The missions and races become repetitive quickly, lacking the necessary variety and challenge to keep players engaged in the long run. The storyline, too, feels shallow and fails to provide a compelling narrative to drive the gameplay forward.

The multiplayer aspect, while promising, suffers from various issues, including connectivity problems and a lack of meaningful interactions between players. This diminishes the potential for engaging cooperative or competitive experiences that could have added depth to the game.

In summary, Crew 2 falls short of expectations due to its lack of depth in the open-world design, shallow progression system, and underwhelming handling of vehicles. While it offers a diverse range of vehicles and a vast open world, the execution leaves much to be desired, resulting in a gaming experience that feels more hollow than immersive.

In short:

Pros:
-LOTS of cars to choose from!
-Content heavy to keep you engaged!
-Massive condensed map of the U.S. 
-Race creator (recent updates)
-Interesting events
-Different types of careers (Street, Hypercar, Boat racing, Motocross, Stunt, Pro Racing, Airplane racing, etc.)

Neutral:
-Soundtrack; some bangers, other songs sound generic and forgettable.
-Customization is great but could be better if wed be given freedom to edit individual visual parts like in NFS HEAT.
-Graphics look like they are from later 2010's but its a sacrifice given the size of the map.

Cons:
-Engine noises sound like they were made for mobile apps.
-Physics: Cars handle like bricks, even with pro tuning some still handle heavy.
-Only up to 8 players in 1 lobby which is underwhelming given the size of the map.
-Only a party of 4. NFS HEAT can have up to 8 players in a party so why not in this game?
-PVP is not really there since I take more than 5 min to queue up and most of the time I get nothing.
- Cars are too pricey. It'd be best if the price were reduced by 50%.
-Upgrade system: don't really like the idea of collecting parts that are different colors with different stats as if it were some Fortnite weapon rarity. 
-Cringey voice acting. Just turn off the voices.

Overall: Solid racing game filled with tons of content to keep the player engaged and every update seems better than the last, especially with the upcoming MAD update. 8.5/10.

Its a decent racer motorfest is way better but is still in its early days. The Crew 1 is better in terms of story and world building the large map in this one is almost ignored with unlimited fast travel.

+ Game is as fun as the first game, but this game is even more fun.
+ Lots of vehicles even for only the base game (not only they got cars & motorbikes, they even have F1, hovercrafts, boats, planes, etc.).
+ You can manually tune your vehicles.
+ Lots of community liveries & mods.
- Basically no story. It's just you, other players and your machines (and your rivals I guess).
- Silent protagonist (probably for multiplayer stuff).
- BattlEye Service is making me to turn off something in my Windows Defender.

If you want fun gameplay, play The Crew 2. But if you want stories, play the first game instead.

I started playing pretty late, just got a newer PC. I really love the game, it's sooo cathartic to drive for actually 30 minutes across the country, and then get rewarded for it too. I've "leveled up" to Star with only like 3 races. Most of my progress is just from driving around the country. It's so relaxing to just take a nice car or bike and just go 70-90 miles, and the game is absolutely gorgeous. Highly realistic rain, beautiful bloom, fully decked out and functional car interiors and dashboards, gorgeous landscapes, etc. I much prefer to drive from the drivers seat camera, there's something so satisfying about it. And it works so well. And when it rains, the windshield wipers go. I just love the game so much. It's my goto when I have time constraints too, because I can just stop when I feel like it, there's no reason I have to play for any certain amount of time. It IS a bit of a time sink, but entirely by choice. It's incredibly satisfying. I also advise taking one of the long distance community street races, it's wonderful, and the prizes are nice for going the distance.

Made my PC explode.

Played for 5 hours straight, game is plenty fun. For context I had a 6600XT+3500X running maxed out settings at 1440p using RSR to upscale to a 4k TV. Should've bought a better PSU and mobo lol or lowered some settings. Hopefully my GPU survived.

EDIT: Replaced with better mobo and PSU. Ram also died so I replaced that. Everything is running fine now. Now that I'm sure my parts are good quality, I'm think it might just be this game is very clunky. It has a few, if minor bugs, like being unable to tab into and randomly crashing.

EDIT 2: After migrating from Windows to Linux this game no longer works due to BattleEye Anti-Cheat (which does support Linux). Ubisoft Connect works, but the game simply crashes. Official support forums were taken down and replaced with... Discord.

I go back in add the performance parts back and back out and the game crashes. Every time. Then when you load back in the performance parts are installed and you're good to go race. I have mentioned it in discussions to the developers and still no fix as of yet. In honesty though it seems all of the Ubisoft games are having problems right now. The main selling point of this game is the miniature USA world map. If you get the game you get it for that. It's fun and relaxing to just pick a spot and start driving aimlessly. Unforunately, it still feels empty because you can only have max 8 players in a session.

There are 598 vehicles in the game but it's a long grind to buy any. You get about 15-20k bucks for every race. But each car usually costs around 300-500k, so that's a lot of grinding, about 20-25 races to own another car. Only a handful of cars are under 100k. There's also their version of a Battle Pass called "MotorPass" which costs 3 million bucks.

There is multiplayer matchmaking but it takes a while to find a group, usually about 10-20 minutes. It's not obvious how to get to it as it's called "Live Battle" instead of multiplayer, and needs 4 players to start (8 max). Good luck trying to find a group on the 2nd rotating playlist as everyone is on the 1st fixed playlist for Street Race and HyperCars. Plus there's no music when you're waiting!

The Crew 2 is an exhilarating ride through an open-world racing paradise! The game's diverse range of vehicles, from cars and motorcycles to boats and planes, keeps the gameplay fresh and exciting. The sheer size of the game world is impressive, offering a vast and detailed virtual United States to explore. The ability to seamlessly switch between different vehicle types on the fly is a game-changer, adding a unique twist to races and challenges.

The graphics are solid, with a great attention to detail in the vehicles and environments. The game's variety of events and activities, including races, stunt challenges, and exploration tasks, ensures that there's always something to do. The multiplayer aspect is enjoyable, allowing you to team up with friends or compete against others in a wide range of events.

While The Crew 2 offers plenty of fun, it does have a few downsides. The story and characters are forgettable, and the AI can sometimes feel a bit predictable. Additionally, the in-game microtransactions might be a turn-off for some players.

Overall, if you're a fan of open-world racing games and don't mind a lackluster storyline, The Crew 2 offers an adrenaline-pumping experience with a vast playground of vehicles and challenges to conquer. It's a fun, fast-paced, and enjoyable ride.

As an avid racing game enthusiast, I've had the pleasure of exploring a wide range of titles, but nothing quite compares to The Crew 2. This open-world racing masterpiece has not only set a new bar for the genre but has also redefined what we should expect from racing games in the modern era.

Visual Spectacle (5/5):
The Crew 2 boasts a jaw-droppingly beautiful open-world rendition of the United States that's a visual feast for the eyes. From the sun-soaked streets of Miami to the serene landscapes of Yosemite, every inch of the map is meticulously designed, capturing the essence of these iconic locations. The game's attention to detail is second to none, making every turn, jump, and drift feel like a cinematic experience.

Unmatched Variety (5/5):
What sets The Crew 2 apart is its unparalleled variety. The game offers not just one type of racing, but a smorgasbord of disciplines, from street racing and off-roading to aerobatics and powerboating. Each discipline feels unique, with its own set of vehicles and challenges. Whether you're tearing through the streets in a high-speed hypercar or navigating treacherous mountain trails in an off-road monster, you'll find something to love here.

Seamless Transition (5/5):
The Crew 2's most impressive feature is its seamless transition between land, sea, and air. With a mere push of a button, you can switch between cars, boats, and planes, allowing for mind-bending and awe-inspiring moments. This mechanic adds a layer of strategy and creativity to the gameplay that I've never experienced before in a racing game.

Incredible Multiplayer (5/5):
The multiplayer experience is another area where The Crew 2 truly shines. Whether you're teaming up with friends for co-op challenges or competing against players from around the world in intense races, the seamless integration of multiplayer into the open world adds endless replayability.

Continuous Updates (5/5):
Ubisoft has proven their commitment to The Crew 2 with a steady stream of updates and expansions. New cars, boats, planes, and events are added regularly, keeping the community engaged and excited for what's next.

Minor Drawbacks (4.5/5):
While The Crew 2 is a nearly perfect racing game, there are a few minor issues worth mentioning. Occasionally, the AI can be a bit too aggressive, and some might find the grind for in-game currency a tad demanding. However, these are minor quibbles in the grand scheme of things.

In conclusion, The Crew 2 is nothing short of a racing masterpiece. Its stunning visuals, incredible variety, seamless transitions, outstanding multiplayer, and ongoing support from the developers make it a must-play for any racing game enthusiast. If you're looking for the ultimate open-world racing experience that will keep you hooked for hours on end, The Crew 2 is the game you've been waiting for. Strap in, rev up your engines, and get ready to embark on the ride of a lifetime. It's a game that deserves all the rewards on Steam and a place in the pantheon of gaming legends.

This game delivers an enjoyable and immersive experience for racing enthusiasts.
One of the standout features of The Crew 2 is its massive and beautifully crafted open-world environment. The game offers a scaled-down version of the entire United States, providing players with a remarkable sense of freedom and exploration. From the bustling streets of New York City to the serene beauty of the Grand Canyon, the world feels alive and dynamic, making it a joy to simply cruise around and take in the sights.
The vehicle selection in The Crew 2 is vast and varied, catering to a wide range of racing preferences. Whether you prefer high-speed supercars, agile street bikes, nimble off-road vehicles, or even aerobatic planes, this game has it all. The seamless ability to switch between different vehicle types on the fly is a unique feature that adds a layer of excitement and versatility to the gameplay.
In terms of gameplay mechanics, The Crew 2 strikes a good balance between realism and accessibility. The driving and flying controls are intuitive and responsive, allowing both novice and experienced players to enjoy the game. The different racing disciplines, including street racing, off-road rallies, powerboat racing, and aerobatics, provide a refreshing variety of challenges and keep the gameplay engaging.

The multiplayer aspect of The Crew 2 is a significant improvement over its predecessor. Players can seamlessly team up with friends or compete against other online players in various events and challenges. The online integration adds a layer of competitiveness and camaraderie that enhances the overall experience. However, there are occasional connectivity issues and matchmaking problems that can hinder the online experience.
The visuals in The Crew 2 are undeniably impressive. The attention to detail in recreating iconic landmarks and cities is commendable, and the lighting and weather effects add a layer of realism to the game world. The game also features a dynamic day-night cycle, enhancing the immersion further. However, there are occasional instances of texture pop-in and minor graphical glitches that slightly detract from the overall visual fidelity.
While The Crew 2 offers a vast open-world, it does suffer from a lack of meaningful content at times. The main storyline is forgettable, and the missions can feel repetitive. The game heavily relies on a leveling system and an extensive collection of activities, but it would have benefited from a more engaging narrative to drive the player's progression.
Overall, The Crew 2 is a highly enjoyable racing game that successfully builds upon its predecessor's strengths. Its expansive open-world, diverse vehicle selection, and immersive gameplay mechanics make it a solid choice for racing enthusiasts. Despite some minor flaws and a lackluster story, The Crew 2 offers an adrenaline-fueled experience that will keep players engaged for hours on end. Strap in, rev your engines, and prepare for an exciting ride

pretty good game especially if you're into open world games. i got a few stuff to say tho:

pros:
-large map for open world fans (supposedly takes 30 mins to go east to west)
-large vehicle variety
-also large gameplay variety with several race types and loads of other activities
-pretty fun races especially the rallycross ones
-Good and right amount of grind. not too grindy that it gets boring but not too easy that its like that one game that starts with the letter F
-a lot of customization for (only) street cars
-vinyl customization babeyyyy

cons:
-engine noises sound too similar sometimes
-car upgrades barely feel like anything. its probably for the grind and all but lesser upgrades that take more time to take but have more noticeable effects 
-body customization only limited to street cars, good luck if you wanted to make your pro racing car or rally car look better
-you only get like 8 guys per multiplayer server despite having an extremely large map. unless youre hanging with friends then multiplayer is basically useless and empty here

in conclusion, good game overall with a huge variety in things to do and vehicles to own. my main issues are multiplayer being too small for the map scale and the upgrades being too gradual to actually visibly change much but other than that, if you like driving, exploring, racing, and all that stuff, and you want to race not just cars but boats, planes, and motorbikes, then this game's for you.

To start off this is probably one of those games where you would need to close your door, put on a pair of headphones, sit down and dissolve yourself through the world of The Crew 2. It's not your average cup of joe racing game out there, it's much more than that, you discover as you drive around and if that's your thing then grab it !

To put it in short its not like nfs, driver, forza and I personally wouldn't top it up as the others cause like others it has its flaws as well. However, driving around the United States in your GT500 , while going through different seasons is something you don't experience in other racing games out there except for maybe two seasons. When I mean the map is huge, it's HUGE, like a trip from NY to LA would typically take you around 1- 1.30 hours and that entirely depends on the vehicle you have. If you're into huge maps and love cruising and discovering new landmarks, this game is for you. 

I have heard direct comparisons with the The Crew  and I can verify that the graphics in The Crew are way better than the second installment, but don't let that stop you from buying the game. The game still receives frequent updates, more vehicles (planes,boats), plus they've added additional landmarks all around the country so it's worth exploring them and comparatively more users are present in The Crew 2 than The Crew. This game might not be for you but you never know unless you try and if you love open-world games well this is totally for you !

Overall, it‚Äôs easy to pick small holes in The Crew 2, its races could be tighter, the virtual sun can be blinding, and there‚Äôs some pop-in that occasionally shows just how hard your PC is working. Its minor failures are, however, dwarfed by its huge successes; for the second game in a row, Ivory Tower has recreated the entire U.S. and this time added planes and boats into the mix too. It looks gorgeous, has a great soundtrack, heaps of customisation and a massive open world that‚Äôs full of stuff to do. More than anything though, it‚Äôs amazing to play a game where, in a couple of hours, you can race through the streets of New York, flip and spin on a monster truck course just outside L.A., loop and roll under the Golden Gate Bridge, and power past the Statue of Liberty in a powerboat. The Crew 2 may not always work perfectly, but when it does, it‚Äôs glorious.

I'm up to 96 hours and I think there's enough to talk about. 

Things I don't like:
* There's too much heavy/immovable junk to drive into for an open world driving game
* There's completely unnecessary traps scattered everywhere that you're forced to re-spawn out of once you fall into them, and if you dare try to off-road with a street vehicle...the game will re-spawn you NOT to the closest area before you got stuck, not even to the closest road. They will re-spawn you to the section of the last road you were actively driving on. This means, that if you're off-roading and you cross a road or drive on a road for a short amount of time and then go back off-road and get stuck...the game will dis-regard the close road you were just on and will still re-spawn you all the way across the map where you first turned off-road. 
* The cars will unpredictably come to a complete stop if you try to slide your car against a railing or wall. 
* Many of the races are dull yet frustrating, keeping you turning left, right, left, right etc. in a grid-pattern city for the majority of the race instead of having all the races at the same level of quality.  
* The guardrails on the sides of the roads are often unbreakable (even some wood ones). 
*In the menu the select button can bring up your car's part boosts....but be careful because that same button brings up the map if you accidentally press it twice. 
* The only thing that seems close to scale is the horribly limited room on the roads, you WILL crash into spawning traffic in this game because there is A LOT of spawning traffic.  

Things I like:
* Good selection of cars that all have interior views, a lot of the G.O.A.Ts are in here.
* Daily challenges aren't intrusive, they can be completed if you like but they're not annoying if you don't.
* Weekly challenges grant you plenty of extra cash and incentive to purchase new vehicles you haven't tried before. 
* After some tweaking in the settings, most players should be able to tune this game to be close enough to what they like to be able to start winning races whether you prefer simulation, arcade, or somewhere in between. 

Conclusion: There is some fun to be had if you're open minded, but there's too much that gets in the way of that fun that seems purposefully placed to stop you from playing/driving in this game. Not only could I not recommend this game, I would recommend that if the publisher wanted to sell a game that tries to stop you from playing...perhaps try making a puzzle game.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

I would probably use the "idk" option, if I didn't have to choose a thumb direction, for my niche interest of open world cruising, it does "ok enough", a lot of it is just a much bigger vehicle selection, and a lot of busywork you can run into along the way. So people like me will probably have like 15 hrs to enjoy potentially.
HOWEVER, I would easily recommend the crew 1, and TDU1 and 2 even more, simply because the exploration itself is much more straightforward and sensible in its progression bar. TDU1 and 2 had uncovering streets by driving on them, probably the most straight forward, but it requires more teleporting, the crew 1 had uncovering by grids, which didn't make you run the same intersections constantly, but some grids were off-road, when the vehicles and terrain just wasn't there for it. The Crew 2 has weird checkboxes, things like "enter location", drive at specific time of day with specific vehicle in specific spot, get X pickups. It's all very non-linear in its progression, feels inconsistent, unrewarding, and some are just terrible straight up.

Now for those who just want racing and vrooming, it is a TON of "content", but they all repeat tracks CONSTANTLY, you click a new race, and it's just reversed or different weather. Then those several repeating ones in one category, repeat in ANOTHER category. You don't have to go back to a race after getting first place, cause you surely are going to get more of it as seperate instance.
For those who want to race, the experience can be downright miserable, the UI is awful to navigate, starting an event always involves not only loading the race area, but also completely useless downtime in its "preparation spot", some have additional pointless drive to the starting area, then they have a cutscene sometimes (some are even f***n unskippable), and then you start riding.
Once you think all is good in the world, after each race ends, you have massive progress bar animation which you can only skip by slowly opening and closing leaderboards, then you have loot that you have to manually ride over (or they get sent to a mailbox with god damn space limit, and you have to travel to seperately), and THEN they have a loading screen for actual multiplayer consistent weather of the area you are at.
ALL OF IT, REPEATED, EVERY SINGLE TIME, FOR EVERY RACE, not the mention that the game can be grindy as all hell if you want to buy a lot of vehicles. If you see my 30,40 or whatever 10s of hours on the clock, the amount spent on mundane s**t is unreal and I hope the FOMO element designers are whipped for YEARS to come, cause it is clearly intentional, designed to waste your time while building up your SUNK COST FALLACY on all of the time you spent. Also a lot of the prompts are "hold interact" instead of a tap, micromanaging upgrades every time, endgame progression being "0.1% to a stat per level" and then additional upgrade loots per 10 levels.

Words cannot describe how horrible the design of the game is, so much actually good craft of it, wasted because of what it tries to incentivize. I like the driving, I like the selection of cars, I like the views, I like cockpit view for basically every vehicle I tried, I like some of the random "skill" events I could run into, I like some of the music, but all that is buried under an insurmountable pile of trash. Not to mention horrible things like forced story, quirky characters (that I had to mute few minutes in), stupid visuals for some of the GUI or these awful emotes.

Unless you are insane like me, where you are willing to spend 5$ just to scratch that frustrating itch for an open world cruising game, I cannot recommend this game to anyone. It is filled with live service nonsense, even more forced MMO elements, required always online (with logoff for afk instead of offline driving), sEaSOnAL "content", and basically no respect for your time.
This thing horrifyingly reminds me of something like Destiny 2, and you have to fight with the game to enjoy anything out of it. At least it seems to be nowhere as popular, given how massive the discounts are, but that might be just in preparations for the third Crew game.
Either way, if this game is supposed to be a trend for what to expect from Crew 3, then I have no hopes for it, besides picking it up 5 years later for 5$ to scrape out some enjoyment out of it. Triple A market is dead, and I can't wait till the live service nonsense gets buried in the mobile market exclusively.

The game runs better than forza horizon 5 hilariously because game devs don't know how to release decent products, this is one of those cases. After playing The Crew 1 you start to see how lack luster and bland this game is and how sad it's become, dominated by nothing but anti-socials sitting in menus or cheaters who use hacks to speed in street race vehicles extremely fast to ram and abuse other players as well as to cheat at summit live making getting summit live or motorpass vehicles impossible. Cars are way too overpriced for no real good reason and the cool cars are summitlive only and can't be bought with ingame money which is super stupid considering even a super skilled driver who has skills in many racing games with simulated and arcade handling can't get platnium on the stupid thing and never gets to get the car because of dumb hackers who are cheating and yet you can't even report them not even in freeroam when you catch them. The car's handling is absolute garbage even fully upgraded cars are either jello or jello and super understeer and feel like weightless toys that can fishtail suddenly for no reason on any corner even if you're doing multiple laps driving consistently. The AI have no respect for the player and will ram you akin to forza's garbage AI that disrespect racing rules of no contact and will hit your vehicle off, races are super easy to cut once you get enough nitro it's a game of who can figure out how to exploit track limits to get the best time ruining any type of racing fun. The grind even with over 500 icon points put into money is just annoying and dumb, hours in you'll struggle just to get a few decent cars and the same races are used for grinding that have no variation. Once you buy a OP car or earn one from the motorpass the AI even on the hardest difficulty become a joke and get absolutely dusted, offroad racing is a nightmare considering how poorly the vehicles handle and demolition derby ring fighting matches are broken and unfair with the AI even on super easy difficulty being extremely hard to beat since they literally fling themself off the arena after being slightly tapped by another AI or get caught on a wall then slammed into and destroyed.The offroad ghost when redoing offroad events you completed will leave you wondering why you're losing to the AI on easy difficulty non-stop and restarting non-stop till you realize after a while that it is your ghost and you don't have to beat it you just have to beat the AI's old time but don't have their ghost selectable so you can actually test vehicles and get an actual race.Vehicle modification is laughably bad alot of cars get nothing but rims and some don't even get that luxury; worked hard for a cool set of tires well too bad this car can't be customized. The traffic in hypercar races needs to be removed the traffic in general is cancer, they spawn in as fake box trucks 10 feet infront of you then despawn till they are 5 feet in your face then reappear too late as a ugly whatever traffic car and not a box truck hitting you and throwing you off the road for no reason. Traffic in racing games is cancer, you companies know players don't want it you're not a cruising game you're a racing game so get rid of it. Street racing is illegal and immoral stop promoting it with traffic and remove it and make it legal.Test drive durations need to be longer you barely get any time to push a hypercar to its limits and get to understand the vehicle, you need to make it to where all cars including motorpass and summitlive cars can be bought with ingame currency at a higher price than normal because you know you have cheaters and exploiters and they continue to harass the community and deny good skilled drivers cool cars just because you had to put a stupid PVP system that is entirely dumb and should be removed and cheaters and exploiters don't get punished or can be even reported. The interior dash of some cars is completely horrid even on high graphics, i've seen much better from forza horizon 1 and car mods from Garry's Mod it's 2023 fix your stuff there is no excuse for this live service sorry excuse for a game to not be updated and upgraded to such standards. Do not buy this game if you are looking for a social open world experience, just like forza horizon it is anti-social full of pause menu abusers and very dead plus it has a stupid player collision system so others can abuse it and ram because for some reason we don't get that no one wants that in freemode leave it to demo derby. The car tuning window is completely useless with really dumb + or - rather than explaining what the setting does leaving you to have to experiment to figure it out resulting in some cars never being good because no one can figure out how to tune them and even if you do the handling system is so horrid it doesnt really matter at all. Asides that absolutely love the ability to switch to different vehicles on the fly using the favorite system, the game is somewhat beautiful to a degree but it's all ruined by having nothing to do and the races being all the same. It is also ruined by never being able to compete in summitlive or getting on the icon leaderboard because it is dominated by cheaters and exploiters, i really think summit live needs to be removed along with the dumb motorpass and icon leaderboard you've let hackers and exploiters dominate your game and it's ridiculous all PVP is entirely ruined.

The original Crew game was pretty bad and my time with it was maybe 3 hours before I just returned it (I had it on console) - The Crew 2 takes the good ideas it had but delivers on them pretty damn well. There are so many different styles of racing in this game and each one has it's own 'feeling' that makes it stand out and all of them are at least somewhat okay once you get the hang of them. Something I really liked about the way they handled all of this is that the cars you get are all very good without you even needing to spend in-game currency on any unless you choose to and for a few event types (primarily the police chase ones), which means you can just have fun instead of needing to ever grind aside if you have a personal preference for a car you'd like and want to drive in.

While the main game of just doing all the styles of instanced races is fun, one of my favorite things in this are the 'stories' which are just long road trips from point-to-point all across America. You get rewarded with loads of fans from everything along the drive and ultimately a new vehicle by the end, but this is one of those rare times the bland and overused adage of "it's about the journey not the destination" is totally true. There's something just nice, fun, and relaxing about going on solo road trips around the country at 300mph.

I like it, it's not the best driving or racing game out there - but it makes up for it in having so much to do in so many different ways, such a big map, and other players interacting outside of events in short fleeting moments like impromptu police chases or motorcycle races.

Played beta and beta progress flows over into the game, got it on sale and not even 10 hours in i want to uninstall already.

Tried mostly everything in game that i am interested in (so basically anything that involves wheels on the ground)(the flying and driving on the water is atrocious IMO), and it kinda has the same problem forza horizon has where there is just no sense of progression.
The car you can buy are cheap enough to immediately just complete any normal event you can do and from every race you finish in the top 3 you get loot which immediately improves your car for that discipline and therefor immediately propels you forward even further making this game only challenging when you repeat events on higher difficulties.
Which is another point on contention because you cant choose higher difficulties for the events untill you completed the previous difficulty (really stupid decision to be honest).

There is an absolute metric fuckton of shit to do in this game also due to its almost battlepas like setup with daily quests and monthly goals and all that BS, but i personally have found none of it upto to this point any type of interesting beyond the cannonball like events because i like to just space out and drive while listening to music.
The stories are just single events with no NPCs beyond the police events which are glorified burnout (the game) events that are extremely trivial to anyone who enjoys racing games fairly regularly.
That or just a small piece of text about someones travels through america and you get to drive to some of the points of interest by yourself and have to find those points yourself which can get really annoying when the clouds show back up on the map when you zoom in...

Did some of the flying and boating events in the beta and never looked back, just atrocious as i mentioned above.

i'll give it some more hours, try and look for events with actual NPCs in them even though the small amount i have done the AI is also atrocious.

In short, if youre looking for a casual racing game that doesnt require you to setup your wheel and just go in and have some fun, this honestly aint it.
Youre better off getting the first the crew game, they someone managed to make the second one worse then the first in terms of a street racing game, hell you'd be better off just playing need for speed or even forza horizon even though i'd personally probably grab my wheel for forza.

Update:  The game was fun, but for some reason the Ubisoft launcher that was always a PIA now won't launch correctly, so I can't play this, or any other Ubisoft game.  I will never buy another one of these stupid games that requires you to use their version of Steam through Steam; either offer it on Steam or don't, but stop making Steam go through your launcher!

First and foremost with this game is expectations.  This is not by any means a racing simulator; it is more realistic than Star Wars racing, but only just.  It is an arcade race game, and a really good one at that!  Just don't be surprised when nothing is remotely realistic, except the graphics, which are great. As a private pilot who used to own an acrobatic rated plane, flying is by far the least realistic, which at first was frustrating, but eventually I learned to just accept it as a fun parody of flying.  Motorcycles are given no justice here; they actually turn worse than cars, which is totally backwards!  Of course in the real world cars cannot compete with motorcycles, so motorcycles had to be "dumbed down" to make them equal in the game.  Hovercraft seem to be the most realistic, interestingly, but all of classes of vehicle are totally unrealistic.  So, if you are looking for hyper realistic physics and realistic controls, this is not the game for you; however, this game is fun and easy to get straight into racing with little to no set up or "training".

The good:  Lots of fun, lots of variety of racing, and an open world, semi based on the USA.  I love all the real world cars, planes, and boats; even if none of them are realistic performance wise at all.

The bad:  the events are not well balanced.  The street racing discipline takes up like 1/4 of the game!  Or, so it feels.  By the time you finish all Street Races on easy, you have multiple fully upgraded cars in that class.  Then, you have multiple classes where you have to repeat levels over and over on easy, just to make bare minimum performance recommendations.  Not a deal breaker, just a little odd.  It would flow better if there were more of the other events, as they tend to be a bit more "grindy".

The biggest bad is the multi player system.  Having random players get in the way while you are doing the same event can be really annoying.  Especially in the weekly Live Summit events; where I have literally had to endure someone parking a monster truck between the edges of a checkpoint, so no one could do well in that challenge.   That was VERY annoying!  Another common problem is other random people also doing the same timed event who are slower than you; now you either wait for a clear chance, or just do your best getting around them in the middle of a scored event.  Ability to race real people, good; real people getting in the way of your single player skill challenges, bad.

Next, the Ubisoft launcher sucks and it can be a major PIA just to get the game to actually start most of the time.  Some times it just flat out refuses to let you on and play, even if you only want to play solo.  Just expect that it will usually take 5 - 15min to actually get the game running, and sometimes it won't let you play for a while.

The world:  The game marketing makes a huge deal of having the entire USA open world to drive, fly, and boat around.  Well, that isn't accurate at all.  From coast to coast is like 50miles and can be driven in about 20 minutes.  It is more a bunch of parts of the country cookie cuttered out and put in roughly the correct places, just with a whole lot less real estate between "cookies".  It's kind of cool that you can drive from Seattle to New York, and you will pass through several familiar places, or many other places.  The cities that it includes are pretty good representations; however, what cities and places they decided to include and not include is very random and odd.  I get the feeling the developers are based on the East Coast, as they have the California central valley a lush forest.  Anyone who has ever been anywhere in the California central  valley knows it is a brown "grass" grassland on the verge of being desert!  It's also funny they didn't include any differential weather, so yes it snows in Miami!  Over all the playing world is a little funky, but great.

Realistic: not a bit.  Fun: absolutely.
