Decent open world racer with some colossally bad game design decisions that ruin entire game:
* Mandatory boat, plane, hovercraft and monster truck content to complete everything. Why are they even in the game? None of them are fun and they all control horrendously.
* Impossible to create multiple characters or reset progress. Prevents 100% completion due to bugs in progress. If you are completionist - you have been warned. 
* Regular server down times, and the game is online only. 
* AI is riddled with hack'arounds and does not feel like it's actually simulated. It is rubber banding in some situations and is completely useless in others. Bosses rubber band and cheat like crazy. Same when AI is closer to your car's performance level. Once you increase your car's performance index, AI disappears, sometimes several minutes behind.
* Physics engine is quite bad. Might something to do with the fact that they have to have planes, boats, monster trucks, hovercrafts and bikes, and all of them are absolutely terrible to drive. 

Few good things:
* Tons of content
* Can buy premium season content with in-game money
* Good car selection and customization
* Variety in environments. All places on the map do not feel the same. 

If they wanted to compete with Forza Horizon, this is not how you do it. It looses to FH in almost every aspect. If feels like weird off-brand FH copy that somehow got every part perfectly wrong. 
There are better options out there.

Playing the Crew 2 I'm really conflicted on it.
on the positives, 
-there's a lot of cool vehicles in the game and a few strange choices. which I always appreciate. even the legendary Gee-Bee.
-Lot of variety. Drifting, offroad, air races, etc. hard to get tired of the variety
-The map is huge. Yeah it's a very strange version of the US but it's sheer size is incredible. 

my negatives
-Controls REALLY suck, you have to level up to unlock the ability to tune cars more in-depth. without turning off assists and such they just understeer heavily. E-brake really doesn't let you slide and without tuning some cars are absolute slogs to drive. other vehicles like the hovercraft and even off road vehicles feel fine. planes are okay. 
-Lack of speed. 240mph does not feel like any speed. 
-Battlepass, bundle content, premium coins, etc are constantly there. 
-Game can be ridiculously easy when doing an event for the first time due to upgrades or just the first go through at the lowest difficulty can be a cakewalk
-Lack of any real narrative, it just feels like cut scenes happen, people talk with no rhyme or reason. and man I hate all these people. everyone minus a few are these "yeah bro lets go WIN and do the sick jump!" dudebro or dude lady. the only character that feels any different is clarance and he feels like an AI speech bot talking to me. And the writing is atrocious at times. "you can win races but you'll never win the race" is a real line in this game. It's just. ugh I hate this style of writing in horizon and I hate these type of characters. I hate racing games trying to have a crappy story and characters. I'd rather no one talk to me then whatever dialouge happens here.
-Air racing isn't air racing. It's just time trials. no actual opponents. this kinda sucks. I still enjoy it but it's Air RACING not air trials. 
-no real evolution or actual "career" just grind credit to buy cars or randomly get them. it doesn't feel like I'm being a famous "pilot" there's really no cutscenes or anything that forms a world or anything. Grid 1 had your race shop grow and become more professional. this game has your house get nicer and that's really the only indication your getting more famous.

I could probably nit pick more complaints. wish I could rate this mid but I'll give it a positive review. it goes on sale very often for a couple of bucks and I got hours out of it. Season pass is not worth full price. probably on sale though. you can have some fun with it and it's nice to just drive or fly. Just wish the handling was better and the game didn't have annoying characters that make me wish I was wolfgang von trips at the monza grand prix in 1961

This game contains Internal combustion powered vehicular devices which can under ideal circumstances move from one point to another at speeds which may or may not be considered unsafe for human life, depending on who you ask. Much of these actions are happening in or around heavily populated streets filled with random pedestrians, all of which can at any moment feel the unrelenting force of a object several tons heavy moving at speeds of 300 kilometers per hour and upwards, which would likely ruin their mood. It is unknown how the individuals owning these cars have gained the permission to do these unsafe acts, but they will surely anger the local authorities.

If I had to sum up this game in one word, that word would be "inconsistent". The core racing experience is fun, and the open-world is still a thrill to just fly, race and drift around. However, there are definitely some irks that hold it back.

The Crew 2 was designed to be far more ambitious in it's storytelling. The cutscenes and dialogue you get occasionally before or after a race feel really disjointed, as if there's a big chunk of the story you missed somewhere.

Also, what's the point of having a house or garage in this game if you can't even do nothing with it yet? Can't customize it, can't have people over, can't do jack squatty. Seems like some lazy backwards logic by the devs if you ask me.
In this game it's just the same thing over and over again, race after race against the AI with no variation in gameplay other than the fact you have planes and boats now. One big long grind to get better parts for your vehicles.

This game is max quantity, zero quality. If you told me this game was designed by people who had never actually driven or sat in a car and everything they knew about driving was through bing searches and 80's action movies, it would all make sense. Then they added rpg elements with based loot. This is a parody of a driving game through the lens of the onion.

And the worst part: Why on earth you lost the license for Subaru? Literally the only brand that would make me still play this game.

This review would probably be a lot more favorable if I got this game when it came out 5 years ago, but it really shows its age now.
 
As an Arcade racer it's fine, but the upgrade system is atrocious. "Loot" for Upgrades is probably the worst thing I've ever seen in a racing game. 

Graphics are only okay when in an actual race. the Cinematics are pre-rendered and looks horrific at anything higher than 720P resolution. Driving in the open world isn't great, even with max settings and motion Blur off, it feels like I'm in a much older game, I had to stop driving in the over world due to it making me a bit nauseous with how bad the Loading Distance, weird tearing, overall low fidelity.  

The AI's you race against are pretty sad as well, I can consistently go into races that I'm supposedly under powered for according to the "perf" stat. But the AI is so bad, that I can easily beat them in most races, which results in a overall boring race experience. 

I do love the Hot Pursuit mode, those little races are far better than the entire Citroen remake that ruined NFS: Hot Pursuit for me.

Overall, it feels like this was a racing game first, then Horizon did really well so they shoe-horned as much content in as possible to compete with it. I do think it was ambitious but a lot of the aspects just don't feel great. Everything feels like it's driving on rails... doesn't matter if you're in a hyper car, off road truck, the badly named "watercraft mk 1", or one of the racing planes... they all have the same feel. If the game is on sale for $10 for the Gold Edition, I'd say it's worth it. Otherwise, wait for it to go on sale.

The Crew 2 is an absolute gem of a racing game that takes the open-world genre to new heights. With its stunning visuals, diverse range of vehicles, and seamless exploration of a sprawling open world, it delivers an exhilarating experience that is bound to leave players breathless.

From the moment you dive into the game, you are greeted with an incredibly vast and detailed world to explore. The recreation of iconic American locations, such as New York City, Miami, and Los Angeles, is nothing short of impressive. The attention to detail is impeccable, and the seamless transitions between cities, countryside, and waterways make it feel like a living, breathing world.

One of the standout features of The Crew 2 is its incredible selection of vehicles. Whether you're a fan of cars, bikes, boats, or even airplanes, this game has something for everyone. The roster is extensive, featuring a wide range of licensed vehicles from various manufacturers. Each vehicle feels unique and handles differently, adding depth and variety to the gameplay.

The driving and handling mechanics in The Crew 2 are smooth and responsive, allowing for precise control over your chosen vehicle. Whether you're tearing through city streets, drifting around tight corners, or soaring through the sky, the game provides a satisfying and realistic experience that keeps you on the edge of your seat.

The Crew 2 truly shines with its seamless integration of multiple racing disciplines. The ability to switch between cars, bikes, boats, and planes on the fly is a game-changer, providing endless possibilities for exploration and competition. Whether you're participating in street races, off-road rallies, powerboat championships, or even aerobatic challenges, the game constantly keeps you engaged and entertained.

The multiplayer aspect of The Crew 2 is also worth mentioning. The game seamlessly blends single-player and multiplayer experiences, allowing you to team up with friends or compete against other players in exciting online races. The multiplayer mode adds an extra layer of excitement and competitiveness, making every race a thrilling event.

Visually, The Crew 2 is a feast for the eyes. The attention to detail in the environments, the stunning lighting effects, and the high level of graphical fidelity contribute to an immersive and visually stunning experience. Whether you're racing through a thunderstorm, admiring the sunrise over a coastal highway, or performing stunts in the air, the game's visuals never fail to impress.

In terms of content, The Crew 2 offers a plethora of activities to keep you engaged for hours on end. The extensive campaign mode, side missions, skill challenges, and multiplayer events ensure that there's always something to do and new goals to achieve. The game offers excellent replay value, and the constant stream of updates and additional content keeps the experience fresh and exciting.

In conclusion, The Crew 2 is a remarkable racing game that sets a new standard for open-world racing experiences. Its breathtaking visuals, vast open world, diverse vehicle roster, and seamless integration of multiple racing disciplines make it an absolute joy to play. Whether you're a racing enthusiast or simply looking for a thrilling and immersive gaming experience, The Crew 2 is a must-play title that will leave you wanting more.

CONS
- The overall physics and effects make it look like "Mobile Game - Asphalt 9"

PROS
- extremely huge open world giving tons and tons of different types of races and stuff.
- very cheap price (90% off) and so much to explore 
- you can drive boats, planes, bikes and cars


Verdict - Game is nice and comes on superb sale but it's too much grind and game feels like poor budget from ubisoft. If you don't have NFS or Forza, then Crew is good title.

Open-world racing game that offers a vast and diverse virtual playground for players to explore. With a wide range of vehicles, including cars, boats, planes, and motorcycles, the game provides an exhilarating and immersive racing experience. The game's stunning graphics and detailed environments make for visually impressive gameplay. However, despite its impressive scale, the game falls short in terms of its story and lacks depth in its gameplay mechanics. Overall, the game offers an enjoyable racing experience with its vast open world and variety of vehicles, but it may not fully satisfy those seeking a deep and engaging gameplay experience.

I've played a lot of bad games in my life, and most of the time I go "Yeah, it's on me for buying it". But holy shit does this take the cake. How is it possible to take a simple concept as a racing game and make everything wrong about it. The handling? Is shit. The physics? Is shit. The gameplay? is shit. The sound design? Is shit. The storyline, characters, atmosphere, and literally the entire game? Is shit.

Nah, don't buy this game even on sale. Because you don't actually buy a game, you own an access to the game. What do you mean? Oh I don't know, maybe because your save file is tied to the in-game servers and you have no way of restarting your progress unless you buy a new copy? But why does it matter? Oh I don't know, maybe because if servers gets shut down you will be left with a skeleton copy of a game that you cannot play? Does that make an owner of the game copy or owner of the game access? Because that just sounds to me like a free to play game with added fee to it.

Graphics are utter garbage. And it's a nice way of putting it. Draw distance is way too close and you can't make out what is happening in front of you. IN FRONT OF YOU IN A RACING GAME. (Ultra settings btw). The lighting system doesn't work. So your headlights do not light up the road in front of you... IN A RACING GAME WHERE YOU NEED TO SEE THE ROAD.

The physics and controls are arcade style. So I let that pass. But if you come from NFS, Forza or Dirt background... Well it will feel like none of those games would feel close. It has it's own sluggishness attached to it. There's also lootboxes for car upgrades. Why? What's wrong with tier upgrade system to put every car on par and balance each car to be equal? Actually don't say it - Microtransactions.

Oh and story? Yeah it has nothing to do with The Crew 1. You are basically playing as an obnoxious streamer. I guess it was hip to make games about streamers back in 2018.

And even the sound mixing is garbage. How do you screw up something as basic as hearing the sounds? Was this mixed by a deaf person? The engine sound is too quiet, the FX and Voice Acting is too loud. And if you increase volume, the menu sounds bangs your eardrums. It's all over the place.

But, I will be nice to the game and give credit where it's due. I like soundtrack. That's it.

So if you read this review, think for a moment, do you really want to buy a game that one day the servers will shut down which lock you out of playing a subpar game? A game with 0 replayability because your savefile is tied to your account with no options of resetting the progress? Yeah, I thought so too.

I went to this game without an open mind, I dislike ubisoft, and the way they abandoned the crew 1 did not bring my hopes up. I wouldn't have bought this game but horizon 5 and its drip fed content ended my patience for that franchise so while waiting and hoping for solar crown to not shit the bed I found this on sale, and I have to say, it won me over.

The races are fun, the variety is cool, the airplanes and boats are gimmicks, yes, but they play okay (no stall manouvers on aerobatics do annoy me tho), it's an activity to do if you need a break, there are bikes, touring cars, rally cars, trucks, monster trucks, bikes, offroad bikes, open wheel racers..
The environment is quite a joy to explore, there is quite a bit of content and I haven't even unlocked the summit yet.

My only complaint is the progression, the crew 1 was a slow burn, it felt rewarding having to take a road trip and drive for some time to get to a new city, then doing the events there, then hitting the road again..slowly giving you the cars and upgrades, some races were very long, crossing multiple states and I miss that, here, fast travel to any event without cost is available from the game start and the progression feels a little too effortless and meaningless to be rewarding for me, it's one of those loot mmo progression systems that does not fit the racing genre well but devs insist on it for some reason, grinding a 4 minute race to fit a legendary "motorcore" (which sounds like a heavy metal genre) loot part, then rerolling it's attributes, I wish they kept to the first game's progression but made it a little bit faster instead.

But honestly, with horizon 5 and the state it's in, I'll stick to the crew 2, it's simply a better open world racing experience, with NFS completely botching a mild success with unboud and forza becoming more and more greedy, careless and putting zero effort in the franchise, I don't see that changing, the crew 2 will be the better open world racing experience out there for a while, not because it's simply that great of a game, it's not, but with competition like that, might as well be.
I only see that changing if solar crown comes out swinging, nothing to do but wait.

Okay. I haven't played a lot, but I can tell you that this game is a bit of a let down. 

First of all, the UI is a jumbled mess. I mean, navigating through cars to buy or to get into is tedious, between races or when you are at a staging area, you slowly stumble along on foot to choose either races, cars or to escape the drudging dull monotony of this mode to freemode in a car. 

It is such a mess that in first play through it took me about 10 mins to figure out how to quit the game. There is two ways I found where you can exit the game. I'll tell you so you'll be able to get outta there without raging and go kill the process in the task manager. The quit options are actually hidden and there's no indication where it is in the game. I've found out that if you are in a race or activity in a car, you must press and hold the Y button on the controller to be able to quit the game. If you are in free mode, either in car or on foot, the exit option is hidden on the far right of the settings menu. You actually have to scroll the menu sideways to the right to be able to see it. Pressing start and having a simple pause menu where you can load, save and quit (Like the majority of games out there) would be far too logical. No! You're stuck here bro until you figure this out. 

Also, don't ever and I mean EVER follow the GPS arrows on the screen that tells you where to go. It tries to take you everywhere and anywhere but on the road (I was in an off road vehicle). That in itself wouldn't be all that bad, off roading through the world could be fun, but the thing is taking you through places where it is IMPOSSIBLE to get out of. Usually you would just have to use the really helpful ''Reset Car'' option (You have to press and hold both Shoulder Buttons) but it just reset your car 5 feet behind IN THE SAME HOLE YOU CAN'T GET OUT OF. I was in the grand canyon, so it might be less of a problem elsewhere, but then again, I don't want to find out. My last play through I got stuck again so I just quit the game, with the really helpful Y button menu. 

All that being said, the driving simulation is competent. The activities sound compelling. And the story missions entertaining. 

As for performance and visuals, there are better options out there (Like Forza Horizon 5). I run the game at 4K resolution HIGH settings on a AMD Ryzen 9 5900x 12 cores 24 threads with 32gigs of high speed DDR5 memory with a RTX 3070Ti and FH5 runs way smoother and looks better at 4K resolution. 

Now I've bought the game on sale at 90% discount. So I got the full deluxe edition for 12$ so the disappointment doesn't hurt as much as if I had paid the full 120$ full price for this. Even at that price, if you crave for a GREAT racing game, throw 10$ on a XBOX game pass and play Horizon 5.

[h1]6/10[/h1]

I played the original game on Xbox back in the day. I was looking for much the same thing when I picked up The Crew 2 on sale and it mostly delivered.

Coming into the game 5 years after release, I was completely overwhelmed by the amount of content that was available to me. The lacklustre tutorial left me confused, not knowing what events to do, or which ones were the main campaign and which were added content. However, once I had figured things out, I loved the vast amount of content.

The driving physics leave a lot to be desired. The Crew 2 is clearly an arcade racer, however this is no excuse for physics which are undoubtedly worse than 15 year old Forza games. The lack of realistic physics makes driving skill less important, instead placing more importance on the perf level of your car.

The difficulty of races is solely determined by the recommended perf level that your car should have. This makes the difficulty rather binary: if your car meets the perf level, the races are easy; if it doesn't, they are hard. This, coupled with the physics, makes progression in the game less of an investment of skill, and more of an investment of time. The weak story reduces the motivation to progress.

The cars are expensive, requiring a significant grind to afford them. With 16 different disciplines (vehicle types), the game is very varied, making the grind interesting, and giving the player lots of vehicles to buy. With the variation of the map, it becomes easy to spend hour doing events that all feel very different from each other.

Roaming around and completing events with friends is really fun. Showing off the vehicle you've been grinding for is rewarding. I believe the game becomes better when playing with other people. The GTAO-style open world roaming allows you to meet new people - who you can add to your crew to play events together,

I was extremely surprised to discover that this 5 year old game is still updated to this day. The weekly Summit adds competitive challenges with good rewards. The Motorpass adds more things to grind for, and the Motorflix events adds more content to the game. Just recently, a race creator was added: I am impressed by this so far but we will see how it develops. With the upcoming release of The Crew Motorfest, the updates are likely to slow, or even stop, which is slightly disappointing.

Some features of The Crew that I was looking for in The Crew 2 that were not present are:
- Linear progression system
- Using one car across multiple specs

Despite all of the negatives, The Crew 2 is an extremely enjoyable game, that makes me keep coming back for more with its varied content. I would definitely recommend picking this up on sale: paying full price is not worth it.

I should have tried the demo first because I kept running into things I didn't like about this game. 

- Driving feels bad. 
- Physics feel very simple, the controls are sluggish, and the camera is terrible. 
- Vehicles handle very differently in game compared to the trailers and screenshots on the store page. 4 wheeled vehicles in particular feel like balloons hovering over the ground with locked rotational axes. 
- Vehicles felt very much the same within types, among the ones I tried.
- Gameplay definitely feels like it was not a priority.
- NPCs often annoy you while driving. 
- Cringe ego pandering. Anything you do seems to warrant brown nosing from NPCs and gain hundreds of followers on fake social media.

The Crew 2 delivers an adrenaline-pumping racing experience with its vast open-world, diverse racing disciplines, and seamless vehicle switching mechanics. With its visually stunning environments and thrilling multiplayer races, it's a game that keeps the excitement revved up. Despite a few technical hiccups, The Crew 2 offers a fantastic blend of exploration, competition, and pure racing joy that will keep you coming back for more thrilling adventures on the road, in the air, and on the water.

EDIT: It's been 3 years since my original review, and as a returning player, I am so glad to have this game. I recently bought a new top tier PC and unlocked the graphics' full potential. For the record, I returned before getting my new rig. BUT!!! The MOST important thing about this game is that the developers KEEP IT COMING!!!! SO MUCH (BEYOND FATHOMABLE) NEW CONTENT THAT WAS INTRODUCED THROUGHOUT THE YEARS- EVEN AFTER A NEW CREW GAME WAS ANNOUNCED. and GOOD and FUN content too! Very diverse, much adrenaline fun.

**Even kind of a "story" was added to the game, like a flash of what would be a plot- Not much but it DOES add some soul to the game. Always room to improve.

ORIGINAL: Bottom line is, this is a good racing game, stands out well in the crowd comparing today's selection of racing games. plenty of things to do, fun to drive. i guess at some point after doing all the initial content the game had to offer before all the updates that came along the way, i lost interest (but only eventually! but still had plenty of fun in this game.)

if i have a friend who usually dislikes racing games who enjoyed this i can tell you it's fun. they keep making content, so i'd say, it's a good thing. so i give it a thumbs up, even though i barely play anymore tbh. i sometimes come back for a couple and then quit. but the game i always come back to is midnight club 2. sometimes even underground. so you can see why people with my kind of taste for racing games would like this.

P.S. at +400km/h you feel the speed, MAN that feels good in this game!!

Pro's - Incredible grip driving
- Decent sense of speed
- Player sync seems okay (other than bikes)

Con's - Game doesn't know what it is
- Drift mode is trash
- Drag mode is trash
- Touring mode is now trash with recent physics changes
- Planes are trash with trash controls
- Boat control is trash and slow
- Parts system is trash and annoying
- Traffic is trash and annoying
- Animals are trash and annoying
- Lot's of ruined first person views (poor gauge placement)
- Motorcycle player sync is trash (as soon as you wheelie other players see you upside down)
- Races are too short for an entire map of the USA (should be more coast to coast 1 hour races)

Conclusion:
Game had massive potential, but unfortunately falls short trying to do everything instead of doing 1-2 things well.

I still have not reached the true endgame yet.

Update (07.04.2021) - Slightly closer to endgame now.

Update (22.02.2022) - Finally reached Icon 9999 at 3060 hours played. Full review below.

While my interest in the game has deteriorated over the years as the more you progress, the less there is to do, I still find personal objectives for myself to progress towards - hunt certain performance part sets or get certain statistic to higher milestone or improve my times on leaderboards - there is a lot to do in The Crew 2. Doesn't matter if you are just starting out or you have played for 50 hours already.

Negatives:

- The game is very grindy and there is barely any story at all
- There is a lot of time-gated (timed exclusives) content
- Quality of Life is completely out of balance (some vehicle categories are well balanced while others have 3 vehicles that dominate out of a group of 30)
- there are boosted sets that dominate leaderboards with only a limited number of players having access to them
- lack of crossplay
- unoptimized game performance can make the game crash even on more powerful systems.
- As the game is always online and mostly on the server side, there is no modding community for it and players have to put faith into devs and Ubisoft, who, honestly speaking, have been milking players for over a year now.

However, there are great parts to The Crew 2 that make the game better for me than other rivals:

- Game offers a vast open world, biggest in a current-gen racing game (though it was released during PS4/XB1 era, the game is a bit too big for those consoles and players suffer from poor performance and lengthy loading times).
- A wide variety of different types of vehicles to play with, learn and master (and collect), not just limiting to cars, but also bikes, boats, planes and hovercraft.
- An enormous amount of different activities, with new types having been added over the years.
- Excellent arcade-ish handling model, works amazing with a controller, but keyboard is great as well. Funnily enough, the actual meta is wheel... in an arcade game.
- Working PVP system, albeit its a bit too simplistic, offers no customization and suffers from bad rewards (PvE is better way to grind for rewards), yet people continue to play it and populate lobbies.
- High level of visual modification for most car/bike vehicle classes. As is standard these days, player populated vehicle livery system is present, where players can use in-game livery editor to make designs for all vehicle types.
- You can drift in this game. It has an entire category focused on drifting.
- Demolition Derby with destructible cars is also a thing.
- The Crew is a GaaS (Game-as-a-Service), which means that it is being continuously updated. Fortunately, all the new cars (non time-gated ones) and events and QoL updates have been completely for free. After buying the game, the only things that require premium currency are vanity items (nitrous, tyres, underglows, rooftops, horns, window tints etc) and there being very few opportunities in the game to receive premium currency, forcing players to put more money into the game.
EDIT as of late 2022 - Motorpass can now be purchased with in-game bucks, premium currency spending is no longer required.
- Leaderboards for every type of activity keep the grinding process engaging, as you can keep on improving yourself on leaderboards, while getting followers (XP), money and other resources.
- Hobbies (accolade system) makes you constantly feel like progressing in the game, no matter what the activity is. More frequently early on, less frequently later in the game.
- Having an insanely high account level cap (Icon 9999, took me over 3000 hours to reach it) means that you are constantly gaining XP and levelling up. You can use these levels to improve various passive stats (Nitro is more powerful, earn more bucks per race etc).
- There are a lot of other great things in the game, the list would be too long.
- EDIT July 2023 - Track Creator has been added to the game, removing it from negatives listing and adding it to positives. Feature looks to be very robust and offers a lot of creative applications for the players on the biggest map in a current-gen racing game.

There are also a few grey areas to mention that I cannot really put into good or bad:

- While the game does not have an implementation of cops, there are game modes where you use "pursuit" vehicles to destroy destructible AI vehicles. It kind of works out like the "Road Rage" mode in Burnout Paradise. You can play this game mode with friends and smash AI in co-op fashion.
- The Crew 2 has an in-game video editor. I have not really seen a lot of player implementations of it and honestly, most people do not even know it exists. 
- PC version has a chat system, which seems to be mostly utilized in PVP. It was used more in The Crew 1 and in the early days of The Crew 2, but in later years, most new players do not know it exists. People use the emote system instead.

I think that is my review. While this is my most played game on Steam and most streamed game on Twitch, it is not the best game I have ever played. It has its flaws and lack of exciting new content and progressive Quality of Life implementation has left a sour taste in the mouth for most veteran players. We hope the publishers still see potential for this game and allow developers to move the game onto a better path, which it deserves. It was great once, it can be great again.

My score for an experience of playing The Crew 2 over 3.5 years = 8.5/10.

The Crew 2 is an open world arcade racing game with the map being the literal entire USA, downscaled to videogame size obviously. Also, i'm hyped for Motorfest even though i'll have to wait another year because Ubisoft, once again, decided to go to Epic Games. They already did come back crawling because Epic didn't work as good as they thought and yet here we are looking at them doing the exact same mistake again missing out on tons of sales because of the selling platform ONLY. Anyways.

I have done every single peace of Content this game has to offer, from races to photo ops but "skills" too and i can tell you i hated almost everything about this game; special hate goes out to every single Boat and Plane activity. I loved playing it, i mean it made me play for 200h+ but i will not ignore how bad of a videogame it actually is

People complain about the Crew 2 but i think its for the wrong reasons; most of the critism is about the grindy aspect of this game and yes they are right it indeed is one of the grindiest racing games ever but to be absolutely honest.. i bought a racing game to win races, if the grind is based on racing then why would i complain? anyways, theres seemingly endless content to be played, most of it feels either the same or really really alike but i really appreciate the cheer amount of content Ivory Tower came up with, set peaces and special events really look and feel cool to go through but it is obvious that most of it were simple instagram filters being put onto your screen to make it feel different even if it mostly isn't.

Graphics are OKAY, it does look outdated compared to even older titles and the antialasing is basically non existent, the backmirrors do not work and your headlights are literally looking like transparent yellow JPGs to make it look like there was light but it actually is no light source at all inside the game engine, the steering wheel barely moves at higher speeds. It definetily has its moments though, it can look pretty and sometimes i had more NFS Underground Vibes than the past 5 Need for Speeds were able to get me but the fact the night time got literally massacred in order to cover up non functioning headlights really bothers me

Heres what i think is important to know before getting into it
Anything you do, wether it be menu navigation or real time gameplay, it feels like a mobile game with PC features. Theres so many decisions made in design which simply go all against the user experience to make it as annyoing and uncomfortable as possible and i will have to give you a couple examples to make some sense of what i actually mean: 

Every time you finish a race theres an unskippable animation playing telling you that you won, how much XP you got and how much money you earned, it takes almost 10 seconds every single time, right after that you'll see some funny colorfull packages spawning in front of your car so you collect them, these are literally random generated tuning parts which also have (feelingly) hundreds of additional passive effects besides pushing the cars perfomance. Once your inventory is full and you tuned up your car, you gotta dismantle the stuff you don't need and that.. takes way too much time. I could guess that 1/3 of my playtime was dismantling tuning parts only.
This entire process is what you get for playing the game. The Tuning is based on RPG NUMBERS and STATS, its no new super duper new engine you build into your car, its literally the same thing now being purple instead of blue (rarity=quality) and the number goes up from 245 to 247. 
Other than that the Visual Freedom of your car is astonishingly huge, less for the GT and Hyper Classes but more than ever in street race cars, generally the car selection is almost as impressive as Forzas is.

The AI in your races also base their difficulty on those RPG like "Perfomance Numbers", meaning your car has to have a "220-Stat" to be able to compete in that specific race; this system leads to the AI being either entirely broken or not existent at all. One side of the game makes you want to own as many cars and have as much variety as possible, on the other side theres really obvious differences in cars in same classes. Almost every Muscle Car feels underpowered as hell while other "meta-cars" will have no problems whatsoever; Some cars really do struggle a ton to keep up with the AI, others will make you simply drive the course to the finish line making it a personal time trial.

But wait! theres more! The Crew 2 has an RPG like Skill Tree. It enhanced passive things like "slipstream power", range, effectiveness, it enhanced your nitrous in 7 different ways and makes competing against other lower level people a joke; actually the PVP section of this game is dead since release because of the slipstream mechanic which is absolute BS, you can literally hear your car gaining +100HP as you drive behind your mate. This is a racing game, no MMORPG and most certainly no MOBA, i genuinenly do not understand how one could implement such things into a racing game, making a skill set almost obsolete (of course you still have to know how to drive lol)

Also, there is an ingame real-money shop for you to buy cosmetics, car bundles and battle pass though you can buy the battle pass with ingame money you get from playing

On the plus side though, i really like how easy accessable the multiplayer is. You invite your friend to the party, you choose a race and there you go, no overcomplicated crap needed for this.

Ubisoft support doesn't exist.

UPDATE: Last week an item disappeared from my summit rewards, I was careful not to lose any unmarked boosted loot and checked every piece one by one, and yet an item has disappeared. It seems entirely evident that Ubisoft support is not run by humans. The responses are either just scanned by a bot and replied with keyword based responses, or they are the most idiotic and/or broken English users to ever grace this planet. It takes weeks to months to get a broken reply, good luck if you have an actual problem which you're likely to run into with this garbage company.

I can only imagine The Crew: Motorfest being plastered with reused assets including the user interface (which appeared in the BETA.) The UI is absolute garbage in TC2, so why would they reuse it in Motorfest? Gosh, it's absolutely appalling how poorly this company runs its own franchises into the ground.

PvP is unbalanced dog shit: We have the issue in PvP of people using manual driving to go faster so automatic drivers literally can't maintain the same or similar speed unless slip streaming. The gears often don't even work properly unless you use non-sequential gearbox, with some cars not switching quickly enough, partly because of this problem people use third party programs to get gears to work on a joystick because Ubisoft couldn't be bothered to implement it themselves. PvP is just following the manual driver's slipstream, and if you make one mistake you are almost guaranteed to lose the race. It's not just their steering that's winning the race, it's the gear changing increase in speed. The auto gearbox lags extremely badly, you can be stuck on a gear for seconds before it changes, losing so much potential power output. Also, if you are further from the server people are able to slip stream off you end race and still win, even if they are behind you because the server counts total time, not race position. If you are delayed by any ping you have a disadvantage because your slip stream is free to use. You'll try to use your slipstream strategically and wait for them to go ahead, then slip stream off them, pass them over the line and lose. They will slip stream off you, and either pass you or not and you will lose, so you're fucked trying to choose when to boost because you're giving them free slipstream no matter what. The game is fucked.

It could have been fun to have an automatic only lobby so people didn't have to dick around with trying to get gears to work correctly in this fucking horrible let down of a game.

Sure, I have plenty of hours, but it was just turned to bullshit when I started PvP, the game is broken. I wasn't bad either, I got world top 100 times in some tracks, PvP was just erratic and almost no one played because they hid it speed within the terrible menus somewhere, fuck knows where it is, I just go to a tent in a HQ.

The game was fun, for a while, but it's buggy and Ubisoft are disgusting and obnoxious. Avoid the forums and their website because it's trash; oversized with massive ignorance, arrogance and censorship nonsense. Don't buy the Season pass, it just floods your game with unearned cars, yuk.

I'm going to be writing this review of TC2 in comparison to Forza Horizon (specifically 5). 
The Crew 2 is the first racing game I ever got into, and I genuinely was excited to get it. I was just as excited and having fun playing it as well. I haven't played since August of last year, however, that's due to my transition to the Forza series. I wanted to try something new. 

Nonetheless, The Crew 2 has a special place in my heart and I will keep coming back to it no matter what. I enjoyed this game a LOT, especially in 2021. Before I get to the pros of the game, I'd like to quickly talk about the cons so that it's out of the way and you're aware of those first: 

The Detail: 

Compared to Forza Horizon 5, the latest Forza game in the franchise, The Crew 2 isn't as detailed when it comes to map design. The buildings and set pieces can be rather bland at times and cities can feel a bit empty. 
In terms of car detail, it's there but not up to par with Forza. 

Characters: 

The characters are not that important, but I'll say they're not very realistic. I feel that Forza did a better job with character customization options. TC2 isn't that heavy on the character design, so just keep that in mind when you choose your default character. 

Single-player: 

- The Crew 2 is heavy on single-player mode, it's mainly a solo game. Yes, you can play co op, aka with friends, but it's more to explore than to race together. Forza has many multiplayer modes, which allows you to compete with other racers and there are leaderboards. 
But this is a PRO OR CON depending on what you prefer in racing games. If you like exploration and adventurous racing games that are solo, The Crew 2 is the right game for you. 

PROS: 

the map: 

- The map is truly huge and detailed. Although not all the displayed states are in detail (because that would take a hell lot of time), the landmarks and major cities are done properly. As a Floridian, I can confidently say that Miami is pretty accurate! The best part of TC2 is the feeling of driving across the United States. That's what you're paying $60 for. You're essentially travelling to all the major cities, beaches, and bridges by car. It can take you hours to drive through the entire country from one corner to the other; I highly recommend TypicalGamer's TC2 gameplay of driving all around the US. Overall, the map is awesome and you'll find many places to go, you won't run out of curiosity. 

Vehicle Switching: 

- this is one of the BEST features of The Crew 2. You can not only use cars but BOATS and PLANES as well. This provides ample opportunity to explore and feel immersed in the world of TC2. I personally love driving a boat around a city during sunset or sunrise. It's gorgeous and worth taking a good screenshot for. Although planes weren't my thing, it could be fun for other players that enjoy aerobatics. Being able to use cars and bikes is also such a cool feature to have. When I started Forza Horizon 5, I was bummed to find out that bikes weren't a thing. I think this is special to the crew 2 since I played NFS and there weren't any bikes there either. So, the trio vehicles are ultimately a great addition to the game and it feels like you're playing three separate vehicle games at once. 

Grinding: 

- this may be a CON for some players, but to me it's a pro. compared to Forza Horizon 5, it's MUCH harder to get cars in TC2 than in FH5. FH5 is very rewarding, of course, but it can diminish the meaning or satisfaction of getting a car after doing many races. The feeling of accomplishment can feel minimal. So, I like that I had to do many challenges, races, and quests in order to get a pretty good car in TC2. It makes me want to play the game more because of how much I have to do to get a car. It feels more realistic. 

Player Homes: 

- In Forza Horizon 5, the player "home" exists and you can purchase different homes other than your default one, but you can't really explore it. You can't go in and customize your car while your character is IN the house. Again, this may not be important to some players, but in TC2 I really liked the idea that my character could be in a 3D space in their house. I could walk around, even run, and change my outfit by just walking to the closet area. This gives me a sense of freedom; I like that I can explore places without using a car all the time. I know that sounds ironic because this IS a racing game, but when there's characters and exploration involved, I think that character mobility adds a nice touch of realism and freedom. 

All in all, The Crew 2 is a vast game of diverse racing opportunities with so much to explore. From hidden easter eggs to story challenges that encourage you to explore more, you'll constantly be driving around getting to know your environment. The customization, map size and landmark details, driving experience, and player mobility all contributes to the great charm of this game. I may be biased since this was my first ever car game, but I truly love it no matter what flaws it has. I genuinely enjoy the endeavor of visiting a state virtually when I can't in real-time. The Crew 2 gives that temporary feeling of adventure and thrill when you most need it. I would say The Crew 2 is worth the price and that you should pick it up if you love immersive racing games.

I initially had this as a do not recommend because of various reasons and one that is still front and center in my head is the terrible wheel support.. I dont understand why a game would claim to support wheels when you have to do all kind of backdoor work just to get the wheel to work with basic functionality.. I still dont have a working gear shifter and I still have to use a controller for anything other than gas, brake and steer.. Even then, I must do this little ritual anytime that I want to boot up the game and use my wheel.. This leaves me to favor almost any other game in my list over this one.. I must acknowledge that the majority will not have a wheel and this will not be an issue for them.. It still needs to be said.. 

My other negative about this game is that it is graphically challenged.. In todays market, there are small studios of a few people that put out graphics like this or even better.. The 60hz restriction is also a major drawback given the games poor graphics.. 

I will say that the game runs pretty good unless I try to plug the wheel in.. Without that, the game doesnt have any graphical glitches or freezes that Ive found.. 

If you have a friend or two to play with, That is where this game gets its positive review from.. The fact that its just fun to play with friends.. Of coarse, We avoid the boats and the planes mostly because those were honestly a waist of time putting into the game..  The core system is fun to play and the driving feels good for an arcade racing game.. Leaps and bounds ahead of the most recent NFS games.. In the end of the day, that is the most important aspect to get right.. If the driving sucks, the rest of the game is not fun.. NFS Unbound and Heat are a prime example of that.. 

Bottom line is that the game is worth a purchase if you are a controller user that has a friend to play with.. I would still wait for a good sale before purchasing.. I wouldnt write home about the game and honestly none of these big companies have released GOOD games in recent years.. The fact that this one is just not as bad as the rest is the reason to buy it.. Some guys like me always get that itch for an arcade racer and this is just going to have to do..

[b]*Original*[/b]
The Crew 2 has always had some problems, enough I think to deter many players from sticking with it. There were/are reasons to play it but this new Inner Drive update (Patch 1.6.0) makes enjoying the game that much harder.

Most of the problems I have with TC2 predate 1.6, the update just exacerbates them without fixing anything. 1.6 isn't all bad though, here are some things I like about it:
-The UI is better. It's still abysmal but it's better than it was.
-Hypercar offroad speed nerf. (probably a lot of mixed opinions here)
-New content.

Onto the bad; for TC2 as a whole, not just 1.6.
-A lot of the content, especially in 1.6, is premium cosmetics. You can earn CCs (premium currency) by completing daily challenges. I have quite a few tire smokes and underglows without spending any real money. 1.6 just adds more options for nickle and dime tactics.
The weird thing about it is how absolutely awful most cosmetics are. Like these things are bad. This is coming from a guy who puts anime tiddies on his cars. But hey, keep adding more instead of making the game better.
-Missing car brands. This is more a fault of the manufacturers I'm sure but it doesn't change the fact that brands such as Toyota and Subaru are absent. No Supra or Impreza for you.
-The open world isn't used to it's potential, there are a lot of tracks to race on but there are so many more possibilities. It feels like they skimped so as to be able to trickle new tracks every few weeks. There are even ready made locations like the Laguna Seca raceway that just aren't used.
-Tying into that, why is there no custom track editor? If you could make and share your own tracks I would reinstall and recommend this game in a heartbeat.

[b]So this is where it gets really bad.[/b]
-The PVP is an absolute joke. It's not about who is the better driver, it's about who has the better car. If you're both driving the same vehicle then it's about who has the better parts or higher Icon level. It's only about who is better if you're both maxed out really.
The higher your level in the game you can assign more and more points to things that make you catch up to other cars quicker, pull away quicker, your boost lasts longer, boost recharges faster, boost is more powerful, less slowdown offroad, bikes and planes handle better, and the more points you earn in skills.
If you're new, even if we both drive the same clunker, even if I unequip my Nitro Chemist parts, I would crush you on Icon Points alone. It's not a subtle difference. If I kept my max performance and perfectly affixed Nitro Chemist parts on I could probably give you at least a minute long head start and still smoke you.
-The grind is atrocious. Each vehicle type has their own parts which can be shared with other vehicles of the same type (Street Race, Drift, Power Boat, Stunt Plane, etc). Each type has 7 different parts, each part has four different rarity levels with yellow being the best, yellow parts have 5 different bonuses, you need all 7 parts with the same yellow bonus for it to activate. Each yellow part has 2 Affix bonuses that can be rerolled to help min-max the part (it makes a huge difference.)
Each part has it's own Performance level. Let's say you start with a Street Race car with 100 default performance rating. Each race you win you will get parts in a 97-103 performance range, the level of the parts will slowly go up from what you have. If you're unlucky you may have 160 Tires but 110 Brakes. Street Race performance maxes at 280 so once you get all your parts there you need to start grinding for a 280 yellow set. Remember each yellow part has 5 different bonuses and you need all 7 parts to be the same (yellow parts can be pretty rare). Now that you ground that out you need to waste around a million in game Bucks to min-max each part's affixes, two per part.
You think you're done? Do it again for the other 13 vehicle types.

I can keep going but if that's not enough for you I don't think anything else I say will really matter. Besides, thinking about things like the above grind for the Drag Race profession or back on track exploits is just depressing.

[b]Other Thoughts[/b]
-I really like the idea of weekly Summits. It's the only reason I've played the game as much as I have.
-Graphically the game is meh. It ranges from pretty good to pretty bad. There are some moments with pop in and LOD flickering that I almost wish the graphics were just worse. The flickering is so apparent and distracting. This is allegedly the fault of having planes in the game.
-The game takes quite a long time to boot up and connect to the Ubisoft servers. After you're in load times are very reasonable, at least on a SSD.

Get ready to rev your engines and join the race in "The Crew 2," a game with a great concept but a terrible execution that's sure to leave you wondering if it's worth the drive.

Sure, if you're solely interested in racing, "The Crew 2" might scratch that itch. But don't get your hopes up for anything else. Want to customise your character and make them your own? Well, tough luck, because you're stuck with a roster of default characters, but you'll have to be smart about it - because you can never change that avatar again. Thanks, Ubi!

Now I know it's the 21st century, but some of us still live in the dark ages, and this game requires a constant internet connection, even for single-player mode. If you're in an area with less-than-stellar internet or you simply prefer playing offline, tough luck again.

But wait, there's more! Let's talk about the car tuning system, or lack thereof. Sure, you can fine-tune your vehicle, but it's all in the form of random loot drops that have nothing to do with actual functionality or your skill as a driver. It's like giving someone a toolbox full of random objects and saying, "Good luck, hope you find something useful in there!" Because apparently, making logical adjustments based on your driving preferences and style is just too much to ask for.

And we can't forget the voice acting, nor the absolute lack of quality in that department. Prepare yourself for some iffy voice acting that's as inconsistent as rush-hour traffic. It's like the developers rounded up a bunch of random uni students and said, "Hey, can you do some voice lines? We'll pay you a half drunken beer and some leftover pizza."

"The Crew 2" is a game that had potential, but never failed to squander it at every turn. While some people might find enjoyment in its racing aspect, anyone seeking anything more will be deeply let down. It's best to hit the brakes on this one and find a game that truly delivers on its promises.

Thank you Ubi.

The Crew 2 is an open-world racing game developed by Ivory Tower and published by Ubisoft. The game features a variety of vehicles, including cars, boats, planes, and motorcycles, and allows players to race across a scaled-down version of the United States. Here's a detailed review of the game, covering its good, bad, and ugly aspects:

The Good:

Vehicle Variety: The Crew 2 features a massive variety of vehicles, ranging from sports cars to airplanes. Each vehicle feels unique, and players can easily switch between them during races or exploration.

Open World: The game's open world is impressive, with a scaled-down version of the United States that is both diverse and well-designed. Players can drive, fly, or sail across the map, discovering hidden areas and engaging in various activities.

Multiplayer: The game's multiplayer features are well-implemented, allowing players to compete against each other in races or explore the world together. The game also features live events that are updated regularly, adding to the game's replay-ability.

Graphics: The game's graphics are impressive, with detailed environments, high-quality textures, and smooth animations. The game also features a dynamic weather system that adds to the game's immersive experience.

Customization: The game allows players to customize their vehicles, including their paint jobs, performance, and handling. This adds an extra layer of personalization to the game, allowing players to create unique builds and play styles.

The Bad:

Story: The game's story is weak and uninteresting, with a generic plot that serves as a backdrop for the game's racing events. The story missions also feel disconnected from the rest of the game, which can be jarring.

Repetitive Races: While the game's variety of vehicles is impressive, the races themselves can feel repetitive. Many of the races share similar layouts or objectives, which can lead to a feeling of deja vu.

AI Difficulty: The game's AI difficulty can be inconsistent, with some races feeling too easy and others feeling frustratingly difficult. This can be exacerbated by the game's rubber-banding mechanic, which can make it difficult to maintain a lead.

The Ugly:

Glitches and Bugs: The game suffers from various glitches and bugs, ranging from minor graphical issues to major game-breaking bugs. Some players have reported issues with the game's AI, physics, and save system, which can be frustrating.

Micro-transactions: The game features micro-transactions that can be used to purchase vehicles, customization options, and other in-game items. While the micro-transactions are not necessary to enjoy the game, some players may find them off-putting.

Overall, The Crew 2 is an enjoyable racing game that offers a massive open world, a variety of vehicles, and solid multiplayer features. While the game's story is weak, its graphics, customization options, and vehicle variety make up for it. However, the game's repetitive races, inconsistent AI difficulty, and occasional glitches and bugs may frustrate some players. Despite these flaws, The Crew 2 is still worth playing for anyone who enjoys open-world racing games.

Ahoy there, matey! I recently set sail with "The Crew 2" and let me tell you, it was a real ride.

First off, the graphics were so good that I swear I could feel the wind rushing through my hair. And speaking of hair, the character customization options were so extensive that I was able to create a driver who looked just like me...if I had access to a professional stylist and plastic surgeon.

But the best part of the game was definitely the ability to switch between different vehicles on the fly. I mean, who wouldn't want to race a speedboat down the streets of New York City or fly a plane over the Grand Canyon? It was like being a superhero, except without all the responsibility and spandex.

Of course, there were some downsides too. The Al drivers seemed to have a vendetta against me and would ram into my car every chance they got. And I may or may not have accidentally driven my boat straight into a building while trying to take a shortcut.

Overall, "The Crew 2" was a wild and wacky experience that had me laughing and cursing in equal parts. If you're looking for a game that lets you live out your most ridiculous vehicular fantasies, this is the one for you. Just be prepared to lose a few brain cells along the way.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2022 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

The Crew 2 is probably one of my favorite racing games, from its fun driving, to its huge map. This game however is not your typical racing game, it's racing taken into so many other fields besides track racing or street racing. There's planes, boats, motocross, offroad racing, rally races, street races, etc. This game has it all. Sure the story lacks as it's not as emphasized as The Crew 1, but you get to mold your own character into who you want them to be. The graphics may also be lacking, but it makes up for the vast map and the crazy amount of content. Not to mention, this game is regularly updated, and has a very positive community. Overall, I couldn't ask for anything better. The Crew 2 is in a league of its own.

[h1] DO NOT BUY THIS GAME [/h1]
I bought it at an 80% discount and I completely regret it. Yes this game has a huge map, a broad variety of cars, and what not, but [b] it is more awful than enjoyable[/b]. First, I played it on 4K ultra settings and it still [b] looks like ancient racing/driving games[/b] (e.g., textures flickering, really bad draw distance, and geometry not spawning). Second, if you played any similar games (e.g., Assetto Corsa, any Forza game, Need For Speed...etc) [b] you will hate the handling of cars[/b] on this one. Third, what is the point of having a huge map if [b] its inconsistent and feels empty[/b]. The only good thing about the map is the different environments outside the cities, however, the cities are copied and pasted. Throughout my 2 hours of playtime I kept changing the graphical settings in disbelief that this is how the game looks in comparison to screenshots and videos.

I want to make this both a positive and negative review... The graphics are very good and the gameplay is very fun so in that case the game is definitely worth buying, however, this game has terrible support for the 'Logitech G29' wheel, as it will intermittently not recognise the wheel and won't create any button maps for it, I googled the issue and found it's been an issue for over a year and yet there's still no fix other than manually button mapping each thing, 'Ubisoft' don't know how to fix it and are clearly making no effort to even though it says on their website that the game has full support for it. The issue seems to be hit or miss and only affect some people, so there is a chance you'll have no issue but just know that there is a chance you''ll have to do a lot of manual editing to make the game work as expected. 

Overall, the game is good but the wheel support is hit or miss.

[i]I feel the need... for a race![/i]

It's clear to me that The Crew 2 was developed by some really passionate people who had an eye for detail, and it's a miracle that they somehow managed to wrangle such a huge and diverse game into a package where everything in it feels competently made.

Really, I'm blown away. There's a huge diversity of racing disciplines, and each one feels unique and well thought-out in their handling and design. For example doing a street race and messily barreling through a city feels vastly different from racing on a track (where, at higher difficulties, taking a good racing line will actually matter), or off-roading through the countryside and trying to manage bouncing through technical terrain. And then you have vehicles like dirt bikes that feel so different that they feel like they could've been in their own game; and then we got boats and planes, that again, are well-made and don't feel like jank bolted onto the game to tick some checkboxes.

The individual tracks themselves also all feel hand-made too, so there's no copy-pasta syndrome to be found here. And given that you'll be racing through complicated cityscapes and/or through large swathes of open country, the devs have also taken care to make sure where you need to go is always sign-posted so that you can focus on the race instead of on your mini-map.

Then there's the world. All I'll say it's absolutely huge, and it's been a blast road-tripping through the United States and creating my own stories.

So what's not good?

The physics. They work, and you can quickly get used to them, but the skill ceiling for mastering it is quite low. You can pretty much full-throttle it 90% of the time, and having to slow down or take a good line is an extremely rare event.

Being able to tailor the difficulty to your skill is also a big problem. Every event has 3 difficulty levels, but you're not able to freely select them, and must finish the event on lower difficulties before you'll be able to access the higher ones. Because of this, almost every event in the game has been too easy for me (I'm usually 10-30 seconds ahead of my opponents), even when I try to match my car's level with the event's recommended level. Sometimes matching the recommended level would give me a challenge, or I'd have to be 10-25 levels behind in order to not have the game turn into a Time Trial Simulator.

The loot system. It adds nothing to the game; all you do is just swap out lower numbers for higher numbers. Not to mention that because I was forced to play through every event on the lowest difficulty levels first, I never bothered with equipping upgrades because it'd have made these events even easier and more boring.

So in terms of raw fun factor, I'd have to give this game a 7. When the game gives you a proper challenge, it's absolutely exhilarating, but far too often you'll just end up yawning from being in 1st place all the time. In my playthrough the magic of the game wore off towards the end because I just wanted to finish the campaign, and I got tired of figuring out how many levels my car should've be under-leveled so that things wouldn't be too easy or too difficult.

But in the end, I must still give this game a thumbs-up due to how unique and how absolutely massive in scope it is. There's just nothing like it, and at a sale price of 80%, it's not hard to recommend.

This game is Very Epic!! Graphics are Outstanding!! Game Play is very Good!! Would 100% Recommend this game to any Racing Game Fans out there, hands down.

That aside, here are some low points of the game;
Even if you shell out $50 to buy the game, is pay to win afterwards.
The upgrade system for parts to upgrade vehicles was done badly.
Not alot of people are ever online.
I never see updates for fixing bugs in the game.
I don't know how to make my own Crew, nothing seems strait forward, and/or everything over complex where it should be simple, and everything in other areas of the game is too simple when should be more complex.
I could add few more complaints, but I'll just end it with, if you wanna exit the game, then gotta go to options, scroll off screen all the way to the right, is like a hidden feature that is very hidden, just for the option to exit the game, very dumb if ask me.

All of that aside, the game is actually really fun, the concept of every race type imaginable all in one is incredible.
The game runs very smooth.
Even if just racing against NPC's, is incredibly fun. (is many still playing all these years later if wanna race others)
The graphics for the whole USA blows my mind away, so very detailed no matter where you go, whether inside of cities, or out in the middle of nowhere, is all eye candy.
I'd say is a top notch game in many ways!!

All and all, if want an Epic Racing Game that is like no others, one that you will not regret buying, than this one is very good. And for the ones that say the controls are bad in the game, they probably have beginner stuff, and not yet have tasted a vehicle with upgraded stuff in it. They just need to put a few more hours in I'd say, or get better at racing. Am on keyboard here, can only imagine how much better a steering wheel would be, but keyboard works amazingly well.

Hope this review helps some people. :)

The Crew 2 is an open-world racing game developed by Ivory Tower and published by Ubisoft. It's a sequel to the popular game The Crew and features an expanded gameplay experience, including the ability to race in cars, boats, planes, and motorcycles. Here is the review of The Crew 2, mentioning both the positive and negative aspects of the game.

Positive aspects:
The Crew 2 has a vast open-world map that allows you to explore the United States and participate in a wide variety of races and challenges. The game offers a seamless transition between vehicles, making it easy to switch between land, sea, and air racing. The game's graphics are impressive, with stunning visuals that showcase different locations and terrains realistically. The game's physics engine is also noteworthy, as it provides a realistic and immersive driving experience.

Another positive aspect of The Crew 2 is the variety of races and events. The game features various race modes, including street racing, rally racing, and drag racing. The game also has events that involve performing stunts, time trials, and speed challenges. This variety adds a level of excitement to the game, as there is always something new to do and explore.

Negative aspects:
One of the negative aspects of The Crew 2 is the lack of a compelling story. The game's narrative is thin, and the characters are not well developed. This can make the game feel shallow and lacking in substance. Additionally, the game's AI opponents are not very challenging, making it easy to win races and challenges. This lack of difficulty can lead to the game feeling repetitive and boring after a while.

Another negative aspect of The Crew 2 is the microtransaction system. While the game itself is not a pay-to-win title, some of the in-game content is locked behind a paywall. This can make the game feel like a grind, as you need to spend a lot of time earning in-game currency to unlock new vehicles and upgrades.

Grade:
Overall, The Crew 2 is an enjoyable racing game with impressive visuals, a wide variety of vehicles, and a large open world to explore. However, the lack of a compelling story and challenging AI opponents can detract from the overall experience. Additionally, the microtransaction system can make the game feel like a grind at times. Despite its flaws, The Crew 2 is still a fun game to play, and I would give it a solid 7 out of 10.

After of hundred of playtime, here is what i can conclude 

1) Car customization still feels like half baked, like if you want certain body part and rim to look esthetic, it really missed the mark. Like there is no body kit manufacture/brand, all the customization preset are just mix-n-match, not come close like other title like NFS series does. Example car like GTR which potentially hold lots of customization laughably can hold 3 body kit preset in this game. This part of the game really need to improve the most as for what you play racing/car game for then? 
2) Same grinding to earn money really come to tear off. Maybe you need to add race customization slider like traffic car density and lap round. Certain player like short race then repeat that over again and again, some player enjoy long trip race but all the available race option it offer are too few. Although, overtime they did add lots of race option into the game, but it does not feel variable as each of these race does not feel so different one to another, and very few variable long trip race being add to base of the game, else from weekly summit event in the game. 
3) I kinda missed the OG the crew 1 where there is free roam police, the thrilling police chase and things to do around the map rather than this 'soy' and being 'legit' of following rules, influencer of motor world wannabe nonsense. In anyway, i didnt deny that adding the wannabe police chase mode aka stuntman mode, movie setup, etc of whatever nonsense creativity you want to bring but the what really keep player busy doing around the map when not in the mood grinding money from race is maybe adding the police chase that your playerbase had been crying out loud for many years yet you would never want to do that. Not gonna spend my time roaming around searching for exp box + car part inside them or perhaps the nobody ask for of the boat and plane being add into this game further render this 'soy' mode in game sink more and more. 

That is all my not recommend tag for this game, perspectively from veteran player. I cant say much for those who are new or want to find reason of if they need to buy this game or not but i would say no since if you are looking for element of customization, grind and diversity of the game could offer for you, in short and long term, it is kinda meh and not worthy. The only good thing in this game is that the very large open world map, LOTS and LOAD of car and they still add few more to the list but thats all.

The Crew 2 is an open-world racing game developed by Ivory Tower and published by Ubisoft. It was released in 2018 and is a sequel to the original The Crew game. The game allows players to explore a vast open-world recreation of the United States, race against other players online, and collect a variety of vehicles, including cars, boats, planes, and motorcycles.

Pros and cons
üü© Positives	
- Expansive open-world with a variety of environments to explore

- Impressive level of vehicle customisation

- Wide range of vehicles to collect, including rare and unique ones

- Well-designed vehicle models with realistic handling

- Weekly events and challenges provide a sense of progression and competition

- Impressive graphics and sound design

üü• Negatives	

- Grindy nature of the game may be off-putting for some players

- Limited storyline and lack of compelling characters

- Some "vanities" can only be obtained through real money or live summits

- Multiplayer PvP mode is limited to simple point-to-point races

- Some bugs and issues with the game, though most have been addressed through updates and patches.

Gameplay
The Crew 2's gameplay is enjoyable and immersive, with a strong emphasis on exploration and racing. The game's expansive open-world allows players to explore various environments, from bustling cities to scenic countryside landscapes. The game's attention to detail is impressive, with realistic handling of the different vehicles and a wide range of customisation options.

Events
The game's "live summits" events are weekly events where players can win vanity items or time-limited cars. However, some players may struggle to win the top prize without first obtaining cars and parts that give them an advantage. The game's multiplayer PvP mode is a simple race from point A to point B.

Vehicles
The game offers rare, unique vehicles not usually found in other racing games. The game's vehicle models are well-designed, and the level of customisation is impressive, allowing players to almost widebody every car. However, some of the game's "vanities" can only be obtained through real money or live summits, which may be off-putting for some players.

Story
The game's story is minimal, with no clear protagonist or antagonist, and the game focuses more on exploration and racing than storytelling. However, the game's open-world and the various challenges and events provide a sense of progression.

Graphics and Sound
The game's graphics are impressive, with detailed vehicle models and environments that look and feel realistic. The game's sound design is also noteworthy, with diverse sound effects adding to the immersive experience.

Conclusion
Overall, The Crew 2 is an enjoyable and immersive racing game that offers a vast open-world, a wide range of vehicles, and various events to compete in. The game's attention to detail is impressive, and the vehicle models are well-designed with realistic handling. However, some players may find the game's grindy nature and lack of a compelling story mode to be a turnoff. Nevertheless, The Crew 2 is still a game worth playing for racing fans and those who enjoy exploring and customising their vehicles.

The game's mechanics felt clunky and unpolished, and the graphics were lackluster compared to other modern racing games. The open-world environment was massive, but it felt empty and uninteresting to explore. The racing itself was underwhelming and didn't offer much excitement or variety, and the AI opponents were frustratingly difficult to beat at times. 

I was also disappointed with the game's reliance on microtransactions, which made progression feel slow and tedious without spending additional money. 

Overall, The Crew 2 is a game that I would not recommend to anyone looking for a satisfying racing experience.

Overall, its a game that could be run mindlessly in the background. 5.5/10.
