[h1] Drive like you stole it! [/h1]
The Crew 2 is an open-world racing game developed by Ivory Tower and published by Ubisoft. It was released in 2018 and is a sequel to the original The Crew game. The game allows players to explore a vast open-world recreation of the United States, race against other players online, and collect a variety of vehicles, including cars, boats, planes, and motorcycles.

[h2] Pros and cons [/h2]
[table]
[tr]
[th] üü© Positives [/th]
[th] üü• Negatives [/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]
- Expansive open-world with a variety of environments to explore

- Impressive level of vehicle customisation

- Wide range of vehicles to collect, including rare and unique ones

- Well-designed vehicle models with realistic handling

- Weekly events and challenges provide a sense of progression and competition

- Impressive graphics and sound design
	[/td]
	[td]
- Grindy nature of the game may be off-putting for some players

- Limited storyline and lack of compelling characters

- Some "vanities" can only be obtained through real money or live summits

- Multiplayer PvP mode is limited to simple point-to-point races

- Some bugs and issues with the game, though most have been addressed through updates and patches.
	[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]	

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]
The Crew 2's gameplay is enjoyable and immersive, with a strong emphasis on exploration and racing. The game's expansive open-world allows players to explore various environments, from bustling cities to scenic countryside landscapes. The game's attention to detail is impressive, with realistic handling of the different vehicles and a wide range of customisation options.

[h3] Events [/h3]
The game's "live summits" events are weekly events where players can win vanity items or time-limited cars. However, some players may struggle to win the top prize without first obtaining cars and parts that give them an advantage. The game's multiplayer PvP mode is a simple race from point A to point B.

[h2] Vehicles [/h2]
The game offers rare, unique vehicles not usually found in other racing games. The game's vehicle models are well-designed, and the level of customisation is impressive, allowing players to almost widebody every car. However, some of the game's "vanities" can only be obtained through real money or live summits, which may be off-putting for some players.

[h2] Story [/h2]
The game's story is minimal, with no clear protagonist or antagonist, and the game focuses more on exploration and racing than storytelling. However, the game's open-world and the various challenges and events provide a sense of progression.

[h2] Graphics and Sound [/h2]
The game's graphics are impressive, with detailed vehicle models and environments that look and feel realistic. The game's sound design is also noteworthy, with diverse sound effects adding to the immersive experience.

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]
Overall, The Crew 2 is an enjoyable and immersive racing game that offers a vast open-world, a wide range of vehicles, and various events to compete in. The game's attention to detail is impressive, and the vehicle models are well-designed with realistic handling. However, some players may find the game's grindy nature and lack of a compelling story mode to be a turnoff. Nevertheless, The Crew 2 is still a game worth playing for racing fans and those who enjoy exploring and customising their vehicles.

Better than Horizon 5, Crew 2 does not throw cars at you every time you do or think of doing something. In Crew 2 getting a new car has a sense of achievement. I played both, Crew 2 is far more enjoyable, even the driving. Horizon 5 is more like a cheap arcade game if it was not for all the hype for some visual gimmicks.Update: story missions are super fun and engaging, large cities are simply amazing (see Chicago, St. Luis, etc), driving is also very fun, recommend to drive open cars like the Porsche Syder 550 to see more of the world as you drive. If you are on the fence defiantly get it, drive with a new version of Xbox controller, and set your settings correctly to drive (look on line for advice). Start with the story missions, they consist of 12 parts each, some less, but each takes about your better part of a real day.  The reward is usually a car , which is nice as cars are hard to get in this game unless you want to pay for micro-transactions, which of course you should not do, it just ruins the fun and the achievement.Also, 10,000 km of roads, amazing country and scenery, awesome vehicles, and super fun driving (somehow more fun than any other driving games I tried in the past).

weeeeeell, it WOULD be a very nice arcade racing game, if I hadn't had some very annoying issues:

1. if you tab out of the game, it's almost impossible to get back into the game (for me at least)
2. I was doing this story mission thing, I was at the VERY end, last mission. 7km before I reached the final location,
I leveled up, which deleted my progress to that destination, so I had to drive all the way from the west coast, to the east coast again. almost 20 minutes of boring high ways... twice in a row >.<
3. the menu is weird to navigate. I often end up pushing the wrong button, which puts me into the store and also deletes my progress towars a story destination -.-
4. you always start at your home and not where you left the game
5. the music doesn't fit the offroad and motocross sections of the game (the music sucks in it's entirety but well, every one has a different taste)

if I hadn't had the issues, I'd give it a thumbs up...

Massive download size, high system requirements. BUT - great driving, and a beautiful open world map. It's great to just drive around with the radio on, finding speed traps and jumps, and doing achievements. The game really wants to push you to do missions, but honestly there's so much more to the experience than level progression that the devs seem to have forgotten about - even if the races and challenges are a lot of fun. If you're interested in the planes, USE A CONTROLLER. Also some of the default key binds aren't even keys on my laptop, like "right ctrl", and you can't change all the binds for the menus. There isn't a tutorial, so it's worth checking your binds even if you have a full keyboard or controller.

If you're new to racing games, this is a great introduction to the genre. It's open-ended, tailors to many different styles, and is very accessible to newcomers.

The thing that makes The Crew 2 great is its variety. Unlike most racing games out there, this game gives you a taste of almost every conceivable racing sport, on land, in the sea, or in the air. From street racing to offroad, motorcycles, dirt bikes, monster trucks, speed boats, demolition derby, aerial acrobatics, and even hovercraft; there's a little bit of everything here. The beauty is that none of them is too difficult for you to quickly grasp the basics, allowing you to seamlessly drift between disciplines to your heart's content. My personal favorites are the multi-discipline events, switching styles mid-race. I also found most of the bikes really satisfying to drive.

The game definitely leans toward the arcade end of the arcade/simulator spectrum, so if you're looking for true depth, you may find the game lacking. But if you're looking for a thrilling time in a variety of disciplines, The Crew 2 has got you covered.

I am not recommending this game only because of the randomised loot boxes that you need to acquire in order to upgrade your vehicles performance.
Bad things about the game:
Firstly, this game uses a system of loot boxes with random items to upgrade vehicle performance, which is highly annoying if you are looking for a specific item because it cannot be found in a specific area or bought using the in game (or real world) currency.  I personally found the loot box system so annoying I stopped playing and bought Forza.  If you can get over the randomly stupid loot boxes then read on.  This game has BattlEye cheat protection which may work while competing against other players, but does not stop cheaters from obtaining impossible speed records.  
Good things about the game:
There are heaps of different vehicles and heaps of different races, both single player and multiplayer.  While there are heaps of different vehicles to race and heaps of different things to do, be aware that this is a game with very arcade physics and not a simulator.  If you are looking for a simulator experience, this is fun, but it's probably not the game for you, however if you are looking for a game that you can just play without having to worry about micro managing vehicle setups and going through ludicrous qualifying stages then this is a decent game (except for the loot boxes).

Sometime in the recent past, the devs added Stories, and these are a great addition. They give you rewards (vehicles, cosmetics, followers, depending on the scope of the story) for driving at your own pace -- though you do have to complete a given leg of a story (not the whole story) from start to finish in one session, usually 5 to 20 minutes a leg. Just make sure the Start location goal turns green before you drive all the way to the final goal... mark my words!

Open-world graphics range from great to decent to ehh. They're mostly good. Many different event types and vehicle types. I'd like to see more classic cars, especially from the 30's-50's, but there are at least a few nice ones. The option to select user-created liveries is a lot of fun.

The bad:
* Mighty Mac in real life does not begin on the northern edge of Detroit, and has only two towers.
* Game taunts you with cars and clothing you have no way of ever obtaining because they were tied to some long-gone battle pass.

All in all, a terrific pick-up-and-play game for those times when American Truck Simulator feels like too much work.

Easily the best open world racing game in 2023 imo.

[b]Playstyle[b]: While Forza Horizon genre becomes dull in a few hours of play time, Crew 2 does it's job of keeping the game alive in any way or form. Live summits are renewed every week, requiring you to grind new vehicles to perform better in the leaderboard. The races in the summits are not seperated from each other and you need every kind of vehicle to achieve a decent point. Grinding for points is easily understanable in 4-5 hours into the game for an average player, unlike other racing games in the genre which takes a lot longer. 

[b]Driving[b]: Not as good as other games in the genre, though has its own style such as drag cars, hypercars and offroad cars. The driving styles are seperated in every category, not as realistic but gets you hooked anyways.

[b]Casual Friendly?[b] : Yes, only factor keeping the game competitive is pretty much weekly summits which is not obligatory to do. You can pretty much try to beat your own score and leave too.

[b]Multiplayer[b]: Not often that you see PvP matches but you can add friends to grind money and followers together which is a much better dynamic.

[b]Pros[b]: A big open world map that'll take hours to roam.

I haven't actually played this game since about a month after it came out because it was so boring compared to TC1, which is a shame because I got every hypetrain challenges in TC1 done for all 15 free cars on launch, participated in the closed beta (and then skipped the open beta because Ubisoft lied in beta emails, locking the easier beta item away forever, even after I contacted support to tell them what was up), and also it doesn't work on Linux because the anti-cheat is unsupported.

The first thing that happened to me in the beta was I drove my car off the ski slope jump and immediately collided with someone in a low flying plane. No, I did not set that up, I have no friends. I just knocked someone out of the air with my car coincidentally because I wanted to see if they fixed the physics going ape shit when you land a non-raid vehicle after a huge jump.

Compared to TC1:

++ improved open world
++ more cars
++ sound design, cars sound more dynamic now.
++ no, seriously, they put more effort into the world
++ anticheat so the records can finally not be arbitrarily limited however Ivory Tower eventually put in place in TC1 where you can now set an actual world record but not have it count because they considered it beyond the "you're cheating" barrier
++ manual livery editor, not unlike Forza.

-- anticheat doesn't work on linux and stops you from playing at all even 5 years later.
-- the story is somehow even worse, how did you make a worse story
-- why are we driving on rooftops?
-- I hate more than half of the racing types in this game and there's nothing you can do to skip them if you really, really hate them
-- last I tried, bikes are even more annoying than in TC1
-- they removed arbitrary fast travel because "you have planes now and hypercars are fast" so if you don't like any of those you can go fuck yourself, or pray someone set a land speed record where you want to go
-- doing the same stunt jump in Chicago for 2 hours to level a car was annoying but now there's no reason to do anything at all. I had no motivation to do literally anything in game anymore.
-- Forza 3 has a better livery editor. Like being able to precisely set the positions of stuff. If that still doesn't exist in this game, it's less advanced than a title available on the Xbox 360 from 2009. I don't even remember if that level of detail was in Forza 2, but if it was it doesn't make their editor any better.
-- CARBON FIBRE STILL CANNOT BE PAINTED OVER WITH PAINT OR DECALS

The Bladerunner 35 looks dumb so I'm not personally bothered but still upset by principle, and the Spitfire MK IX in Aerobatics being paywalled was also really stupid.
~~ There is no longer a division between "Street" and "Performance" where cars seemingly randomly have a street version but no performance version, ex. the Chrysler 300C SRT8 in TC1, which is basically a Dodge Charger, but only available in Street probably due to licencing. Or the reverse which means the car is available for the spec with the least races in the Story [i]and[/i] PvP despite being the spec with the most vehicles (WHY?). I did not buy enough cars to find out if there's still an issue like there was in TC1 where around 50% of the Performance category is unusable at max level because there's "Performance" and "[b]Performance[/b]" spec vehicles divided by "is basically a fast street car" and "this rivals a circuit spec car." Now instead you have "road cars" and "really really fast road cars" which also means "I hope you really like a modern hypercar (that's in this game) because if not this is going to be a set of long and boring races because it's either hypercars or no car"

After playing it for a while, i've realized, i actually really like this game.
If you expect realism, this game isn't for you, but if fun and speed is what you're after, you honestly can't do much better than this.

The variety is honestly spectacular, you can go from a driving an F1 car, to racing in speed boats and then fly around in an acrobatic plane in the same event, its nuts! 

The game also tells me that 69% (nice) of my time spent in the game was on street racing, and there's good reason for that, because you can turn any car you want into an absolute monster, the customization is pretty good as well, despite the parts being all original from the game (brand name parts are still sorely missed).

I say give it a try if you're a fan of arcade racing, or if you're burnt out from sim racers, this is quite a breath of fresh air.

Waste of money. Here's why I think that: The concept is nice, cars boats and planes racing all over America. It sounds good on paper but as the game really plays, the map is quantity over quality, in exchange for such a large map they had the game essentially looking like a mobile game. Another issue is the races are just boring roadtrips if they aren't just within a single city. That's all fine and dandy except when you consider the handling is very barebones and the sense of speed is basically nonexistent, plus the soundtrack isn't really the best so you're really just in for an incredibly boring, incredibly long ride. I have never fallen asleep playing games unless I was really comfortable but this game had me snoring while standing up, that's not what you want out of a video game. Another thing this game offers is vehicles. Personally I only really care about the cars and let me tell you, the car list is pretty solid. A good amount of tuner, muscle, and supercars. They even have a good selection of bikes and even a hovercraft if that tickles your fancy. The game also has customization which is where the fun ends for me. I do want to say that the customization isn't so bad, and it almost isn't. But it's mainly just splitter kits and tacky spoilers, alot of the better customized cars coming with some pretty ugly body kits that make Need for Speed Underground 2 look more considerable. If I had to say, I'd recommend just buying Forza Horizon, you'll have more fun with that mess than you will here. But if you want a real recommendation, despite the fandom calling it essentially one of the worst games ever, Need for Speed Unbound is a great game. Significantly better customization, more unique handling between cars, a banger soundtrack, colorful artstyle, beautiful city to go along with the stunning graphics, and the single player story is more interesting than whatever The Crew 2 has to offer. This game feels like a cheap yet incredibly overpriced Forza clone and it's not worth your time or money. I already wasted mine and have taken too long to get my refund, I just hope you can spare your wallet or save the money for something better. Maybe Motorfest will be better at least, I really do hope for the best for that game.

In this comment I will be telling you if this game is still worth to buy in 2023. This won't be the best explanation or review but at least I hope this will help you decide, but from now I will tell you WAIT FOR A SALE it's not a this good of a game to be worht the full price for it. 

Let's Begin.

Cars: There are so many cars to collect and there is at least a few that you won't usually see in forza or any other racing game (Unless they get inspired by it). For example Bugatti La voiture noire and cars that are completely created out of nowhere (If I'm not wrong) with a lot of customization, which leads to my next point.

Customization: You can almost widebody every single car in the game, the customization might not be need for speed style but you can still make it cool. But there is something called "Vanitys" you can change almost every part of the car that goes tires,windows,nitro color,tire smoke and neons, but you can earn them by buying them with real money OR through live summets but if you don't care about that it shouldn't be a big deal.

Events: The only events in this game are "live summets" they are weekly events where you can win vanitys or cars that are time limited. For a new player you can't win the top prize, no chance. You need cars and parts that give you a bit of advantage which sucks but at least you can try and win something on it.

Mulitplayer PVP: Race from point A to point B that's all.

Open World: The map is huge and it will take a very long time to travel alone or with your friends from the left side to the right side of the map. It suppost to be America but not really because the citys are small and it's inaccurate.

Everything else is just personal opinion, I hope this review helped with your decision.

Driving dynamics in this game are embarrassing. Think oldschool Lego game driving feel, Not the lego racing games, the TT game vehicle handling model. This worlds interpretation of gravity seems to be that the ground is a magnet. Where normal gravity has you take a jump and soar through a beautiful arc through the air. This games jump ends with a direct drop straight to the ground with the least satisfying of crashes. And thats with any vehicle, thats just how the "physics" work. Them putting stuntparks and jumps in here is nothing short of ballzy with these physics, as it so clearly outlines how abysmal they are. You want a fun arcade racer with easy but competent physics? Hotwheels unleashed is infinitely more complex and intuitive than this game.

I played the demo for this about 2 years ago, felt like trash then, feels the same now. Theres a lot of things that this game does well and compared to Forzas dilapidated state of content and complete lack of personality, This game has a lot of good ideas and flare, and really, it has massive potential. The physics are not okay, they're not what I consider passable my any degree. The first Crew had passable physics and driving, This is like that game if it were made in 1996, but remember, Porsche unleashed came out in 2000. And by comparison, Porsche would be a certified racing sim. Its close to the worst driving Ive ever experienced, but I used to play a lot of bootleg cheap iphone racing apps back in highschool 10 years ago, so its just slightly above that standard for me.

The kicker for me requesting a refund was that I log in today and my controller mapping is completely borked. Cant reset to default, doesnt fix it. Cant remap to get an accept button, Just completely unusable. On the forums on here I learn its a common issues and the best solutions are messing with code files. At that point I requested a refund. 
The devs appear to have stopped fixing issues, but they seem to still be releasing content to dangle MTX and paid transactions ingame. What an absolute shame. I heard they're planning another entry soon to compete more directly with the Horizon franchise. I guarantee you wont see me there if the physics are not at least 10x better than this, because Horizon 5 is probably 30x. I was hopeful that there would be a more targeted effort with the franchise, but having now played this one firsthand, my outlook is quite grim.

The Crew 2 is a racing game with a poor driving model that falls short of its potential. The driving mechanics are unrealistic and lack depth, making it difficult to enjoy the racing experience. The physics feel off, and the handling is far too simplistic, making it difficult to maneuver around tight corners or maintain control at high speeds. The game's emphasis on arcade-style racing also detracts from any sense of realism, which may disappoint those looking for a more authentic driving experience. Overall, the poor driving model is a major drawback to an otherwise promising game.

If you're looking for a good arcade racing game then this one's for you, the game has a good vehicle selection, big and beautiful map taking up to an hour to drive across, much to do and much to see. Though, there are some downsides to the game but the positives outweigh the bad ones. 

The game's fun, the big map adds a lot, but most often it just feels desolate with only about 10 different npc car models and the pedestrians.
Big selection of cars, bikes, boats, planes, but to be honest you'll be playing with cars most of the time. Plane control is horrendous so I just avoid them, boats are fine. The game does not have any cars from 2020 from what I've noticed.

You'll be crashing into npc cars on the road a lot and I mean a lot, sometimes they're literally  invisible or they just spawn right in front of you while you're going at 400 km/h.

I wouldn't recommend buying this game alone, try to persuade a friend or two since going solo will be super boring. (most fun times i've had were when me and my friends would go on road trips across america with wonky vehicles).

Good luck finding a pvp match or players in general since the servers are pretty dead with their being 1-3 people in a regular session.
Do not buy this game when it's off sale, don't scam yourself by paying the full price, just wait for a sale and get it for pretty cheap.

Godspeed.

Upon playing this game for solid 50 hours i realized that this game is more of MMO than a fun multiplayer racing game. Every car,boat,plane is so damn expensive to purchase. You can play NFS or Forza Horizon game for 50 hours and purchase everything those games have to offer. But in here after playing for 50 hours i only got 4 cars and few boats&planes. It takes ridiculous amount of time to purchase something. Controls are kinda janky i played it with kbm and dualshock 4 and it felt like game tried to act like half sim and half arcade but in the end it couldn't do either of them a justice. It's not a terrible game though, graphics are fine and it's cool to take your favorite vehicle and ride it through map of whole USA. In the end the game couldn't satisfy my needs and disappointed me. I apologize for the grammer mistakes i did. I'm not a native speaker.

Short review: ITs a good game with some major issues. About 200+ square mile map, tons of real world landmarks outside of the major cities, many small cities, photo op and story side missions requiring traveling. good amount of cars, some notables missing(no 90's NSX, S15, 65' Cobra, F50 etc), can use planes and boats too, they are decent, you'll either love it or hate it, dont have to use them. 4 main discipline catagories with 4 sub catagories within. main story is bare bones, told mostly in subtitles. Main rivals are laughable. handling model is alright. some issues. two game currencies called Crew Credits and Bucks. CC must be gained using real money. You level up from gaining followers you win from events and doing tricks in free roam. Good game with some glaring issues

Long review:
My first impressions when playing the first 20 minutes was that the handling model was strange but not too much of a problem, but when I came to realize is that this game has the strangest handling model of any game that ive played. Nearly every car seems to spontaneously lose grip when going around corners. whats worse is that the certain cars have handling that is complete opposite of their real counterparts. Case in point two cars, the 2018 Nismo R35 and the Lamborghini Veneno, The Nismo handles more like a 65 Shelby Cobra would, tail happy all the time with no downforce. The Veneno has the steering response of a Lincoln Continental. I suspect they do this to foment discontent so you spend money to try and fix the issue

The map is cool, lots of things to see and do. You have a home base in LA that will change as your Icon level goes up(you get another in Florida if you have the Season Pass). There are photo ops in each of the 4 catagories(Street Race, Freestyle, Off Road, and Pro Racer) There are Hobbies with 3 catagories(Explorer, Collector, and Racer) with LOTS of in game achievements. There are 12+ Stories where you travel all over the map to unique locations that take hours by themselves to complete because of travel distances and you get unique prizes like cars and custom wheels, horns, nos etc. There is also I live summit event which consists of 8 events varying in disciplines and is point based. You compete with other players in point totals going from bronze to platinum(platinum being the top 4000 players). Prizes for each medal, platinum being a rare custom item you can only get through live summit. There are also PVP events in  as well which ive never tried as of now but you just add the human factor to all the things ive mentioned

As you progress the map with show events as you progress as well as the headquarters of the 4 main disciplines. Traveling around is fun and engaging. You can see other players as well, up to about 10  There is also a day night cycle and some cars even show the progression of time on their digital dashboards if they have them. The graphics are decent but I have a serious problem with the pop in and the lack of sufficient detail on distant objects at ultra settings. Also settings any resolution past 1900x1200 with show constant microstuttering, at least for me, no fix as of yet. So I cant set the game to my monitors native resolution which sucks and is a mark against the games appeal

Overall I would recommend the game but on sale. Full price it has too many glaring issues to be worth full price.
9I9A

The Crew 2 is an open-world racing game that allows players to explore a vast virtual recreation of the United States. The game offers a diverse range of vehicles, from sports cars to airplanes, that players can use to race and perform stunts. The game's map is massive and well-detailed, offering players a variety of landscapes and environments to explore.

However, The Crew 2 is not without its flaws. The game's controls can feel loose and unresponsive at times, making it difficult to navigate tight turns or perform stunts. The AI opponents can also be overly aggressive, leading to a number of frustrating accidents during races. The game's story is also underwhelming and lacks depth, making it difficult for players to become fully invested in the game world.

Despite these issues, The Crew 2 is still a fun and engaging racing game that is well worth checking out for fans of the genre. The game's diverse range of vehicles and vast open-world map make it a unique and enjoyable experience that is sure to provide hours of entertainment.

Even though this is not Forza Horizon 4/5. But this game is special in it's own good way. One of my favorite arcade racing games. Really fun to play with friends. Especially with the "Crew' mechanic, which means if you are playing with a friend, and one of you win, you both win. Weekly updates (Summits) can keep you playing for a long time after you finish everything. Every week Summits allow you to compete against other players to win limited edition items/cars, which keeps things fresh. Game also receives free DLC updates few times a year. Another + to this game, is Motorpasses (Crew 2's equivalent to battle passes) can be purchased with in-game currency, so you don't have to buy In-game micro-transactions to get the new stuff! (To my knowledge this is the first game to do this) A lot of people reviewed this game for it's "poor" story. Even though it's about "becoming famous" and gaining followers, it can still be enjoyable, and it keeps getting updated and getting better with every update. You can see that the developers really try to make this game better with every update. Overall: Would highly recommend this game.

I have a hard time deciding whether to give this damned game a thumb-up or thumb-down
I'd say 3/5

[h1] Story [/h1]
The game is mostly about street racers trying to legalize street racing and have fun[i] (3/4 disciplines, because Pro Racer is salty as hell.) [/i] IMO this is a weird turn from the first The Crew game where it's like, about revenge and underground stuff
[i] Cons, see Gameplay. [/i]

[h1] Pros [/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Visual & Scenery[/b] - If you're up for chill rides and scenic routes, this game has a good landscape and graphics.
[*][b]Bikes[/b] - One of the reasons I'm still coming back to this game is I love street racing games and bikes, which FH and NFS can't offer. [i]But still, see Cons.[/i]
[*][b]Planes[/b] - This game has them and ngl I love my Mustang so much.
[*][b]Free Battlepass[/b] - You could get them with a huge amount of grind currency. But hey, 'least it's free, eh?
[*][b]Exploration[/b] - This game has a lot of side activity beside racing. Photography, not gonna lie, this game has great photo mode. And Stories, where you get to travel to places finding secrets which I didn't get to it fully just yet.[spoiler]Or I'm just hungry for it because PSO2 NGS exploration sucks so much.[/spoiler]
[/list]

[h1] Cons [/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Unforgiving Competition [/b] - It's not that I'm a snowflake that can't the L, but according to the story, the competitions is supposed to be [i] for sports and fun [/i]. But no, in this game, If you lost, you won't get no jackshit. Not even a perf part to gitgud. It's supposed to be like Forza Horizon and not like NFS universe where GGEZ is a thing.
[*][b]Bikes[/b] - Bikes suck. Ubisoft just nerfed them to the lowest pit of hell. I used to ride Panigale everywhere, and now it could barely corner at all. And not just Panigale, everything. Fireblade, Draxter, S1KRR, you name it. They suck.
[*][b]AIs[/b] - The AIs in this game is either insanely bad or insanely good after you maxxed out the perf limit on your rides. It's either you or them are going to be collecting dust always.
[*][b]RPG system and Grind[/b] - The Crew 2 involves a shitton of grinding and you better start praying to god you don't get trash parts so you can move on to cooking or do something else.
[*][b]Boat races[/b] - Who the hell at the HQ takes a dump and thinks this shit is a great idea?
[*][b]Customization[/b] - The Crew 2 is about fast, flashy cars, but offers weirdly bad customization, about visual parts I mean. [b]Because the vinyl system is even worse.[/b] Hell, you can't even search or [b]save[/b] vinyl designs. The search engine is incredibly horrible. You can get either the tops, or recents. Tag search isn't helping either. Forza franchise tops this. Ubisoft if you don't fix this, you won't even get a chance at a comeback ever.
   JDM fanboys, I'm sorry. You could barely customize R35 at all. No fat body kits, not even wheels.
[*][b]Weird Weather[/b] - It's a minor issue I have for immersion reason. Imagine chilling in summer and the next minute it's already snowing for a whopping 5 minutes.
[*][b]Weird vehicle lineup[/b] - Recently Nissan unveild '24 R35, and this game decides to add '15 model of it just now I don't understand why. I think they previously add the old '16 Yamaha M1 during around the 2021 MotoGP period too. Still waiting for more bikes like R1 and V4 by the way.
   I was so excited for F4U Corsair when it was leaked. Words can't describe my disappointment to think they already scrapped it.
[/list]

I'm still doubting if I should give this a thumbs-up, I really want to do the opposite. But I won't lie I find myself still enjoy chilling in this game. So thumbs-up it seems.

Coming from a player with 2000+ hours:

Good game...
-Very large map
-Lots of camera angles (including cockpit)
-Lots of cars
-A few planes
-A few boats
-Lots of racing variety (16)
-Good enough graphics
-Customization: Vanity (tires, smoke, nitrous,tint) Livery sharing

However...
-Microtransactions
-Buy the Gold Edition or you won't get the permanent 20% vehicle price discount
-Limited edition cars (LIVE Summit exclusive) that you can only win in specific weeks (can't buy them)
-Can't customize Visual Parts (hoods, front bumpers, widebody, spoilers) on limited edition cars
-Very little camera shake, makes it boring
-Not very exciting special races, only 1 or 2

6-7 / 10

After playing for a while to this title I feel ready to give a certain opinion about it.
Since the beggining of the game you may notice that it's a little empty. As far as i'm concerned I think that we both can agree(me and you(the reader(if you have played more than 2 or 3 hours))) that the game is particularly empty considering the astonishing quantity of the cities all around United States. I mean that there are only 11 cities on the map that are "the most important" or "the best known" cities. Some examples that come to mind and could have been added to the game are: Philadelphia Indian√°polis San Diego Oklahoma Atlanta or even Austin. 
Another thing that I'd like to emphasize is the few amount of villages that are scattered on the map. For example If you go from Los Angeles to Miami you i'll get bored since there aren't much villages  that you can visit while the drive.
Lest's move on to another particularity of the game that it is Rubberbanding it's frightful. You are racing and without reason you get passed by another car just before the race is gonna end. This have happened to me a few times but i was really pissed off.
I'm not quite sure if I can recommend this game it's really fun but there are some things tha might ruin your experience.
I really enjoyed driving and the taxi missions are fun either but the for ex if you go full to the right the steering wheel moves a only a little bit and i felt that  hardly any realistic. The graphics are pretty well done.
[h1] So in conclusion [h1]
If you want a game to drive and waste some of your time going from a city to another is a good game. The races aren't thaaat bad but could have been much better
If you really want to feel an exciting expierence of driving i can recommend Forza Horizon 5 rather than this game.

I am a 51 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 30 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he friended and invited me to join him. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Really awful feeling driving physics (driving feels more like Warzone than any racing game I've ever played), game is 98% empty space with the same 2D-looking tree copy-pasted with tons of texture popping and super low-detail geometry in the distance. Anything more than like 20 metres away looks like PS2 graphics. Game is capped at 60 FPS. Camera angles are very limited and you can't look around very well. City designs are a bit disappointing, VERY small cities that feel like they have no personality or detail. Highway ramps / interchanges look like they were made in unmodded Cities Skylines.

Only really positive thing about this game imo is that the game world is big, but with most of it being basically empty landscape and the handful of cities being like less than 10 city-blocks in any direction, it feels very hollow.

Got it on sale in the Winter Sale so I figured I'd at least doing a little virtual road trip to the grand canyon but the camera angle doesn't even let me get a good view while parked right at the edge, and the awful rendering quality for anything at a distance makes it look awful. The Crew 1 was better. Unless you are literally completely out of any racing content from other games, I don't think this game really offers anything. If you haven't played them yet I think you would get more value out of something like Burnout Paradise (even though it's like 14 years old) or picking up a Forza Horizon game on sale. As it stands I don't see myself really putting any more time into this as it's just not compelling despite it only being $12.

Not even really worth discussing the plane/boat stuff, it's not interesting and probably just waited a bunch of development time that took complicated the physics programming or took away from putting more work into building up the rest of the world or focusing on better game performance.

If Ubisoft makes another installment of The Crew, I suggest they return to only focusing on ground racing (mix of street, track, offroad, and maybe bike) and spend more time on making more responsive driving physics and a more polished game world... and maybe less gigantic 50 metre tall ramps randomly placed in the middle of city streets (kind of makes it hard to suspend disbelief).

I am a 55 yo father. I am a single father to my Son, who is 20 now. I gift my son this game for his birthday, then he installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I would be willing to overlook the game's flaws if it was reasonably challenging and offered good driving mechanics, but it doesn't.

I played a race on the hardest difficulty setting (Ace) with my car's performance equally matched with my AI rivals, and I can easily win races with a 5-second lead. (No, this isn't due to my skill level since I often lose races in multiplayer, it's simply due to easy AI).

The rubber-banding effect (at least on lower difficulties) is also extreme - I can crash out at the back of the pack and easily wind back up in 1st place by the end of the race. Even worse, the game forces you to play each event on the lower 2 difficulties before the hardest difficulty was unlocked, which is unnecessary and time-consuming.

(And no, I haven't tried purposely using underpowered cars just to make the single player races challenging, since this would be pure trial-and-error and would be unnecessary if the game offered a reasonable challenge).

The driving mechanics are also disappointing. As far as I can tell, there is virtually no drift, and it's completely impossible to spin out when cornering, meaning you can take most corners with the pedal to the metal simply by steering. (Even arcade racing games like Ridge Racer Unbounded require you to use skill when cornering so that you don't oversteer and spin out entirely). This makes the driving mechanics closer to Burnout or Mario Kart than a serious racing game. (I even tried tuning the controller settings and turning all driving assists to "off", but noticed very little difference).

There are also a few other oddities, such as planes getting stuck when hitting trees. But again, this is negligible. The fact that the game is time-consuming but offers little challenge and uninteresting driving mechanic's isn't. The only real saving grace might be the multiplayer (since all cars are upgraded for free when playing multiplayer and no mindless grinding for parts is required), however games like Forza Horizon 4 probably offer a much better multiplayer experience.

Overall, I don't recommend this game at all except for young children or people who don't play racing games with more realism than Mario Kart or Burnout. It's all flash, but very little substance, and seems to be more of a cash-grab than a well-designed product.

(P.S. I also think the publisher may be deleting negative reviews, since i recall this game's average rating being "Mixed" a few months ago, but all of a sudden it has hiked to "Very Positive").

Never expected that this game deserves a review, but after the release of Unbound recently. I would feel that this beats Unbound easily despite of its age. Here's on how I see TC2 from my present self:

1. Criterion doesn't take the conventional 'hyper-realistic' route for Unbound and apparently some people like it as a change/dynamic/variety... BUT, unfortunately, TC2 balances it all. Ubi also tried to be different in addition to include every technological advancement/prowess at its time. (Criterion gave Unbound ray tracing, which isn't possible for TC2) TC2 also offers replayability value so it's a big win.
2. For the sake of story-telling/lore, Unbound takes a win here. However, TC2 never meant to be a singleplayer prodigy title. Ubi opened a blank new page to start a new journey. TC2 focused on vehicle optimization and gameplay features instead of storyline (that also explains TC2 story kinda stale/leaving players hanging)
3. Unbound rises rage and anxiety for many people (especially for the fact that Unbound being a $60/$70 game) while TC2 being the character it delivers. (TC2 already fine the way it is) TC2 tried and get improved overtime, so by now the player base is moderate enough for the skill ceiling, which is explained that Unbound definitely not ready (yet) as a competitive title.
4. Obviously, TC2 has microtransactions, but why does it even matter? IT'S ALL COSMETICS. I'm not gonna buy a brand new release merely for the lore. I bought this for 18 months and I feel so thankful that I can still play it until today, giving this a taste of RTX 3060 that my 'revolutionized' internet caf√© has. I paid ONLY (due to exchange rate, so approximately) $7 for the whole experience (I'll continue my road to 100% assuming that I have the chance)

In conclusion, TC2 wins, at least from the perspective of a third world country. Let them feel the experience of Unbound, who you ask? people who ACTUALLY bought it. They always took money for granted. Having the privilege of better govt (policy) and stability, who doesn't want to live such an ideal life? But ironically life is just that miserable... ^-^

I could feel the guilt weighing heavily on me as I sat at my computer, watching as the macro I had programmed took over and played the game for me. The sound of engines roaring and the sight of my competitors falling behind filled the screen, but I knew that I wasn't the one responsible for my victories.

I had always dreamed of becoming a top racer, but I had never been able to put in the time and effort necessary to get there. So I had resorted to cheating, using a macro to do the work for me.

At first, it had seemed like the perfect solution. I was able to dominate the tracks with ease, and I even started to receive offers from teams and sponsors. But as the accolades poured in, I couldn't shake the feeling that I wasn't truly earning them.

As the truth about my cheating was eventually uncovered, I was banned from the racing community and ostracized by my peers. The sound of my computer shutting down and the sight of my once-proud achievements disappearing before my eyes filled me with a sense of shame and regret that I knew I would never be able to escape.

TLDR: Emphasizes Quantity over Quality.

Graphics:
Rather dull, dead looking colors with even the most beautiful of places lacking appeal.

Storyline:
Absolutely miserable. Both the Stories and the Storyline have the appeal of a 4th grader's fiction assignment.

Price:
The average person will likely quit fast, buy it on sale.

Difficulty:
Pretty easy when the game works well, extremely hard when the game bugs out. Keep in mind it's an arcade racer type game, meant to be repetitive and easy.

AI:
They aren't even really AI. The "AI" are just other cars with completely preset paths and decisions, making them rather easy to figure out and beat (sit in the back of a race and watch how every moves, now do it again. It will be identical).

Cutscenes:
Absolutely miserable. Ubisoft neglects cutscenes majorly and it shows. They all look like something you'd see in a 6th grade computers class where they're working with Prezi.

Fun:
It's fun when it works. Unfortunately, that's only half the time.

Sounds/Music:
They sucked. Bland noises and only pop/dubstep-like music.

Replayability:
I could 100% see replaying it... well, maybe not the whole thing. There's some things, like the 45 minute Hypercar race, which are just unbearable to do again. I could see how you could return to regular races though.

Controls:
Each class of cars feels absolutely horrible at first, but soon you'll have an extremely tight grip on it. You feel like you have total control of every car.

Performance:
Worse than Cyberpunk to power something that looks worse than 2012 NFS games.

Modding:
Unfortunately no mods will ever be publically supported by the game. Ubisoft decided that always-online with other players was the best approach, meaning there is no way to mod the game.

Selling Out:
Ubisoft has absolutely sold out.
- "Special Edition"
- "Gold Edition"
- "Season Pass"
- In app purchases
- A literal battle pass (yes, in a racing game)

Similar Games:
I'd say anything in the Need for Speed series would be pretty similiar.

Bugs:
- Random crashes
- AI teleporting to win races (yes, that happens)

Adding my additional thoughts.. I am still not a fan of how the game handles. I have tried to change some settings (graphics) from medium to high to see how it could affect framerate but nothing really changed. I did not find a way to select a locked fps of 30 or 60fps in any menu (unless I am blind). But there is also no FOV slider and I found that playing and just simply driving around the map causes me to have headaches after 30 minutes, something I never experienced with Grid, NFS, Gran Turismo or Forza in my limited experience with those games. And this is really odd because my astigmatism usually triggers headaches for FPS and third person action games only, never an arcade/simcade racer game. I do not understand why it is happening with this game specifically.

My nephews have no issue with the game, so maybe it is really just me. They have fun, but even watching them play gives me headaches over time still. 

As an arcade racer, I can't really recommend this game. But for something different and on sale, it is a packed game for what it offers, but it really isn't for me.

Will I buy Crew 3? On sale maybe to give it another chance in the future. But this game, glad I didn't overspend on it with those DLCs or vehicle packs.

Overall a pretty fun arcade-like all in one racing game. Tons of different styles of races to do and plenty of content to play through and a very extensive list of IRL cars to buy and play with as well as a massive open world mimicking the US. They recently made it so you can buy their "Moto-Pass" (Their rendition on a battle-pass) with in game money which I commend them for doing so. Surprisingly the game is not completely dead I have seen quite a few people most of them seemingly veterans to the game but also a surprising amount of new players. In conclusion if the game is on sale I definitely don't think you will regret the purchase there is at least a few hours of entertainment to be had here undoubtedly.

The map makes this game. If you want a driving game with a massive open world to explore, while also having decent races to do, this is it. While the driving may not feel as intuitive as games like Forza Horizon, it feels fine enough and doesn't take too long to get used to. Having access to a manual transmission mode is also nice to have. The graphics are great at times and awful at others; in terms of cars, most of them look really good, and the lighting is also decent as well, however the city-scapes and buildings don't look so great, and the cities in general feel pretty barren. The variety in vehicles is also nice, however I personally find myself almost exclusively using cars, unless its for a specific race; while the vehicles handle just fine, I find the game to certainly be more land-vehicle oriented. You will find some big name car brands off of the roster (like Subaru), but all in all its a fine game, almost entirely worth it if you just want a big open world.

The controls are straightforward to learn, and even as someone who isn't familiar with cars, it was an excellent introduction. As a note: I recently re-purchased this game on Steam after pre ordering the collector edition four years ago. I had played the game for a bit less than 72h back then.

Three years ago, I wouldn't recommend this game at all. The changes in its handling, physics, as well as how new content was delivered, were all terrible. The game went from enjoyable handling model to "how the hell do i control this soap?"
Then as years passed, the game went through drastic changes, its only mistake being that those occurred in the span of [b]four[/b] years. 

The grind has been greatly improved, it isn't a second job anymore. Handling is fun with all its quirks and features, being tough to master but easy to get by. The premium motorpass (battlepass) has recently been made available for free if you've got enough in-game money (bucks) that is. The plethora of Motorflix episodes (new races being released monthly) are fun and very well made for the most part, altho the current latest events (Into the Storm) was a bit underwhelming as it had half as many events as the previous episodes, altho it has a lot of untapped potential. If you get the game now, you'll face a mountain of content waiting to be explored.

I'm glad I decided to revisit this game after all these years. It has become quite good since then, and is a nice break from games that attempt to incorporate more sim-ish models into their handling and physics. It's dumb fun, and that's all I could ask for.

First the mechanic part of the game is excellent. You can tune cars, customize almost everything from exterior to interior, from top to bottom. Second part is Map and Cars, you have a lot of cars in this game from BMW, Mercedes, VW, Ferrari, Lamborghini, Buggati, Ford, Nissan, Mitshubishi etc. Its playable with friends and very rewarding mechanism and a lot of Missions and side missions and new missions every week. You want to play street races no problem there is street racing mode. You want street race but faster sure there is Hypercar mode. You are bored of racing, you prefer drifting, well dont worry there is drift mode. You are more of a drag race mother*ucker, say no more they made drag race mode. Wait a minute i dont like street racing, i want to race on track with pro cars and F1 vehicles, okay we made that too so no worries. Well what is with people who like offroads and motorcycles, well we thought about them too, we made rally cross and motocross events so jump in and start playing. And thats just begining of playing, there are boats, planes, there is even military hovercraft, These guys thought on everything. So dont wait and buy this game and start playing it today. If you want someone to start playing with feel free to add me. KUDOSHIJR RECOMMEND THIS GAME!

I apologize for the constant complaint. I would just like to point out that this is a very respectable game. I just come across a lot of issues. That being said, here is my issue. I have looked up plenty of tutorials and all of them I have followed. None of them have fixed it. I do not mind the low frame rate, my PC has old specs so it is to be expected. However, it is the constant frame drops that anger me the most. Cruising around I average 60 FPS (since it is capped at 60) with frame drops down to 0, and back up. Usually it is only for a few seconds at a time, however, occasionally it can last up until a full five seconds. I do not know about the other players, but I do not want to be going 200 MPH and not know where I am going for 2 seconds. Not just with cruising, but with in game events as well. Drifting puts my average frame rate to about 36 FPS (of which I am perfectly content with) but with frame drops happening every 3 seconds where my game would quite literally freeze for 1-4 seconds before resuming. Very. Infuriating. I have put all my graphics to low and exited all background applications with no results to show. Nothing has worked. Last time a developer has told me exactly what I have done already, so I will put this into another sentence to make it clear.

If I hear another person tell me to verify my files, disable background applications, turn down graphics, or use a trouble shoot wizard of some sort, I will lose my mind. These generic steps I have tried and do not work.

best game imo

!!!DO NOT BUY IF YOU USE CONTROLLER!!! 

I recently bought a Xbox official controller. I tried to use it in the game but when you try to change the key-binds, it does not even care what key-bind you set, it just keeps the stock key-bind and ignores what you told the game to set the key. Also, the stock controller key-binds are trash. Ex. Acceleration & Brake for the controller is automatically set to "W" and "S". I don't know of any controller that has "W" and "S" on it. Keep in mind, you can't change the key-binds, so you will just have to stick with a, "One-hand-on-controller-one-hand-on-keyboard" method of playing. 

On the plus side, the graphics are pretty good and the use of cars + planes + boats + motorcycles makes this game very diverse. The map is also huge with 80+ miles from one end to the other. I also like the use of real life cars, it makes the game feel more prestige with this addition.

If you look, my steam account has over 3400 hrs on beamNG.Drive, 3000 hrs on GTA V, and on my Microsoft account, 200 hrs on FH5. In my opinion, these are WAY better options for a "Vehicle Simulator" and these should be considered when you buy a car game. Overall, this would fall about 7th-8th place of the best car games iv'e played. (Iv'e played better Roblox games). And my score would be a 4.5/10

I hope this helped

Edit: No Steam Deck support, another huge turn off, but I guess that was to bei expected. Ubisoft already milked the game pretty dry, no need to appeal to Deck users. Such a shame as this would probably play well on the Deck and offer a still pretty much unique racing game experience (if you can ignore the battlepass crap, that is).

TL;DR: Getting shafted by what is essentially greed sucks, especially when the thing that you paid for doesn't actually deliver enough to be recommendable.

Such a shame it had to go this way, I really like the possibility to have cars, bikes, boats, airplanes and even hovercraft available in the same game, especially with the weekly time/score based competition.
Sadly, the game is lacking in almost every aspect and only very little has been and is being done about that.
- The performance is getting worse, despite the graphics not getting any better.
- Having to launch the uplay app every time I want to play this game is annoying, but I guess that is something we will have to live with these days, looking at how many other games have similar situations going on
- Content for most vehicles besides cars and bikes is running thin, there haven't been new tracks or vehicles or air and water based racing in a long time.
- There is next to no street or touring bike exclusive content, sure it's nice that they let you use bikes on the same tracks as the cars, but the bikes massively outperform the cars in PvE and there are only a few bike limited tracks in PvE and even less in PvP.
- The rate at which new cars get introduced is fine, I guess. What isn't fine is how overly expensive all the vehicles are when compared to the amount of cash you get as rewards.
- The micro transactions used to be completely optional, basically only allowing players to shorten the grind to obtain all the vehicles they want or need using a premium currency, but I guess that doesn't bring in enough money. So they decided to add cosmetics which are mostly unlocked using the premium currency, but as that somehow wasn't enough either they just couldn't resist following the most recent micro transaction content trend and introduce battlepasses. If this was a free to play, fair enough, but as you might spot on the store page, this isn't one, in fact, they even want you to buy the season pass. But as that isn't enough either they have made it impossible to collect enough premium currency to obtain their battle pass without paying at least 10‚Ç¨. To make it even more insulting, half of the currency you can earn during each "season" is locked behind the premium pass, the free rewards are extremely weak, however the rewards behind the paywall are vehicles that outperform the limited selection of non-premium vehicles you can get for the leaderboard (summit) events during the battlepass 'series' (season), rather than the usual, completely acceptable cosmetics.
- The fact that there are so many cars which you cannot get via gameplay but only via micro transactions by now is just not okay. Especially not when there are ranked activities which require a new class of vehicle and most of the vehicles of that class are locked behind that nasty paywall and the "free" ones are the worst performing ones.

As you might be able to tell, the last points are what drove me to post a review for this. I absolutely despise having micro transactions in games that already have a price tag up front, season passes are already bad enough on their own, but now you can't even expect those to grant you access to all content of a game you already paid for.
The Battlepass and the way they "justified" the recent changes is intolerable to me, not only did they take away the possibility to obtain the premium currency for free on daily basis, they also introduced loads of cars which are obtainable with the help of premium currency only.
So, why did they remove the possibility to obtain larger amounts of premium currency for free? From their announcement you can gather that they didn't want too many daily activities overlapping with eachother (fair enough, could have integrated the currency rewards into the ingame progression systems, but well, didn't happen) and, to no ones surprise, that they didn't feel like they got enough money out of the game to keep up the support for the game.
With that reasoning in mind I really get the feeling that they don't actually want this game or rather the series to keep going, choosing to go the lazy route, adding content that basically is just fancy reskins instead of improving and continuing the content that is already there.
I guess we will see how this will work out for them and wether or not this will mean the end for The Crew in the long term.

I got this game on sale and while there are parts that I don't enjoy, I'm pleased to say this game is happily worthy of it's full price. If you see it on sale, snatch it up.

This game has a greatly detailed and expansive open world. While you can quick travel to locations (and it can certainly be necessary to use quick travel on shorter gaming sessions.) taking the time to travel through the open world is highly interesting and rewarding. The game has many fleshed out major cities and suburb areas, incredible land marks like the grand canyon, and some cool sites like Cape Canaveral.

There is just about every type of race event you can think of. From boats to planes to cars and even hovercraft. You can do street races, demo derby, monster trucks, air stunt events, deliveries, and my favorite, drifting; just to name a very small few of the types of events you can partake in.

There is a really fun exploration mode where you are given an approximate location for a site to visit, but you must deduce specifically where to find the site. This mode has you traveling along various regions, often requiring you to manually drive from the previous location to the next location. At the end, you gain a special vehicle which can only be obtained by doing these events. It's very fun and very rewarding.

My gripes are:
* Handling and physics are a little to arcade style for my preferences.
* Progression through improvements and upgrades is uninteresting. 
* Specific cars only work for specific modes. If you get a rally car, you can't tune it to be used in street or drift races. The car is locked to the specific event type, so you can't use a rally car for street races (for instance) even if you wanted to.
* There is literally NO vehicle damage.
* The lack of a compelling story is moderately disappointing.
* Instead of "Experience" to level up, you gain social media followers. The more followers, the higher your influencer level.

"Experience": Experience and levels being based on social media influence is the stupidest thing in this entire game. Social media being a plague to humanity is glorified and almost worshiped in this game. Don't quantify your self-worth based on "followers", "likes", and "comments". You're an incredible human and the sum of your worth is not by how you influence people because of pictures of food on some website, but by your own personal accomplishments and not by what other people think of you.

Handling gripes and suggestions: I'd like to see slightly (or vastly) more realistic physics as an option and then group people into lobbies or shards that use a similar level of realism.

Progression gripes and suggestions: Once you get a max level set of parts for one road car, you can use those same parts in any other road car. It works like this for all vehicle types. Unlock max set once, use the same parts in any other vehicle of the same type. It's boring. I'd like to see cars upgrade more gradually and with a greater level of verbosity to the part names, descriptions, and the effect that the parts have on the vehicle. Instead of obtaining car parts exclusively as "loot" for winning an event, simply lock parts behind player level and/or car level as well as cost requirements. The "affix" and "set bonus" system is just silly and weird to me.

Tuning gripes and suggestion: Allow any car to be used in any car event and rely on the tuning of the vehicle to allow it to enter specific events. Have a rating for race types that your car needs to meet before it can enter the event. If your car has a high rating for rally but a low rating for street racing (due to how it's setup via selected parts), then the car won't be allowed to engage in the street race until you equip parts that increase the street racing performance.

Vehicle damage gripes: Why is there no vehicle damage? This game is so incredibly detailed and vast. I would like to see some kind of vehicle damage. It doesn't have to be BeamNG Drive levels of detail, but some kind of vehicle damage system would be preferred.

Story gripes and suggestion: I know a lot of people don't care about stories and often skip through them, but I enjoy them. The seeming lack of a story in this game, while being minor when considering the scope of the game play, is still disappointing. Any kind of story presented is a generic "I'm going to beat you in this race!" ... "What you won?! How dare you beat me!" and forgoes any sort of deeper plot.

All in all, I really like this game but it could be made so much better. This game suffers Quantity over Quality. And while the quality of a large portion of the game is very high, some portions were overlooked or intentionally made less complex for the sake of casual audiences. 

I think the thing preventing me from playing until my eyeballs bleed is: the progression and parts system. I got my car upgraded to max on the first sitting. "Need for Speed: Heat" has a far more compelling upgrade system. Considering the depth and scale of this game, I'm surprised they went with such a shallow system for progression.

Do buy if: You want a *gigantic* and detailed open world with an almost uncountable number of diverse race events and endless things to do.

Don't buy if: You want realism or interesting progression.

Crew 2 is an arcade racing game that builds on the first game's experience. On the American continent, we have a large open world, cities with their main points of interest, and four different types of vehicles to compete on the roads, off-road, on the water, and in the skies.

Despite the game's obvious arcade nature, it feels surprisingly good - the cars are heavy, react differently to various surfaces, and the level system provides fair balance in online racing. This game is a good racing game to introduce genre to your friends - it doesn't require a wheel to play, and the diversity of content will always allow you to rest a little and play around with different activities and achievements.

The game is a little pricey for its age, but I would definitely recommend picking it up on sale.

This is interesting game but I don't know how it play this game

It is called crew 2, but forming a "crew" is pointless. No co-op missions, and the gameplay is geared towards playing short races for small money for hours to get enough money for decent cars. Or, you can spend an extra $40 to $70 for credits and hopefully get the more top of the line model. That is per vehicle price. Outrageous. The skill box are useless as it is all about the part rating number. Skills have little impact. 

I try to interact with others and create/join crews, but the conversations are limited to preset emojis and tag lines. Often leading to long games with no one in the maps. And when there are other players, everyone pretty much lone wolfs. 

Buy the game on sale = or >50% off and you get some good play out of it. Buy it at full price and you will be disappointed. Don't bother buying credits. Waste of real money as the new vehicles shine rubs off very quickly, so you will not get your money's worth. As mentioned above, a new car can cost more than buying the game.  Other comments already cover about the Season Pass as well. Base game is enough for a few weeks of fun, if you didn't pay full price.

Biggest disappointment is the Motor Pass and how you have to buy it in order to unlock the items you win with achievement points that are earned by grinding. Otherwise, you can look at the item you have enough points for, but can't get it unless it is "free". Anything  that looks cool will cost more credits than you can earn in the game.  Again, only recommend the game if on sale. 

UPDATE: Came back to this game and saw a neat update. There were "step" missions to earn vehicles. After a few hours to complete one mission the award was a crap car. not really worth the replay. Uninstalled again.

The Crew 2 is a strong competitor to the open-world live service arcade racing genre. Visually flashier than the first game, but also lacking in unique locations and a move away from embracing the full continental US experience. 

The driving is great with a little bit of understeer here and there being common. There's also a ton of vehicles to get and 16 racing styles, including things like monster truck rallies and dirtbike races. 

Overall, it's a game full of content with a ton to do, though the overall atmosphere suffers as a result of the switched focuses.

If you like a long explanation, here is mine:

When the game first came out, it was Wonderful. there were in game events, stuff to do, fun to be had, friends to play with, etc. the items on the shop werent too bad, you could earn in game credits to buy shop stuff. cars were easy to tune and fun to drive. that was over a year ago. i stopped playing then because there was an update they did where you couldnt earn coins to buy stuff in the store anymore. there were reaccuring bugs with the land/ground where the cars glitched through. the sound would come and go as it pleases, and the graphics would stutter. (No, not a computer issue. i checked.) 

Coming back to this game, playing on 10/13/2022, this game isnt worth it too me. The glitching of the cars through the ground seems to be fixed. however you are still not able to earn coins via events or races. so you have to use real money to buy extra items for your car. (Note: most of these items are cosmetic). The Graphics are still stuttery, but not as bad as they used to be. the sound goes out on some cars. you sometimes hear the squeal of the tires or the engine, other times you dont hear anything, just the whine of the turbo like its an electric motor. not cool, especially for us manual shifters who base it off of sound. the community in game seems dead. i hardly saw anyone anywhere when i explored the map. i even hung around the old popular spots like the dock or the rally race tracks, and the demolition arena. only one or two were there, but just afk. it use to be Full of people all the time. was so much fun. 

So, in all, I would Not recommend this game. it is a waist of money now, and the fun you would have had in the beginning has died out. If a third game were made, i most likely would not buy it.

The Crew 2 is a giant open world racing game where you can use land air water vehicle to compete in the world. You, the main protagonist will participate in LIVE event to reach to top/podium of the event and defeat the champions on each four factions.

There isn't much story to tell except to beat the champions as mentioned above, so if you are looking for a story driven racing game, this is not the game for you to get pumped because of the story as it has none. I would say this game is on the dumb fun side so you can do whatever you like in this game.

With that being said, let‚Äôs talk about the gameplay, The Crew 2 packs with multiple driving physics depending on the class/faction you picked. Providing you unique driving experience for each factions, but not all driving physics are excellent to say, as a matter of fact some of the faction driving physics is borderline bad, for example drifting gives you zero feedback as if you are just swaying your ride and pray it don‚Äôt sway to a wall for no reason. 

Having a large roster of rides provides you choices to pick your favorite ride and customize it, most of the customization doesn‚Äôt include licensing so Ivory Tower went ham with how the body parts look like compared to Need for Speed/Forza as you can do so much with licensing.

As for monetization this is one of the grindiest racing games I've played for a long time. You basically have to keep grinding the longest race to get the car you like and then re-do it all over again, making it feel like a chore. However, the more you play the game you get comfort points to increase your stats so you could have 10% nitro boost or increased payout/experience gained in a race, making it very friendly for veteran players to grind. The game also rocks with the battlepass system so you can get limited edition themed cars and cosmetics, unfortunately there‚Äôs no way for you to earn premium currency anymore. 

If you want to get competitive, there‚Äôs always weekly ranking system where you get rewarded with cosmetic for doing well in ranking, but do be warned though, platinum ranking is filled with veterans and tryhards you probably need a friend or two get you through the rankings.

In conclusion, the game is pretty cool, I find this fun because it‚Äôs a no brainer racing game to relax yourself with. If you ever consider buying this game, probably wait for the discount, it‚Äôs a lot better. 7.5/10

After seeing the recent positive reviews I figured I should give this game a chance. It definitely kept me engaged for a few hours, but in a very love-hatey way. There's lots of variation: lots of different types of vehicles, and an enormous map. It just sucks that they don't feel good- as an arcade racer, nothing feels fast or fun. The map is disappointing- I don't actually want to drive through *any* areas  in this game. This is all not to mention that everything else in the game: the interface, characters, "story", all of the context that you're racing in is completely soulless and uninteresting. Lots of racing games have varied soundtracks with some good songs / radio channels, but I found almost all of it pretty unlistenable in this game.

So I decided to buy this game during the Steam Summer sale, before Forza released the Hot Wheels DLC. I really tried to get this game to work for me, in the sense of enjoying it. Trust me, I really did. But sadly, I could not. *Spoiler Alert:* I do make a lot of comparisons  between the Crew 2, vs Forza Horizon 5 and Need for Speed: Heat, so watch out.

I was not aware until I purchased the game that this is one of those Pay to Win games (P2W) . Where if you want a car, even an average one, if you don't have enough credits, you gotta pay real cash. It does not help that the Devs intentionally make Credits hard to come by. Even worse, some cars are locked behind seasons pass or seasonal only, meaning you can not get it unless you buy a special pack, or happen to be here at the right time in order to obtain it.

In contrast, Need for Speed: Heat and Forza Horizon 5 make Credits easy to come by, especially the later, and Forza Horizon 5 practically gives you cars as you progress through the game. 


As for the map, which was my main selling point for buying the game, unlike Forza Horizon 5, the map may be huge, but it's mostly empty with few details outside the major cities. Another thing that disgusted me was the outdated and bland customization system. You have no access to community made logos/decals, and what little you have, can only be applied to 16 cars in the game. That's right, you can only customize 16 cars before you have to delete a skin. You can not even have more than one skin for the same car. This is something that makes nearly no sense. In contrast, Need for Speed Heat while it does not give you access to community decals, does give you plenty of decals to choose from, and you can have up to 100 skins for your cars, including the ability to make more than one skin for a car. And as for Forza Horizon 5, while I have not hit a hard limit, (I do have more than 70 skins made, including community ones), in theory lets you have unlimited skins, and community made decals.

In conclusion, while a good number of games do have micro-transactions (what game does not these days?), including this one, the system really does not belong in racing games. Unlike some games like those of War Thunder, and World of Warships, which have little to no competition, The Crew 2 has plenty of lower cost, non P2W, non micro-transaction racing games available. There are so many that it would be impossible to list them all.

So in the end, unless you do not mind spending a lot of extra cash on this game, I would advise you to look elsewhere.
