This game has realistic looking cars based on real car models. For most car brands the sports cars models are mostly available. This is like a large open-world of the entire United States and you can drive around freely and then join different types of events as you want. Otherwise you can just drive around from city to city or to other locations and get on the highways to race with other real players. I like that this game is not too punishing for getting damage to your car and you car gets quickly auto-repaired in like one minute by itself so this game is not too serious or stressful. So you can make mistakes and crash a lot if you are just learning as a new player. I play this game with xbox 2 elite joystick but other players use the actual steering wheel and gear shift gamepads also. This is a pretty accurate simulation of actual car driving and you can keep driving around for hours freely in the open-world environment or join any races, speed traps, do courier missions to deliver items, look for special loot boxes for rewards, etc. You can also get off the main road and drive through the deserts, fields, and any other terrain on the sides of the road it's all part of the open-world terrain. You can go anywhere on the map basically if you just like driving around freely and it's a ton of content in terms of events.
fantastic

The good part is the novelty of a gianormous miniaturised continental USA and a huuuuge vehicles variety all of which got a full detailed cockpit view even for the aircrafts, greatly appeasing the most autistic of us. The bad part is its ubisoft lol so where do we start with the bad? The racing itself fun for most part aside from feeling like you're racing toys in a static make-belief world which to be fair is the definition of racing videogames, but this one shows it better than anything especially with how all the performance parts are interchangeable between different brand cars. Up next is the dialogue: that was cringe beyond cringe so as an avid fan of cringe even i had to mute it cuz it was just too unbearable, like it was hazily written by some drunken dudebro degenerate. Of course it has a "battle pass" which locks away the coolest lookin cars... what else what else did they lock, oh right the fps to 60, thanks again consoles. So overall a fun time waster with lots to do, great for listening to newscasts and stuff! Play it before they shut it down forever.

For how much they're charging for this 4 year old game, and for what they showed in the trailer, I expected far better. However, the graphics are pretty low quality for the highest settings, and the physics engine sucks to say the least. There's also a frame rate cap which you can't remove on a game that should be taking full advantage of a high refresh rate display. Neither driving, flying or boating feel very polished. Your money would be far better spent on a game that does each single thing better, such as Forza Horizon for driving. Cannot recommend, especially at the price they are charging.

I feel that The Crew 2 is a very underrated driving game. There are many people that say it is the worst driving game, but personally, I feel that it is one of the best, I even prefer it to Forza. It was great diversity and has a very fun and interesting feel to it and Forza just doesn't get. I love the map and the races and activities are great. It's a great game to relax to.

I just wish however that the graphics were a little better, although the new graphics update has helped. Maybe there were some more cars (although not too many as I feel that too many cars is also a problem). The car sounds are okay but they could be better. I will say however that the races are very easy, and there is almost no competition (unless you do PvP), personally this isn't and issue for me but others may find it to be. But no other problems stick out to me.

I tried this game when it was free for a weekend, and decided to buy it. It is a very relaxing racing game which I play after office hours.

Positives:
- There is a lot of content, and not the usual boring and filler material. So many types of races, including destruction derby, bike races and boats will keep you busy.
- It is easy to upgrade cars, you get a lot of materials to upgrade. Live Summit changes every week and provides good rewards so leveling up is easy.
- This game has one of the best ways to display the map that I have seen in a racing game. 
- On Normal level, it is an easy game, so I play the race on normal and win, then try it on hard (and win again most of the time). 

Negatives: 
- Ubisoft
- In a lot of races, you race against a ghost and there are no other drivers.
- Soundtrack is mediocre. Racing games like NFS and Forza have one of the best soundtracks, something you enjoy while driving, but not here. Very okish. 
- Graphics are good, but at some places, houses look like boxes. 
- Online component is dead.

I also find the plane controls pathetic, although I am not sure if others feel this too.

Overall, it is worth the money. Get the gold edition, so that you have a headstart with extra cars and content.

Although, Forza Horizon 5 is the best in terms of visuals, storytelling and variety in cars, I still come back to this game to travel around the United States with one of my best friends in cars, planes and boats. I prefer the photography in this game as it's much simpler to use (though fh5 does have more camera like settings). While this game is now FIVE YEARS OLD, they still update it regularly with summits every week, new vehicles every couple months or so and even have improved the graphics with some nice new shaders. While this older game cannot compete with many new games with newer graphics engines and optimisations behind the scenes, this game makes it easy to lose yourself or play the same race over and over. 

So thank you Ubisoft for a great game and I do really hope for a third version!

The Crew 2 is one of my all-time favorite racing games, mostly because of all the freedom the player has. I'm not like the average car fan, in racing games I usually like to see how crazy I can make a car look instead of customizing it as if it was a real world vehicle, and the crew 2 is the perfect game for players like me. The customization is amazing, there are dozens and dozens of different parts for each of the nearing 400 vehicles, including a livery creating system to make and share skins with the community. The Crew 2 also has a big variety of vehicles, including my favorite, the DMC DeLorean (though I hope sometime soon they'll add tesla vehicles to the game!). The map is also extremely large, with amazing graphics, especially lighting. The tracks/courses are fun and creative, although some can be annoying at times. Overall, I give The Crew 2 5 stars, and I would recommend the game to any racing fan.

On June 28, 2018 the game was released and  I was one of the first of a few thousand  to buy this game. That was three years ago and I think its about time I gave this game a fair review. Before I bought this game I was playing the TC1 (the first crew game). It was AMAZING and I never played anything like it. It was where "fast and furious meet need for speed" it was cool as crap man. The only thing that I really hated about it was the excessive amount of traffic cars in EVERY RACE. All they had to do was take out the traffic cars out of most of the races (this does not inclued open world driving, hot pursuits, and other small events). Other than that the game would have Achived perfection.

 Then the second game came out; and boy where do I start?

The game itself had some really good features such as vehicle customizing (I think they thought it through very well), cars that were not added to the first game, avatar selection(even though you couldn't change the avatar at all Which sucked). The motorflix which the most recent updates thus far was in fact pretty fun (except "The Chase", that one sucked really bad). There was some stuff out of the ordinary and it was really
fun and different and it was something to enjoy and it really changed things up in a good way.

However the game has more cons than pros, and prepare to get burned Game Makers.

Most of the vehicles in this game are worthless. There are over 500 vehicles and only about 50 of them are any good. In my opinion they wasted a lot of time getting at least half of those cars in the game, and believe me I test drove over 400 of them(yes that how many I own in the game). I did however like having a good variety. But to in all honesty: HOW MANY MORE CARS DO YOU NEED TO PUT IN THE GAME?! I mean seriously its like their trying to turn this this game into Forza Horizon.  

There are no cops in this game( so if you don't like hot pursuits you don't really need to read this part). I'm a huge NFS fan and I love a good hot pursuit. After I bought the game and then found out that there will be no hot pursuits added, I was pissed. Because in the previous game those event gave a variety of fun. Seriously it never got old, and it was a good money maker when it came to buying cars. They wanted to GIVE the game a "MOTORSPORT THEME". They thought that "Legal racing was the way to go in this game". Boy are you guys so wrong. I got so bored doing the same races over and over and over. Even with all the current updates I still get bored playing this game. This is one of the biggest reasons I think this game sucks.
Oh and F.Y.I. one of the latests updates called "The Chase" is an absolute insult to all NFS fans.

There are no faction races. ( not yet at least). In TC1 they had Faction Races, those were the best races and the best money makers. A few of those race took me 3 and a half hours to complete and they were SO MUCH FUN!!!!!! I hope they add them to TC2, because if they don't, the game will just become a bigger disappointment. 

There not much of a story line. Now keep in mind this was not much of a disappointment, however there is no plot and it made the game a little dull. Basiclly it was: go in, do a few race and kick the champ's ass. Thats all it is and it sucks. However with the moterflix added it did change some things up, but there no main plot and I'm still disappointed.

The Motocross Discipline: So back when the game was new the dirt bikes were fairly easy to handle, although the handling wasn't perfect, it was still fun. Then a few years have past and then an update came out, that update was supposed to improve the experience of the dirt bikes or something like that.
But the game makers screwed that up too. The handling ended up being soooooooo much worse and its frustrating to play now. I MEAN SERIOUSLY!!!! HAVE THOSE MORONS (referring to the game makers) EVER RODE AN ACTUAL DIRT BIKE DIRT BIKE!?!?! ITS NOT THAT HARD!!! I own one and last I checked the handling is not that difficult! They should of left that alone, it was fine the first time. 

Boats and planes: It was fun to an extent but some off it got really frustrating. I'm a fan of Ace Combat and I'm a pretty good pilot. Handling the planes in this game was a little tough however. I got the hang of it but I still wish I had the same control setup as ace combat. I tried too make the setup a little similar, BUT GUESS WHAT!!!!! THE BLOODY GAME WOULD NOT LET ME!!!!!
WHAT THE HELL!?!?!
 As for the boats: having them in the game was cool and like the planes there was a little trick to winning races in them. The powerboats weren't bad, but when it came to the jetsprint boats, lets just say I was not a happy camper. Seriously! LEAVE THE BOATS AND PLANES OUT THE CREW GAME!!!!!!! They just don't belong. This was another big reason why I think this game sucks.

You have the summit, the online racing and a very similar mapping setup which was all well and good. But then they took the best stuff out and replaced it with garbage and then managed to flush down the toilet. I've seen people screw up sequels, but DAMN!!! This is ridiculous. ALL YOU HAD TO DO WAS MINIMIZE THE AMOUNT OF TRAFFIC CAR BEING SEEN IN THE GAME AND GIVE IT A NEW STORY LINE AND THE GAME WOULD HAVE BEEN PERFECT!!!!!!!!! BUUUT NNNNOOOOOOOOOO!!!!! YOU JUST HAD TO GO IN AND RUIN IT!! And at this point there just constantly adding a high dose of suger to dog crap.

I'm sorry, but you don't just go and take a wonderful game and turn it to garbage with a sequel. I think thats the biggest disappointment of them all. If you like motorsports then I do recommend this game. But if your like me then save you money because I give this game a big fat noooo. I just hope that the game makers read this review and take it into serious consideration when making the The Crew 3 if they plan on it.

I am a 41 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 16 now. My son got this game for Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, got my car and map and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

I ignored this game for many years because I thought every single event involved a mix of cars, boats, and flying. Oh no, I was very wrong.

Had a lot of fun with this one. I bought the base game on sale for 10 bucks. The season pass isn't necessary as it just adds more cars and a slight discount in the game store, but you don't need it, you just gotta play and earn stuff that way which to me is more fun. 

I'm really glad there's actually characters and narratives that kept me interested. A lot of racing games are just go here, do the race, go to the next one, etc etc. But here the story, leveling up, loot and characters made it feel like I was aiming for a goal. 

There's a TON of stuff to do. Street racing, hyper car racing, drag, drift, power boats, air races,  rallycross, hovercraft, motocross, touring, demolition derby, and MONSTER TRUCKS!!!! Those were my favorite. It's all arcadey feeling, so you can turn your car in mid air and stuff like that. There's also HUGE JUMPS which are so much fun. Plus there's loads of side activities like taking photos of landmarks, animals, stunts, etc, and escape missions, speed traps to name a few. Not to mention weekly events (called Live Summit) that have leaderboards and rewards are based on how many points you rack up against other players. 

On top of all that there's these really cool movie like scenarios called Motorflix where you have to either do events for movies, or smash vehicles like youre in Burnout 3. AND there's treasure map type missions where you get clues and have to find the specific area and take a picture, which when all are completed you'll get a nice reward. All of it is completely optional. You don't have to do every single event in any section to progress. I jumped around a lot. When I got tired of races, I'd jump into some drag races, monster trucks, photo ops, live summit or the motorflix. Just whatever you wanna do.

Speaking of rewards, this game gives them out nicely. Not just cars either. You can get parts, cool visual stuff like neon underglows or colored tire smoke or nitro colors. It's basically a dopamine simulator. 

Got all the achievements, completed the live extreme series and did over 70% of street racing, offroad, freestyle, and pro racing events. I also did all three seasons of motorflix and part of season six. There's still a ton of stuff left to do if I wanted as well.

The only stuff I didn't like was that since you can fast travel to any event, there isn't much reason to drive around the world. Kinda wish they would take a Forza Horizon approach and have billboards and fast travel boards scattered around to encourage this, but the way the whole game is set up is still really fun. I wish the game had more steam achievements too since there's so many things to do and unlock in game. Kinda surprised they had em in the first place considering it's a Ubisoft game. But the worst part is it's online all the time, which means when Ubi shuts down the servers the game will be dead, probably. So it's possible the game has an expiration date, unless they let people play it single player. 

And let me point out that while the game is called The Crew 2, I basically played almost the entire game by myself. I joined a crew for a little bit and did some stuff, but then I guess I got kicked out but all of my progress was still there so no big deal.
e

Pros: Cool car game, the map is badass
Cons: Pretty much everything else

I overall enjoy TC2 but it's very much an arcade game before anything else, consistency and predictability are not there for those who want to challenge themselves for lap times and such. It turns into a grindfest very fast and the constant barrage of Ubisoft sh*t to keep those dopamine hits coming gets old. There's a constant battle against RNG factors that honestly just gets tiring. The "tuning" adds another layer of personalization, but it feels more like a band aid for the lackluster handling model and just another minigame to get the highest numbers somewhere.

I love the idea but despise the execution as it's the epitome of modern Ubisoft "game design." Usually I'm the type to say git gud but can't reasonably expect anyone to sit through the grind this game calls for. Games need to stop relying on spoonshoveling mountains of garbage into kids' mouths and get back to making genuinely entertaining experiences. The racing genre has a million opportunities for innovation, stifling that for more microtransactions and RNG mechanics just shows how gutless and disconnected this medium has become.

I played the game in 4k on a 3080 with an XBOneX Pro controller. All detail was maxed except AA and blur. I do not recommend a keyboard and mouse.

PLEASE NOTE, even though I have left comments on, I am not interested in you telling me that I should put 4000 hours into a game I don't enjoy so I can "git good", and then I would like it. That is a stupid argument. Don't be stupid. Skill is not indicative of enjoyment, and I have better things to do than bash my head on what I personally feel are bad / mediocre games on the off chance I could maybe like them one day. I have a life and don't play games to develop Stockholm syndrome.

Neutrals:
- There are 25-minute single races. In an arcade racing game. I hated this. You may not.

Pros:
- Most of the time, it ran at 60 FPS.
- Large map, but...

Cons:
- There is little to see on the map that's interesting. Sometimes the trees change type, and maybe there's more water in an area.
- The upgrade system is painfully bad and is essentially a lootbox minus a box. You win a race, you get some random upgrades. You can have, say, LVL 65 in every part but one and it may take you 20 races to get an upgrade for that slot. Yes, you can get RNG'd into having to grind races to upgrade. It's as bad as it sounds.
- VERY hard to read tracks when racing. Sometimes you'll just go in the wrong direction because you have no clue where you are intended to go. You essentially have to watch the minimap because watching the race itself is useless as the tracks are signposted more poorly than any other racing game I've played in recent memory.
- The AI is tuned incredibly poorly. Either they're WAY ahead of you even though you're driving a better car and the race is half your level, or you're absolutely demolishing them. There is no adjusting this. It is infuriating.
- All the cars control like they're racing on butter. Everything slides uncontrollably and really shows off how shoddy the physics are in this game. You will constantly careen into stuff. And speaking of...
- Hitting damn near anything brings you to a complete stop. You don't slide past stuff like other arcade racing games when the corner of your car clips a bush, you come to a complete halt. You now have to restart the race because you WILL NOT catch up. Is the race 12 minutes long? Too bad. Now to find that race reset...
- The menus are awful. I had to actually Google how to restart a race and quit the game. Thought they'd be in the in-game menus? Hah, you simpleton! You have to hit Y to bring up a special menu that hides in the corner of the screen, but only comes up while driving! Want that menu on a keyboard & mouse? NOPE! Those buttons sometimes show up at the bottom of a different menu where you may have expected them in the first place! Well, sometimes. Only when the option for the buttons feels like appearing. Sometimes it just doesn't.
- The characters are astoundingly annoying and are written to speak like a Red Bull commercial. The overtly positive "might as well be saying nothing at all" style garbage non-speaking flows out of everyone's mouth continually. The story is non-existant. If you love chasing "followers" (ugh), then go on Instagram and be vapid there. Even the shell of a life you pretend to have there will be more fun than The Crew 2.
- Very odd and frequent framerate drops when physics items interact with each other. This happens often. Adjusting settings did not help.
- It looks worse than the original did somehow, and the first was quite an ugly game.
- One of the worst game soundtracks I've heard since Gone Home. This low-budget mess of a soundtrack complete with incredibly shrill lady-punk songs. The only good song on the soundtrack is Airbourne - Running Wild, and it's over 10 years old. Yes that's an opinion, and your mileage may vary.
- I am an idiot and preordered the Gold Edition because, hey, this is a sequel. It's going to improve on the original in many ways. (Narrator: "It did not.") They didn't listen to a single damn complaint about the original, even though nearly every review both professional and amateur said the same things (Many of which are pointed out in my review here). This makes me madder. You couldn't even be bothered to fix the obvious? Bad form, Ubisoft.
- They haven't improved on any of these complaints since launch and instead insist on putting out boring Live Events. This is because Live games make more money (See Destiny). Make no mistake, this is a product, not art and it definitely wants all of your money.
- I genuinely tried to like it and power through some of the issues, but I just can't any more. I hate this game. It is one of the worst racing games I have played in recent memory. Even the two most recent Need For Speed games were better, and they were mediocre at the best of times.

UPDATE:
Tried it again several years down the road. Holy god there is so much seasonal crap slathered everywhere, and random things to level that they're trying to sell you it was nearly impossible to figure out what to do next. This somehow got even grosser than it was. Oh, and even though the menus have changed, they now make LESS sense due to the sheer amount of layered-on garbage that, AND I still couldn't find a way to quit. I had to Alt + F4.

I purchased this game with intention to play less than 2 hours and refund. Just giving it a try for fun.
Now, 43 hours later I find myself that I can't stop playing and not planning on stopping.

Ok, I purchased game couple days before motorpass started so that was good way to get started and get prepared for new motorpass.

Let's talk about what I like and what I dislike/would change or improve:
Graphics:10/10
Weather and day/night: 10/10
Cars: 10/10
Amount of vehicles: 10/10
Amount of events/ amount of what to do in game: 10/10

Ok, so from playing this many hours game definitely doesn't feel like grind fest or that you have to pay real money to progress. Game actually feels sit back and relax, if you buying cheapest cars from every category than it's easier rather than grinding to buy most expensive cars.
It took me first 20 hours to save up $2.3 million to buy my first bugatti. now I can do it quicker, BUT instead of going for RICH perk, I went for FAMOUS perk and can get 100k followers every 30 minutes. I prefer followers over money.
Currently icon 300 so not bad going.
But back to the cars and legendary upgrades and perks. I thing I aboslutely hate and it's not having presets!
I mean how hard is to have preset for every car, for example Bugatti with followers preset and second preset would be skills doubled. I really do hate constaly swapping and finding the correct set I have to the other one. This can take several minutes!

Map, is absolutely huge. Plenty to do and also different climates.
Let's move onto tasks. This is another thing I personally would change is that completing race on easy difficulty count as compelted towards your 100% completetion. INSTEAD of this should count as 0.3% and you would have to complete all 3 difficulties to count towards 100% completion. Yes it is easy, but it would make player to play harder difficulties.
Once car is fully upgraded even ACE difficulties are bit easy, i wish it was harder than it is now.

I played PVP for 2 races, not big fan of PVP to be honest, so not gonna leave feedback other than not a lot of peope playing it as waiting time was over 4 minutes and only got 4 players.
Not very popular.

SUMMIT on the other hand is fun, great challenge against other players, making you try and try over and over again to get better scores. And has great rewards. I do like this one.

MOTORPASS again I enjoy this with great reward. BUT, what i don't enjoy is that motorpass still has 56 days left and i completed it already meaning all those daily/weekly challenges are pointless sometimes even summit has 30 token as reward which is so pointless. AGAIN why they couldn't make further small rewards after stage 50 in motorpass for people who completed it just so they don't feel like for next 55 days all these daily/weekly challenges are absolutely uselles with 0 reward!
Motorpass was easy, but didn't expect to complete this early...bit of waist from now

Flying planes: Controls are horrible and i struggle a lot especially in summit and this is one of my weakness that i can't get 100k in flying through zones. Not my favourite

Lastly when you trying to climb leaderboard in crew2.
First you learn track/circuit AND THEN once you know track you learn all the shortcuts. In crew2 you could be the best racer, but if you don't know shortcuts you will never get to the top of leaderboard.

Just imagine New York hypercar takes 33 minutes without shortcuts OR 24 minutes with shortcuts. 9 minutes saving!

Final verdict: I got gold edition with huge discount to play for 2 hours and then refund. That was my intention. Now still playing it a lot.
Fully recommended, still full of players. Don't think it's worth it for full price, but it is fun game.
My bigest complain are not being able to do presets on cars for different legendary upgrades. That was my biggest hate. Otherwise all positives ;)
Hope this helps someone on making decision whether to buy game or not

i got it with season pass for 75% off and...my short review is....''i wish i could refund it''

i played an hour and forgot to shut off the game for the next 5 hours so ignore the 6h playtime of original review

the game literally use a minigun and throw you pop-up, notifications, rewards, unlocking, etc..... the first hour you play you just cannot play for how much the game wants you to know about every single events and whatnot.... after having skipped 90% of cutscenes and barely read what the events are.....i was just left in game who felt like playing a sandbox game like Garry's Mod.....the game don't tell you what to do and you do as you want......ok but when you start you should have some place to be brought at that isn't a tutorial that teaches you how to inhale and exhale with your lungs



the gameplay feel like Forza Horizon as an ''off brand knockoff''......the steering is unresponsive...the only way i could say it actually is, is by using a steering wheel to drive around.....the fps maxed at 60fps also make the game not as responsive as it could so...expect a lot of imput lag as if you were playing in 30fps




side note to the Dev team.........can you fix the launch of the game? having an ssd with an i7 12700k taking 30+ sec just to launch is disgusting.................oh and the 2nd time i opened the car market to check what i was supposed to have with the season pass made the game crash...uppon going back i got what i was supposed to have

The game is quite fun; not a super fan of airplane and speedboat racing but they are there and you can ignore them if you don't like it.
The car racing part is quite enjoyable; if you like Forza Horizon and similar you will feel at home with this game. The map is quite large and it is very well made in terms of replicating various areas of USA. The areas are quite small and not reflecting their real counterpart but it feels like being in New Mexico, Los Angeles, Seattle or New Orleans, so good job on that.

The driving model is OK; it is not a simulation by any means so don't expect each car to drive considerably differently as they would do in more simulated games; but at the same time the fact that the game is more arcade allow you to do fun things while driving. AI cars are few and in between but they are there, and crashing won't affect anything.

The game is based on missions for most part, you progress by collecting prizes and using money to buy new vehicles; so nothing you haven't see already. The fun part is mostly the various events, which are kinda like Forza Horizon; where you participate in specific race categories or events that put you in various setup and conditions to win those races. You can play at your own pace and you can even totally ignore the main competitions and just focus on side events, like the taxi driving missions or the delivery missions and so on. You also have a house where to store your stuff and various areas where you can see your avatar walking around; but it is not GTA: can't get out of the car at any time or there is anything to do on foot, it is mostly for looks

Being a Ubisoft game you can expect monetization and it is there in your face; the game expect you to pay money to buy the usual pass for more content and in game currency to get upgrades for your cars (which are basically like loot in rpg/shooter games, with different color and rarity). I didn't spend a penny simply because I don't even play online, so to me the improvement of the vehicles is something that is relative; but if you play online a lot, you will feel pressured to upgrade your ride or spend a lot of time grinding for parts.

There are also hidden cache spread through the map; you will hear a sonar beep when close by and it is a matter to run around remote areas to find those boxes, which will give you parts and cosmetics at random.

Other than that, there are not that many negatives; I never tried the "crew" feature, which is one of the main selling point of the game, but I don't play online nor I care, so YMMV. 
It is a nice game that you can play even to just roam around doing side missions, in a semi-realistic setup; and it is entertaining for a while. Eventually it gets old like every open world game but there is a ton of content and you can play most of it with just the game purchase (buy it on sale, it goes often on sale)

A 7 out of 10 for me; well done and enjoyable but does not flip the racing game world upside down

I don't even like racing games normally but this one is a lot of fun. Crazy vehicle variety including cars, bikes, boats, planes and even helicopters to choose from. The map is vast, open and really fun to explore. Races have no cheap rubberbanding; if you have a better car than your opponents you just leave them in the dust without them magically catching up to you. Also since i'm a sucker for games where loot is a thing, i kinda like the car upgrade mechanics even if they are quite simplistic. Other than that, you have many different options of visually customizing  pretty much all of the 500+ vehicles presently available in the game. My favourite customisation feature has to be being able to share livery designs with other players or using their designs on your own vehicles. And if all these features weren't fun enough, this game is fully playable in co-op. You can play almost every event in the game with up to 3 friends and you all share the rewards, so it's fun and worthwhile. Overall this is game is great fun and I would recommend it to anyone who appreciates fun driving, big open worlds and co-op. 




DO NOT BUY IF YOU'RE LOOKING FOR A SIMULATOR OR A GROUNDED EXPERIENCE, YOU WILL BE SORELY DISAPPOINTED.

Notes: The game's strongest point is the huge variety of vehicle types, ranging from land, water and air, and even a mix of the first two with the Hovercrafts! [note that a vehicle of a certain type (ex. street race) can't be used in another race type from the same discipline (ex. drift) so you'll have to buy a different car for each type of event] As said before, the game features free roam and the map is huge. Next to the races it has a few little free-roam challanges like Speed Traps and Slaloms and often updated quests. The game is very arcade-y and not very realistic physics and handling-wise, but is extremely fun, and the assists can be turned off.

Additional notes and things I've missed:
- The game has a similar-ish performance system to the one in Need for Speed: Payback, but way less furstrating and only really required in late-game grinding.
- The game has a character select at the start similar to that of Need for Speed: Heat, and clothing customization mid-game, with some unlockable clothing.
- The game has leaderboars for races, the Live Summit, the free-roam activities, and probably some other stuff that I don't remember.
- The game has been getting updates since its release in 2018 and has a fairly healthy playerbase

* If I missed anything or you think I've got something wrong, please feel free to comment

The game isn't perfect but not a flop. The insane gravity makes cars behave differently, lots of grip unlike Forza Horizon 4, Forza Horizon 5 or GT7. The camera is really weird, you won't have the freedom of looking around freely; it snaps right back to where it initially was placed (third person). The map is massive well not actually the real life distance of US states but it took me 55 minutes at an average speed of 170 mph to go from Los Angeles to Maine but there's a downside, only eight players are allowed per session. Finally, there's no sense of speed. Going 100 mph or 160 kph feels like going 50 mph or 80 kph which is terrible though car interiors and exteriors are so accurate.

Can finally recommend this game again since Ivory Tower has finally begun to address the main issue I've had with this game; the inconsistent handling model. 

A bit of backstory - since the Inner Drive update, Street Race and Hypercar had their handling models updated to be more grippier and more intuitive to drive compared to when the game launched after an initial test run on certain cars during the Blazing Shots update. The problem is, for the next two years, this change was not applied to the other ground-based disciplines (Rallycross, Rally Raid, Touring Car, Alpha GP), meaning all cars in those disciplines that released prior to Blazing Shots and Inner Drive were on the older, outdated handling model while cars that released during and after those updates were on the newer handling model, leading to inconsistent handling and a heavy imbalance of performance in said disciplines.

Now as of Season 6, IT is gradually working on righting this wrong, starting with a full rebalance of Rallycross, followed by a current test run with Touring Car. I still think this change should've occurred during Season 3, when these disciplines were the main focus content-wise, but I suppose it's better late than never at all.

This game is just garbage. I got it on sale for 20 bucks basically and it's not worth even that. 

Physics engine is wonky and cars dont handle like you'd expect. it doesn't feel like a fun arcade racer or a fun simulator, it just feels gross and floaty. Gearboxes dont behave the way you'd expect in auto or manual mode. A one-ton truck feels the same as a mustang, it's just pathetically bad. 

It looks like crap. It looks like something from the early PS3 era. Customization is laughable when you cant even remove stock liveries from vehicles. The RPG style upgrading of cars is also complete trash. 

The controller support is bad. It does not support a native xbox one controller wirelessly at all. 

Microtransactions are another thing it has, avoid it, dont give them your money it's not worth it. 

This entire game is just complete and total garbage barely worth 3 bucks let alone the 60 or more it sold for previously.  Do not recommend, infact I would avoid. Go spend your money on Assetto Corsa, BeamNG, Forza Motorsports, anything else other then this pile of absolute garbage. 

Oh and one last thing; I dont know who designed the Lake Tahoe region in this game, but whoever you are, you  should be absolutely ashamed of yourself. You took this big, beautiful region and instead of giving it any kind of love or attention, you crushed it down into a pathetic water feature that would be found on a golf course.

Terrible game.
It feels rushed, like it was put together on a time crunch.
A lot of assets and sounds are reused from previous ubisoft titles, such as Driver:SF, A much better game might i add. Probably one of the few decent games ubisoft has ever produced, but this isn't about driver:SF.
Right, back on track.

Buildings are copied and pasted, Horn sounds are taken straight from Driver:SF. For an open world game, this world feels incredibly lifeless like it was slapped together in a week.
To even think that this game was full price at some point makes me vomit. The visuals are way to poppy and "Graphic design is my passion" Esq, the voice acting is terrible and whereas TC1's story made complete sense, this feels like a concept game more then an official release.

Whatever you do, do NOT pay for this game.
If you decide to buy this game, you will see exactly what i mean when you play it for a few hours.

chocolate chip cookies

Ingredients
150g salted butter, softened
80g light brown muscovado sugar
80g granulated sugar
2 tsp vanilla extract
1 large egg
225g plain flour
¬Ω tsp bicarbonate of soda
¬º tsp salt
200g plain chocolate chips or chunks
Method
STEP 1
Heat the oven to 190C/fan170C/gas 5 and line two baking sheets with non-stick baking paper.

STEP 2
Put 150g softened salted butter, 80g light brown muscovado sugar and 80g granulated sugar into a bowl and beat until creamy.

STEP 3
Beat in 2 tsp vanilla extract and 1 large egg.

STEP 4
Sift 225g plain flour, ¬Ω tsp bicarbonate of soda and ¬º tsp salt into the bowl and mix it in with a wooden spoon.

STEP 5
Add 200g plain chocolate chips or chunks and stir well.

STEP 6
Use a teaspoon to make small scoops of the mixture, spacing them well apart on the baking trays. This mixture should make about 30 cookies.

STEP 7
Bake for 8‚Äì10 mins until they are light brown on the edges and still slightly soft in the centre if you press them.

STEP 8
Leave on the tray for a couple of mins to set and then lift onto a cooling rack.

RECIPE TIPS
FREEZING THE BISCUITS
If you‚Äôve frozen the biscuits, take them out and arrange them on a lined baking sheet. Once defrosted, pop them in a medium oven 190C/170 fan/gas mark 5 and heat for 2-3 mins to crisp up. Don‚Äôt leave them too long or they‚Äôll dry out.
STORING DOUGH
You can keep the uncooked dough in a sealed container in the fridge for up to two weeks. Simply take some out, dollop on a lined baking tray and allow to come up to room temperature for 5 mins before baking

Hi! If you are looking for a good online multiplayer racing game then you have come to the right spot. The crew 2 is a fun racing game that has more than 100 cars! And of course, it has the Mazda RX7 and the Nissan GTR. And for the dodge fans, it has the Dodge Challenger Hellcat and Demon! This is by far the best racing experience you have played. The graphics mixed with the high-quality engine sounds make a good combination for a racing game! Have Fun!

Perfect Game
game is capped at 60 frames max, it's so disturbing / unpleasant to play such game in 2022

Let me start this off by saying if you only plan on playing with a controller go for it which is why i'm recommending it ONLY if you're using a controller

 If you have a sim rig or even just a basic setup with a wheel you will be extremely disappointed. The force feedback literally makes no sense. You'll be taking a corner and when the rear end slightly slips out from under you the force feedback just decides to fu*k off in a direction that makes no sense. There's an insane amount of options missing that would be in any racing game whether it's an arcade racer or sim with wheel support. 

Next issue is the fact that for everyone on PC you are limited to 60 fps with no work around.....like...WHAT!?!? Iv'e literally never played a game on PC that limited my frames to that of a console. What was the thought process behind this decision? 

Interface controls moving around the map with a wheel is extremely frustrating but you can get used to it

I have to scroll through every single wheel till I find the ones I want as there are no filter options unless I missed something but come on guys 

On the vehicle selection screen there's these flashy light things grazing across the car tabs and is super annoying / makes it hard to see what you're looking at

Some of the cars wheels maximum size still are too small and makes the tires look like they should be on a rally car

Just because we have a sim rig doesn't mean we are limited to sim racers. Sometimes we just want to screw around in an open world environment and zone out which Horizon is great for but that's literally all we have and every NFS title with wheel support is probably even worse than this

In the end if your game is going to have wheel support why even bother having it in the game if you're not gonna do it right?

I'm really enjoying this game, so far. There are so many things to do, it's not just about racing - or even one style of racing. 

You have street races, off-road races, Motocross, boat races, hovercraft events, and airplane races and stunt competitions. 

There are also "story" events, where you cruise from one town to the next, uncovering clues about a character's life. The clues lead up to the discovery of some unique car: a lowered, tricked Road Runner or a rare, vintage Porsche... and so on. 

I think I've spent more time in this game just driving around than actually engaging in the race events, and I'm still having fun.

Let's see:
- FOMO out the ass with the live summits, and their cars remaining in the shops just to show you that you can't get them anymore, you fucking loser
- Map wide as an ocean, deep as a puddle
- All the vehicles feel the exact same, not that you have any reason to use anything that isn't a car to begin with
- Event rewards so low you could go through Ferrari's entire convoluted process for buying one of their newer models and still have wasted less time and money than it takes to buy a mid-range car in this game
- Draconian Battlepass system that requires you to play the game religiously and has all but, what, [b]three[/b] significant rewards (as opposed to pathetic amounts of money) locked behind a paywall?
- Motorflix was honestly just a shit idea in general. We're six seasons in and they have managed to have exactly ONE good idea (Stories, which they managed to miserably fuck up anyway and there is only one story that's any fun at all)
- Obtrusive activity UI that takes up the entire screen for a good five seconds if you dare to hit a speedtrap while trying to get somewhere
- Obnoxious sidekick who will chime in at random times to make asinine remarks that aren't even correct ("Why haven't you tried Street Racing yet?" is a stupid question to ask when I'm currently driving the car you get as a reward for completing the **** Street Racing storyline!)
- There is precisely nothing good about this game, its only pro (and the only reason I still play it at all) is that you can't buy the much better Test Drive Unlimited games (anymore in the case of the first two games, yet in Solar Crown's).

Yeah, pass on this one. Get the first instead.

Ubisoft is a GARBAGE company! They literally have so many problems that they disbanded their customer support team. There phone numbers don't work and they don't even have live chat or the ability to submit a support claim. I had to create a second ubisoft account so that my 2nd son could play and when I did I used the same email as my first account. It worked and I was logged in. Then I linked the new Steam purchase of the game. Everything worked and both my boys were able to play last night. A very good game, a lot of exploration can be done, nice sounds and great graphics considering you get quantity over quality. I will admit that things like, character animations, character models (cutscenes), floating trees and voice overs ruins the experience a little bit. The character animations look very unrealistic. When roaming around, you'll often find floating trees. Character models in cutscenes look rushed, and the voice overs don't really fit in to the animation of a character. Overall, a very good game. I recommend it if you like racing games, and exploration games. 9/10.

I have not even played a single race and I am already annoyed at this game. Who in their right mind in the development team, thought it was a good idea to let you select a character and then NEVER AGAIN be able to change it. Honestly, is this for real? I selected one just to see what the game was like, I did not feel like dealing with a selection process and would go back later to then choose what I wanted. Or so I thought. First, why am I stuck to one character forever? this is the most ridiculous  decision I have ever seen in a game. What game does not let you start over, or start with a new character. I dont care if it has no bearing on the gameplay. What if I have other people in my family that want to play.(which is actually a reality) So they have to play with my character? It is real dumb. It seems that this game was made under the conditions of one person ever using a computer forever as if people have NO families, and no choice of change of mind on who you want to look like.  It has a clear definition of what type of thought process the game has been developed under. Anyway at least the game is fun overall but some design decisions are silly

Just picked this up for 10 bucks.  Wish I bought it years earlier.  I can't believe how massive the open world is and you can quick swap between car/bike, boat, or plane, on the go.  This is like GTA 5 without the weapons or the story, except you get 20x the vehicles here.  If you're like me and love riding motorcycles in real life but get a lot of crappy/rainy/hot days that prohibit you from enjoying them, you can always ride on here.  The terrain is extremely realistic from mountain top to valley.  The vehicles vary from passenger cars, sports cars, hyper cars, vintage cars, f1, wrc, drag, drift, suv/pickups, monster trucks, motor x, atv, buggy, utv, cruisers, naked/sport bikes, speed boats, hover craft, acrobatic planes, helicopter and several others.  So much to do.

V1. So much wasted potential. At the foundation this a fun arcade racer with plenty of racing disciplines to experience. However, the number of disciplines is also a huge problem. Each one is only developed to the bare minimum. Detailing makes it clear that the game is capable of more, but instead they focused on live service content updates rather than upgrading the base game. If you want variety and arcade racing this is for you. If you were hoping for more effort in the racing itself this isn't for you.

As an FYI if I were to place the realism/arcade of the racing with Forza Horizon as the perfect middle ground IMO this would be about halfway between arcade and the middle.

+ Weather. Actually, looks nice for this being an open world racer.

+/- Scaled USA map. The overall geography of USA is modelled across the map. Several miniaturized cities with relevant landmarks are also modelled. For the most part things look pretty good across the map. Except being a racing game the lack of curvature (both right/left and up/down) in the roads can be very unnerving. Many games way older than this one has more accurate road shapes so its really inexcusable. 
+/- Physics Model. Based on the config screens for cars this game was capable of much more detailed physics. However, none of this is properly explored within each of the disciplines. Once you've used one vehicle you've used them all (aside from just being generally better at doing things).

- Progression. You get money, unlock races, buy cars and that's it. You really aren't gaining any new experiences from unlocked content. Its just the same thing in a different car. There isn't the reward of learning the ins/outs of your vehicles and getting better that you would normally get in most racing games.
This game has great variety and a big open world. But the mechanics of the game aren't too good. But the pros weigh out the cons and this game is really good and fun to play.

First a note: don't care for the constant internet connection required aspect... That said, there is a lot to like. The open world is vibrant and dynamic, the cars are spectacular and the gameplay isn't boring a bit repetitive at times but not boring. It does have a currency purchase mechanic with real word $$, though I'm not sure if there are things that you couldn't otherwise get without spending more than the initial cost of the game.  Its a joy to have a game where I can drive my favorite cars around with things to actually do vs many games where its an unlock after most or all of the games missions have been completed...

So much content you'd almost never have nothing to do
On the other hand, quality of said content isn't the greatest sometimes (but still playable of course).

As a tip, don't grind a single race too much even if it's a very good grind, because it's very tiring.
The Harlem West grind has become a threat to my mental health (10/10 still don't have the full set bonus after 100 races)

This game has received years of post-launch support from the developers.

There's always something new to do whether it's a vehicle you wanna grind out, boosted part set you wanna collect, or new missions from an update.

This game is a great example of "fun playing solo, even better with friends". There are weekly Summit events that can be played solo perfectly fine and there are TONS of events to run through individually, but if you have a friend who also plays this game the possibilities are literally endless. There are a few cases when the weekly Summit has included a speedtrap event which is much easier with a friend since you can slipstream them and get a faster speed, but other than that I don't think friends are needed for any other aspect of the game.

Being someone who owns an entry-level gaming computer, this game has served me well. I'm able to get a consistent 60fps on medium settings running at 1080p which is not achievable on most games for me.

Its a fun, arcade style racer! Don't expect realism, especially with the nitro aspect but a fun game none the less! Only thing is that you can easily outclass the recommended level of the missions and so they end up being WAY too easy.

I like the variety of racing (street cars/hyper cars/grand prix/touring car/dirt/planes/bikes/hovercraft/boats/jet sprint) & a helicopter for looking around. Drifting feels weird/wrong & I just dont enjoy how the hovercraft responds. 

The map is huge. Being able to swap between vehicles as you are driving around is cool.

For my taste in handling I need to use Advanced Tuning on every vehicle. Advanced tuning is easy, once you get the hang of it but having to always fiddle with it on every vehicle gets annoying.

Parts - Grinding for parts has gotten easier but rerolling them to the stats you want is a pain & absolute waste of resources. 

Weekly Summit - I enjoy doing these but unless you have the right completed part set & know all the shortcuts its difficult to get platinum.

Motorpass - I like the idea of unlocking rewards for doing tasks but let me earn the green CC in game. 

Headlights - why have them in the game if they dont work

Non player cars - oh my these buggers spawn when they want & for some reason I cant see them until Im right of top of them. Some drive over the middle road line, some intentionally block the road & intentionally ram.

One of my biggest gripes is not being able to see where Im going b/c of weather or night or where the road is. There is no need to change the weather & day/night cycle that many times in the NY hyper car race. 

Overall Id give the game 6/10 (If i could earn all rewards in game it would be 8/10) - esp those older sexy motorpass/summit vehicles
I just asked for a refund because this game is so boring, car control is bad (feels like 2004), stupid story, cars sound terrible.Overall this game is not worth my time!

A lot of different styles of racing too, from street, to drift, to touring, or even sea and air.

Although, there are some issues. The story is okay, but could have had more work put into it. Additionally, for a game from 2018, the graphics are kinda disappointing, and the framerate is locked to 60. Lastly, vehicles sound meh, often time lacking the kind of whine or roar that actually gives you a feeling of power.

[h1]tl;dr: Seems to be more of a quality control lacking framework for a live service, a game where the actual game came second in development.[/h1]


This must be one of the worst first experiences I've ever had with a game cause of how many unique ways this game found to frustrate me in only 3 hours.

So, first of all, the menu and UI. Changing key binds in this game is akin to a battle against a very "smart" system that attempts to automatically resolve key bind conflicts. Allegedly. What it actually does is a mystery to me, but it always changed a number of unrelated key binds as well, seemingly at random. Which meant that every edit had a cascading effect throughout all the controls that you had to fix with trial and error. It took me like at least 10 minutes to change 3 binds. And it's not like the game didn't allow my config, it just made it almost impossible to get there.

Second big annoyance: How to start an event from the map. Well, you select it, drive/port to the marker and then you have a access a menu which gives you some information about said event, but to actually start it you have to drive into an adjacent building. Took me a sec to figure that out. But there was a problem. I like to play with a manual gearboxx, meaning of course, to drive forward i have to shift into first gear.
In my case the button to do so being the same button to access a menu. So, every time I ported to an event, I had to reverse out of the marker to then be able to shift up and drive into the building.
You could say that this is my fault for rebinding the "shift up" key, but this is the second most common layout that works on every other open world racing game that I know of.

But maybe this game isn't supposed to be played with a manual gearbox. Because every time a race starts, the HUD takes a few seconds to appear. For some unknown reason. So i guess I just have to shift blind till 3rd gear.
And can I just say, having the speedometer on the left side is very jarring. This is more of a nitpick, I'm sure you get used to it, but out of curiosity I skipped through a video comparing the gameplay of 100(!) racing games. Out of 100, only 2 had the speedo on the left. "The Crew" and "The Crew 2".

To cap off menu and UI, at one point the game remembered that I bought the gold edition and added a bunch of stuff to my invetory, wich triggered about a million progress bars and achievements to appear successively. Which would be annoying on its own, but for the first half I could not interact with the world anymore for some reason (I wanted to buy a car) so I had to just wait it out.

Oh, and I haven't been able to find the "quit game button" yet. Maybe the game has one, but I searched for a good while and did not find it in any menu. Only ever quit with Alt-F4 or the game crashing because I tabbed out. Oh well.

Let's get the "story" out of the way really quick. I would not mind a non-existent story, or even a bad one, but everything here is just weird..? Why do i find myself in a stunt event where suddenly some cringe(I don't even like that word) NPC comments every single move and also talks like I'm driving his car? "Oh, my new paint job!" "Don't faint" "Oh, my shocks!" - Who even are you? Could you please stop talking for 3 seconds? I think I never had a game where I had to turn down all voices to zero.

I also don't get why the some races insist on bending reality itself. Nobody needs immersion, here is a tech demo with no actual effect on the gameplay. But I'm not impressed, only confused.

Maybe a good time to talk about graphics and art style. The cars look nice. But many things are just not up to the standard of 2018. The environment is bland and lacks detail, the draw distance is noticeably low and and the cutscenes appear to have a fixed resolution. Why can I see pixels in a pre rendered cutscene? 1440p should be within reach for a game of 2018.

I don't really care for the art style, in my second race I already saw some over the top animated smoke cosmetic so I guess there is just no consistency with the realistic environment/cars but whatever, it's not really a problem just not my cup of tea. I just screams of microtransactions and you can see how the need for flashy cosmetics overrules the integrity of the visual design and that's always sad.

And lastly.. what about the driving experience itself?
I do not have a problem with arcadey driving models, but I would like my car to be predictable. This game has some sort of assist (I disabled all the official assists within the options of course) that intervenes [i]sometimes[/i] when the car is about to slide out. If I steer too hard into a corner, I would expect my car to oversteer. And it does. Good. But [i]sometimes[/i] when I transition from hard left to hard right the game limits my steering, maybe to prevent me from sliding out too hard. In a sequence of corners (aka every race all the time) this leads to my car sometimes losing the grip as expected and steering hard into the corner as planned, and sometimes barley reacting.
I don't mind arcadey assists, I mind inconsistency. And inconsistency is usually the argument against sim-racing and in favor of arcade. The goal of arcade is a simple and predictable handling. This weird assist is not a result of arcarde (or sim), it's a result of bad design. How can we have a 20 years+ of history of perfectly fine driving models and a modern game of 2018 feels so weak?

I'm sure this game has redeeming qualities like an overabundance of content and.. many other things.. maybe? But I don't feel the need to explore it further. I can already see more things ready to annoy me in other reviews here, like people complaining about progression and grind. I think I'll try to satisfy my longing for a good modern racing game elsewhere.

Update: ACE still isn't challenging, but I've learned to approach this game differently. If you really want to enjoy it after maxing out, try using lower tiered cars or putting more affixes towards loot find/quality. That helps keep the pack with you so that races don't get boring and you can still max out the car with gold parts to get the most from affixes.

They also added a massive amount of street races, and just about all of them are pretty well thought out, only one or two runs to get the track feel down. There are some exclusive cars due to season passes (motorpass), but none of them really top the leader boards so it's not a huge deal.

Originally I gave the game a negative review, but it's gone through a ton of updates. Some of the issues are still there like locked to 60hz refresh and the photo op/skill prompts during free roam still take up most of the screen for about 20 seconds every time you go through one.

If they could fix just those two issues, mainly the HUD just not working well at all especially with 3 screens... it'd be a close contender for the best arcade racer.

OK.  I'm going to write this as someone who has been a huge fan of The Crew franchise.  The short answer is, "Yes.  I'd recommend this game."  The longer answer is a little more nuanced and if you'd like to read a few "caveats" from someone who still enjoys the game, mostly......please proceed.

I have played this game since launch.  I owned the "Gold Edition" on PS4 and logged A LOT of hours there.  I then made the switch to PC and, as you can see, I've logged over 200 more hours on here.  There are a lot of positives that any number of other reviews will also bring up.  There are also a lot of negatives, many of which are not immediately apparent.  And here is where I am going to bring these up.  They weren't severe enough for me to not recommend the game, but they were important enough for me to mention.

1.  No cross-platform support or cross-play (not too concerned about cross-play though)

It's one thing to not offer this.  It's another to have very specific rewards for completing certain events and not allow people who earned those rewards to carry them over (or even allow them to use MTX to buy them back on your new platform).  Don't get me wrong, if they asked me to pay money for items I already earned; I'd tell them to get bent.  However, this business model here actively discourages people from buying the game on more than one platform.  Seems stupid.  I have numerous cars earned from PS4 Summit, but because my Uplay account is logged in to a steam version of the game instead of a PS4 version of the game......I can't use them.

2.  It's pitched as "any vehicle, anywhere, any time"

No.  It's not.  Sure, there are plenty of events and lots of different vehicles, but the lion's share of events and vehicles fall in to "street race".  There are more "street race" events than all the other "Street HQ" events combined.  There are more hypercars and street race cars than any other class except for MAYBE Rally Raid and Touring Car.  I don't mind these events/vehicles, but it would be nice to get something else.  It's especially bad for Summit as most "special vehicle rewards" are just another street spec or hypercar spec.  The "Xtreme Series" (one of the more unique aspects of the game) has less than ten events and that's after they added some.

3.  It's "grindy".

Again, clearly I don't mind the grind, but I'd be lying if I said a large majority of my time spent wasn't re-running the same handful of events for cash and parts.  The RNG is hell sometimes and certain vehicle types just get aggravating to get parts for.  

For example.  I own full legendary part sets on every single hypercar I own.  I managed to do this in about a week simply re-running the New York hypercar event,  It nets about 300,000 bucks on Ace and yields a BUNCH of legendary parts.  The event is a long cross-country event and takes around 30 min to complete.  Simple enough.  Jump on, run it once or twice, net cash and parts.  But outside hypercars (and one or two street race events) there aren't any events like this for the other specs.  This is ESPECIALLY egregious, because they had stuff like that in the first Crew.  It would be nice if there was a better way of earning legendary sets without relying on Summit or getting to Icon 1000+ to dump a bunch of points in to buffing your loot quality and amount.  

4.  "Vanity Parts" and "Premium Currency"

I have an issue with "pay to customize", especially on a game where customizing is a key component to that experience.  It's one thing to pay $5 to have a gold gimp suit or some such crap on Battlefield or CoD.  It's another to have these "pay parts" on a game all about customizing.  It's made worse by the "Season Passes" having a "regular" and a "premium" version and even the premium pass doesn't net you enough Crew Credits to buy an epic vanity part.  You get a couple extra vehicles (probably another street spec or hypercar).

I mostly bring this up because they used to gift Crew Credits a bunch more and just by saving up a bit, you could put them to use in amazing ways and made you WANT to play.

5.  The "Online" Experience.

It's not great.  It's better than a lot I've seen, but it's still pretty bad.  I've had invites from all kinds of people,  almost none that actually want to do events.  You join someone's crew, you screw around on the map until someone gets bored.  Someone joins YOUR crew, they quit as soon as they realize you're starting an event.  Maybe it's time.  Maybe it's the platform.  I can't say for sure.  I CAN say, the social experience WAS better when I was on PS4.

Last but not least, this isn't Forza.  If you're expecting Forza, then buy Forza.  This is more akin to the GOOD Need for Speeds from back in the day (i.e. Most Wanted, Carbon, Underground).  The physics aren't great, but they aren't horrible.  It's mostly just designed to goof off with and have a good time......not recreating what driving a Bugatti is like.

If nothing I said dissuaded you, then give it a try.....and if you see me around, shoot me an invite.  Just don't be afraid of doing something.

Game has evolved from "Free DLC as long as you wait" to "Buy this car NOW or it will be gone forever". 

They introduced this thing called "motorpass" which is basically events that you play to earn loot. These missions are used to level you up and get unique items like tire smoke, decals, and even cars. The motorpass costs real money and changes often enough to not be worth it.

They try to jump around this by technically making it possible to buy motorpasses with the special currency you earn in game, but the motorpass changes every couple months and it's IMPOSSIBLE to save enough money to get the motorpass free without making this game your life.

Finally, the biggest stab in the heart, is the devs said this game would forever be "free to earn" and the season pass (not the motorpass mind you) would only grant you access to cars as they release and got a special 20% off any item in game. They found a way to work around this completely by making certain cars free but require the paid for motorpass to acquire.

Tl;dr: Abandoned "free" dlc gimmick and made owning the season pass practically worthless throughout update's. Do not recommend investing time in this game in it's current state.

TL ;DR
The Crew 2 is a huge racing game, the best on the market for arcade racing fun (with a bit of realism here and there) and exploration lovers, with a little rpg soul when it comes to vehicles powerups and leveling.
An underrated masterpiece that deserves more love.
I will explain why.

There are hundreds of vehicles in many categories.

--Street cars and bikes, Hyper cars, Drag cars, Drift cars for the Street racing, a "family" of races based on the pure asphalt you can find around the cities of USA, with the most varied race experience in this game.
This is also the category with the largest amount of bodykits and parts, and i'm not talking about vanity items like neon wheels and coloured smoke or NOS, just body parts.

--GT cars and bikes, F1 cars, Powerboats and performance Airplanes for the "professional" category, mostly track races with boats and plane races that are really funny and usually placed in great sceneries.

--In the off-road section you can find Rally cross vehicles, Hovercrafts, Motocross bikes and Rally raid (enduro) vehicles, really funny and you can figure out why by yourself ;) p.s. use hovercrafts only in freeroam.

--Then you have the "non-pro" Freestyle category with Monster trucks, Demolition Derby cars, stunt planes and Jetsprint boats, i just play some monster truck and demolition events, cause i find plane stunt events and jetsprint a pain in the ar se.

Every of the mentioned categories have a lot of races and stunt challenges, but this game seems more focused on the road racing, due to the amount of vehicles and events in this section. AND THIS IS A SHAME, sadly.
JUST ADD A SIMPLE RACE EDITOR, like the one in the first Crew game, dear developers.

The personalization is really good, every single car in the Street racing category has at least 50 different body pieces, combined.
When it comes for vanity items (neon wheels, rainbow smoke and animated glass tints for example) you need the premium ingame currency.

The "POWERUPS" i mentioned at the beginning are basically car parts that you put in slots like brakes, suspensions and wheels.
You get them after every race or event, with the rarity depending on the difficulty level.
Those will give advantages to the player like more powerful or durable boost, better aerodynamic trail, better handling on offroad, more money or followers and a lot more, based also on the vehicle type.
Then there are some special sets of "golden" parts that gives a special bonus when you equip them togheter, like double boost, double followers etc.
Besides those "arcadish" effects these parts will not give any power, handling or speed advantage to your vehicle.

When you level up your followers-level (after becoming an icon, aka level 100) you'll get some points that will increase the same stats given by the above mentioned powerups.

Every week there is a "pack" of races called Summit that mixes some of the categories with some twists, like stunt races, themed races with cool effets etc.
Every summit gives some limited items to players who can place high in the leaderboard, like special car powerups/parts, fancy vanity items like colourful neons, smoke or wheels or even themed vehicles.
It's meant for player that have already completed the single player campaign with a bit of virtual money in the wallet to get the new vehicles needed to complete the races and challenges of the summit.
Those vehicles are always bundled and discounted, so you will get a bunch of cool vehicles at bargain prices.

The driving experience is arcade with some realistic "twists" here and there. Funny nonetheless.
There are many different handling types in every single vehicle of every of the above mentioned categories.
And... EVERY VEHICLE HAS A TURBO BOOST, AKA NOS, called Pro-tox in this game. :D

The map is HUGE AND FULLY EXPLORABLE by air , ground or water.
A simplified version of the united states of murica, with the main cities, roads , monuments and nature beauties.
Lately i'm having a lot of fun roaming around in first person with motocross in the mountain forests , and with airplane between skyscrapers, really cool.
Actually the interiors and the first person in general are very well made, with the camera that will lean in the steering direction in a realistic way...so first person is well suitable for racing too.
Also the sound effects shine in first person. You will hear the wind whistling the faster you go, the wheels and the engine sounds (very well made, top notch) will do the rest.
THE MUSIC is also top notch, with various and radio stations based on your music tastes. Very good track selection and a lot of hours of different songs.

Graphically talking I find this game really beautiful an particular.
And i played FH4 maxed out....but it feels worst in some aspects compared to the Crew 2.
The climates are better in the Crew 2, without any doubt.
A lot of transitions and diverse weathers that can change in a matter of minutes with a lot of nice lightings, shaders on cars and diverse terrain effects.
Car models are really well made and the interiors are top notch.
The terrain and the world in general is very detailed considering it's a racing game.
The world destructability and the physics are ok.
The draw distance is ok, but really shi tty when it comes to traffic vehicles. I think developers made this choice on purpose for console optimization reasons.
This game lacks only in some ultra modern lighting effects but you will not notice cause lighting it's still very well done.
I play with an Xbox one controller and it's great, also funny and not too difficult with my DFGT wheel, but since i do a lot of different race categories....i found myself driving a bike or a plane with a damn wheel :D

The multiplayer can be due the lack of players in other racing/vehicle categories besides street racing.
So grab some friends add them to your crew and solve the problem, you'll have a lot of fun drifting on mountains or racing around :D

IF YOU LIKE ARCADE RACING GAMES BUY IT ON SALE, MANDATORY.
Even without cops (there is actually a cop in this game, but is YOU ;D) , it's at least 150 times better than every modern NFS, and the world map, the exploration factor, the weather system and the fun in general outshines FH4 and his copypaste FH5.
This game is over all the best motor sport game I have ever played

Very fun game, however it would be nice if they could add a update of the map, perhaps adding more locations. Also some different music would be nice, would be cool if they added more. I recommend it, just needs some new scenery and new tunes.
The biggest open world driving game the biggest I have ever played and best for how giant The Crew 1 and 2.

This racing game is more than just a racing game like they promised what it's going to be like, even though the graphic are not as great as the first one, but this one is good enough and fun enough to play with either single player or with friends, it's also very addictive, and makes me wanna play it again and again, i love the crew 2 in so many ways, i hope that this game get more interesting by getting some graphic update or any other content update.

Reminds me a lot about Forza, just with planes, boats and such as well.
Really fun to play, after a bit of tuning and removing of the assisst systems the cars become much more responsive.
The assist one can turn off right away, to tune everything on the car one have to wait until one reaches the first Icon level (there aree 9900 Icon levels), one can get there relatively quickly so isn't much of a hassle.
Works quite well without having to tune the veichles as well and just go with the default, the only thing I strongly recommend is to turn off the assists, as they make controlling the car feel unnatural and for me anyway harder. Everycar can be indvidually tuned, but the assists that is found in the same place as the tuning and is the top category of it is goes for each type of veichle, so if you turn it off for one Street Race car you turn it off for all those, same with hyper cars,hover crafts, race planes, power boats, and so on. There is a line seperating the assists from the normal tuning, the normal tuning is done individually for each different veichle and is not done for all veichles of that category, different veichles also respond different to the same tunings, so that is a good thing. Or one can just go with the default tuning, that one is pretty ok to.

In the first Crew game you where working undercover, pretty much like many of the Need for Speed games, in this one you are a driver making a career, much more like the Forza Horizon Games.

There are tons of different activities to do, everything from classical racing, to Demolition Derby, Monster Trucks, Slalom with different kind of veichles, Air racing and acrobatics, Escapes, Photo Shots, Skills, Events, Exploring, Collecting, Stories, Upgrading with better parts, customizing the looks of both the veichles and your character, as well as designing ones own custimzed looks like in Forza, and customize the chassises on cars, the Street cars are the most customizable ones (There are several different categories of Veichles) and more.  Both PvP, Solo play activities, and Group (Crews), coop play PvE or PvP, depending on what one prefers.

Really loving it and is really hard to put away, although one can buy Crew Credits (Special in-game money aside from the usuall Bucks that is the normal in-game money) there is not really much need as it is not that hard to earn cash. And most things can be bought with normal cash or won through activities and events, there are somethings that can only be bought with Crew credits, but as far as I have seen those are just cosmetic stuff.

The control setup for planes and boats are pretty easy to use as well, not very complicated :).
one can also choose between several different cameras, 2 3rd person cameras, a hood, camera, a bumper camera, and a cocpit camera for all types off veichles, on cars one can also customize how the inside of the cars look. And different cars will look different offcourse depending on what car it is and their make.

There are also both modern and classical veichles.

If you like the Forza Horizon games, then you are probalbly going to enjoy this one as well.
And if you did not think Forza had enough to do, then this one have even more activities to do :D.

It is a fun arcade racer. A good variety of vehicles to choose from, starting from the crown vic taxi all the way to a Chiron and Monster trucks, Rally cars and Motor cross bikes to planes to hovercrafts and whole lot more.

I initially bought this game on the Xbox when it had recently come out and I absolutely hated it due to the physics and complete lack of a story. When I noticed it was on sale about 2 years ago, I decided to try it again on my PC, with hopes that maybe I was wrong, and I was. While the physics are weird and I hate the fact that you sometimes need to fly planes, the wide variety of vehicles, expansive map, and consistent content additions and updates have kept me around for longer than I had originally imagined. While this game is not the best racing game I've played, it's adequate, full of content, and was cheap when I bought it. Cool game as long as you don't mind repeating events, flying planes, and a complete lack of even an average story.
